0003F7r 3                               ; ldy #0        ; Y is already 0 by clearing the line.
0003F7r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp3),y
0003F9r 3  85 rr                        sta status+1
0003FBr 3               
0003FBr 3                               ; Increment the tmp3 pointer so we can use ,y addressing
0003FBr 3                               ; on both tmp1 (the input buffer) and tmp3 (the history
0003FBr 3                               ; buffer)
0003FBr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp3
0003FDr 3  D0 02                        bne @2           ; Increment the upper byte on carry.
0003FFr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp3+1
000401r 3               @2:
000401r 3                               ; Copy the history buffer into the input buffer,
000401r 3                               ; sending the characters to the output as we go.
000401r 3  A9 0D                        lda #AscCR
000403r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000406r 3               
000406r 3               @history_loop:
000406r 3                               ; See if we have reached the end of the history buffer.
000406r 3  C4 rr                        cpy status+1
000408r 3  D0 03                        bne @3
00040Ar 3  4C rr rr                     jmp accept_loop       ; Needs a long jump
00040Dr 3               @3:
00040Dr 3                               ; See if we have reached the end of the input buffer.
00040Dr 3                               ; (only comparing to lower byte as we currently limit
00040Dr 3                               ; to 255 characters max)
00040Dr 3  C4 rr                        cpy tmp2
00040Fr 3  F0 0A                        beq @hist_filled_buffer
000411r 3               
000411r 3                               ; Copy a character and echo.
000411r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp3),y
000413r 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp1),y
000415r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000418r 3               
000418r 3                               ; Move to the next character.
000418r 3  C8                           iny
000419r 3  80 EB                        bra @history_loop
00041Br 3               
00041Br 3               @hist_filled_buffer:
00041Br 3                               ; We don't want a history recall to EOL our buffer,
00041Br 3                               ; so back up one character and return to editing.
00041Br 3  88                           dey
00041Cr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp accept_loop
00041Fr 3               accept_done:
00041Fr 3               @done:
00041Fr 3                               ; Copy the input buffer into the currently
00041Fr 3                               ; selected history buffer.
00041Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr total_recall
000422r 3  85 rr                        sta status+1
000424r 3               
000424r 3                               ; Also save it in the first buffer byte.
000424r 3  A0 00                        ldy #0
000426r 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp3),y
000428r 3               
000428r 3                               ; Move path the count to the data bytes
000428r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp3
00042Ar 3  D0 02                        bne @4           ; Increment the upper byte on carry.
00042Cr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp3+1
00042Er 3               @4:
00042Er 3                               ; Copy the characters from the input buffer to the
00042Er 3                               ; history buffer.
00042Er 3               
00042Er 3               @save_history_loop:
00042Er 3  C4 rr                        cpy status+1
000430r 3  F0 07                        beq @save_history_done
000432r 3               
000432r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
000434r 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp3),y
000436r 3  C8                           iny
000437r 3  80 F5                        bra @save_history_loop
000439r 3               
000439r 3               @save_history_done:
000439r 3               z_accept:
000439r 3  60                           rts
00043Ar 3               
00043Ar 3               total_recall:
00043Ar 3                       ; """Internal subroutine for ACCEPT that recalls history entry"""
00043Ar 3               
00043Ar 3                               ; Generate the address of the buffer in tmp3. Start with the
00043Ar 3                               ; base address.
00043Ar 3  A9 rr                        lda #<hist_buff
00043Cr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3
00043Er 3  A9 rr                        lda #>hist_buff
000440r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3+1
000442r 3               
000442r 3                               ; This is a bit annoying as some bits go into each byte.
000442r 3                               ; .....xxx gets put into address like ......xx x.......
000442r 3  A5 rr                        lda status
000444r 3  6A                           ror
000445r 3  29 03                        and #3
000447r 3  18                           clc
000448r 3  65 rr                        adc tmp3+1
00044Ar 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3+1
00044Cr 3               
00044Cr 3  A5 rr                        lda status
00044Er 3  6A                           ror             ; Rotate through carry into msb.
00044Fr 3  6A                           ror
000450r 3  29 80                        and #$80
000452r 3  18                           clc
000453r 3  65 rr                        adc tmp3
000455r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3
000457r 3  90 02                        bcc @1           ; Increment the upper byte on carry.
000459r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp3+1
00045Br 3               @1:
00045Br 3                               ; Save the current length of the input buffer in
00045Br 3                               ; histinfo+1 temporarily.  Reduce to 127 if larger.
00045Br 3  98                           tya
00045Cr 3  C9 80                        cmp #$80
00045Er 3  90 02                        bcc @2
000460r 3  A9 7F                        lda #$7F
000462r 3               @2:
000462r 3  60                           rts
000463r 3               
000463r 3               
000463r 3               
000463r 3               
000463r 3               
000463r 3               ; ## ACTION_OF ( "name" -- xt ) "Get named deferred word's xt"
000463r 3               ; ## "action-of"  auto  ANS core ext
000463r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ACTION-OF"""
000463r 3               
000463r 3               xt_action_of:
000463r 3                               ; This is a state aware word with differet behavior
000463r 3                               ; when used while compiling vs interpreting.
000463r 3                               ; Check STATE
000463r 3  A5 rr                        lda state
000465r 3  05 rr                        ora state+1
000467r 3  F0 0C                        beq @interpreting
000469r 3               
000469r 3               @compiling:
000469r 3                               ; Run ['] to compile the xt of the next word
000469r 3                               ; as a literal.
000469r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_bracket_tick
00046Cr 3               
00046Cr 3                               ; Postpone DEFER@ by compiling a JSR to it.
00046Cr 3  A0 rr                        ldy #>xt_defer_fetch
00046Er 3  A9 rr                        lda #<xt_defer_fetch
000470r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_subroutine
000473r 3  80 06                        bra @done
000475r 3               
000475r 3               @interpreting:
000475r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_tick
000478r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_defer_fetch
00047Br 3               
00047Br 3               @done:
00047Br 3  60           z_action_of:           rts
00047Cr 3               
00047Cr 3               
00047Cr 3               
00047Cr 3               ; ## AGAIN ( addr -- ) "Code backwards branch to address left by BEGIN"
00047Cr 3               ; ## "again"  tested  ANS core ext
00047Cr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/AGAIN"""
00047Cr 3               
00047Cr 3               xt_again:
00047Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
00047Fr 3               
00047Fr 3                               ; Add the opcode for a JMP. We use JMP instead of BRA
00047Fr 3                               ; so we have the range and don't have to calculate the
00047Fr 3                               ; offset.
00047Fr 3  A0 00                        ldy #0
000481r 3  A9 4C                        lda #$4C        ; JMP
000483r 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
000485r 3  C8                           iny
000486r 3               
000486r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x         ; LSB of address
000488r 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
00048Ar 3  C8                           iny
00048Br 3               
00048Br 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x         ; MSB of address
00048Dr 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
00048Fr 3  C8                           iny
000490r 3               
000490r 3                               ; Allot the space we just used
000490r 3  98                           tya
000491r 3  18                           clc
000492r 3  65 rr                        adc cp
000494r 3  85 rr                        sta cp
000496r 3  90 02                        bcc @done
000498r 3  E6 rr                        inc cp+1
00049Ar 3               @done:
00049Ar 3  E8                           inx
00049Br 3  E8                           inx
00049Cr 3               
00049Cr 3  60           z_again:        rts
00049Dr 3               
00049Dr 3               
00049Dr 3               
00049Dr 3               ; ## ALIGN ( -- ) "Make sure CP is aligned on word size"
00049Dr 3               ; ## "align"  auto  ANS core
00049Dr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ALIGN
00049Dr 3                       ; On a 8-bit machine, this does nothing. ALIGNED uses this
00049Dr 3                       ; routine as well, and also does nothing
00049Dr 3                       ; """
00049Dr 3               
00049Dr 3               ; ## ALIGNED ( addr -- addr ) "Return the first aligned address"
00049Dr 3               ; ## "aligned"  auto  ANS core
00049Dr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ALIGNED"""
00049Dr 3               
00049Dr 3               xt_align:
00049Dr 3               xt_aligned:
00049Dr 3               z_align:
00049Dr 3  60           z_aligned:      rts             ; stripped out during native compile
00049Er 3               
00049Er 3               
00049Er 3               
00049Er 3               ; ## ALLOT ( n -- ) "Reserve or release memory"
00049Er 3               ; ## "allot"  auto  ANS core
00049Er 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ALLOT
00049Er 3                       ; Reserve a certain number of bytes (not cells) or release them.
00049Er 3                       ; If n = 0, do nothing. If n is negative, release n bytes, but only
00049Er 3                       ; to the beginning of the Dictionary. If n is positive (the most
00049Er 3                       ; common case), reserve n bytes, but not past the end of the
00049Er 3                       ; Dictionary. See http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ALLOT
00049Er 3                       ; """
00049Er 3               
00049Er 3               xt_allot:
00049Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
0004A1r 3               
0004A1r 3                               ; Releasing memory is going to be a very rare operation,
0004A1r 3                               ; so we check for it at the beginning and try to make
0004A1r 3                               ; the most common case as fast as possible
0004A1r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
0004A3r 3  30 22                        bmi @release
0004A5r 3               
0004A5r 3                               ; Common case: We are reserving memory, not releasing it
0004A5r 3  18                           clc
0004A6r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
0004A8r 3  75 00                        adc 0,x
0004AAr 3  85 rr                        sta cp
0004ACr 3               
0004ACr 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
0004AEr 3  75 01                        adc 1,x
0004B0r 3  85 rr                        sta cp+1
0004B2r 3               
0004B2r 3                               ; Wait, did we just grant more space than we have? This is
0004B2r 3                               ; a check we only do here, not for other situations like cmpl_a
0004B2r 3                               ; where smaller amounts are reserved.
0004B2r 3  A0 FF                        ldy #<cp_end
0004B4r 3  C4 rr                        cpy cp
0004B6r 3  A9 7F                        lda #>cp_end
0004B8r 3  E5 rr                        sbc cp+1
0004BAr 3  B0 48                        bcs @done               ; we're fine.
0004BCr 3               
0004BCr 3                               ; Oops, that was too much, we're beyond the end of
0004BCr 3                               ; legal Dictionary RAM. Reduce to max memory and report
0004BCr 3                               ; an error
0004BCr 3  84 rr                        sty cp                  ; still #<cp_end
0004BEr 3  A9 7F                        lda #>cp_end
0004C0r 3  85 rr                        sta cp+1
0004C2r 3               
0004C2r 3  A9 00                        lda #err_allot
0004C4r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
0004C7r 3               
0004C7r 3               @release:
0004C7r 3                  		; The ANS standard doesn't really say what to do if too much
0004C7r 3                               ; memory is freed ("negatively alloted"). In fact, there isn't
0004C7r 3                               ; even an official test. Gforth is little help either. The good
0004C7r 3                               ; news is, this is going to be a rare case. We want to use as
0004C7r 3                               ; few bytes as possible.
0004C7r 3               
0004C7r 3                               ; What we do is let the user free anything up to the beginning
0004C7r 3                               ; of the RAM area assigned to the Dicionary (CP0), but at
0004C7r 3                               ; their own risk. This means that the Dictionary pointer DP
0004C7r 3                               ; might end up pointing to garbage. However, an attempt to
0004C7r 3                               ; free more than RAM than CP0 will lead to CP being set to CP0,
0004C7r 3                               ; the DP pointing to the last word in RAM (should be DROP) and
0004C7r 3                               ; an error message.
0004C7r 3               
0004C7r 3                               ; We arrive here with ( n ) which is negative. First step,
0004C7r 3                               ; subtract the number TOS from the CP for a new CP
0004C7r 3  CA                           dex
0004C8r 3  CA                           dex
0004C9r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
0004CBr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0004CDr 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
0004CFr 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0004D1r 3               
0004D1r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_plus                     ; new CP is now TOS
0004D4r 3               
0004D4r 3                               ; Second step, see if we've gone too far. We compare the new
0004D4r 3                               ; CP on TOS (which, if we've really screwed up, might be
0004D4r 3                               ; negative) with CP0. This is a signed comparison
0004D4r 3  CA                           dex
0004D5r 3  CA                           dex                             ; new CP now NOS
0004D6r 3  A9 rr                        lda #<cp0
0004D8r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0004DAr 3  A9 rr                        lda #>cp0
0004DCr 3  95 01                        sta 1,x                         ; CP0 is TOS
0004DEr 3               
0004DEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr compare_16bit               ; still ( CP CP0 )
0004E1r 3               
0004E1r 3                               ; If CP (NOS) is smaller than CP0 (TOS), we're in trouble.
0004E1r 3                               ; This means we want Z=1 or N=1
0004E1r 3  F0 17                        beq @nega_done
0004E3r 3  30 15                        bmi @nega_done
0004E5r 3               
0004E5r 3                               ; Yep, we're in trouble. Set CP to CP0, set DP to the first
0004E5r 3                               ; word in ROM (should be DROP), and abort with an error
0004E5r 3  A9 rr                        lda #<cp0
0004E7r 3  85 rr                        sta cp
0004E9r 3  A9 rr                        lda #>cp0
0004EBr 3  85 rr                        sta cp+1
0004EDr 3               
0004EDr 3  A9 rr                        lda #<dictionary_start
0004EFr 3  85 rr                        sta dp
0004F1r 3  A9 rr                        lda #>dictionary_start
0004F3r 3  85 rr                        sta dp+1
0004F5r 3               
0004F5r 3  A9 0A                        lda #err_negallot
0004F7r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
0004FAr 3               
0004FAr 3               @nega_done:
0004FAr 3                               ; Save new CP, which is NOS
0004FAr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
0004FCr 3  85 rr                        sta cp
0004FEr 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
000500r 3  85 rr                        sta cp+1
000502r 3               
000502r 3  E8                           inx
000503r 3  E8                           inx                     ; drop through to @done
000504r 3               @done:
000504r 3  E8                           inx
000505r 3  E8                           inx
000506r 3               z_allot:
000506r 3  60                           rts
000507r 3               
000507r 3               
000507r 3               
000507r 3               ; ## ALLOW_NATIVE ( -- ) "Flag last word to allow native compiling"
000507r 3               ; ## "allow-native"  auto  Tali Forth
000507r 3               xt_allow_native:
000507r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr current_to_dp
00050Ar 3  A0 01                        ldy #1          ; offset for status byte
00050Cr 3  B1 rr                        lda (dp),y
00050Er 3  29 F5                        and #$ff-NN-AN  ; AN and NN flag is clear.
000510r 3  91 rr                        sta (dp),y
000512r 3               z_allow_native:
000512r 3  60                           rts
000513r 3               
000513r 3               
000513r 3               ; ## ALSO ( -- ) "Make room in the search order for another wordlist"
000513r 3               ; ## "also"  auto  ANS search ext
000513r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/search/ALSO"""
000513r 3               xt_also:
000513r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_get_order
000516r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_over
000519r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_swap
00051Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_one_plus
00051Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_set_order
000522r 3               
000522r 3  60           z_also:         rts
000523r 3               
000523r 3               
000523r 3               ; ## ALWAYS_NATIVE ( -- ) "Flag last word as always natively compiled"
000523r 3               ; ## "always-native"  auto  Tali Forth
000523r 3               xt_always_native:
000523r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr current_to_dp
000526r 3  A0 01                        ldy #1          ; offset for status byte
000528r 3  B1 rr                        lda (dp),y
00052Ar 3  09 02                        ora #AN         ; Make sure AN flag is set
00052Cr 3  29 F7                        and #$ff-NN     ; and NN flag is clear.
00052Er 3  91 rr                        sta (dp),y
000530r 3               z_always_native:
000530r 3  60                           rts
000531r 3               
000531r 3               
000531r 3               ; ## AND ( n n -- n ) "Logically AND TOS and NOS"
000531r 3               ; ## "and"  auto  ANS core
000531r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/AND"""
000531r 3               xt_and:
000531r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
000534r 3               
000534r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000536r 3  35 02                        and 2,x
000538r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
00053Ar 3               
00053Ar 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
00053Cr 3  35 03                        and 3,x
00053Er 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
000540r 3               
000540r 3  E8                           inx
000541r 3  E8                           inx
000542r 3               
000542r 3  60           z_and:          rts
000543r 3               
000543r 3               
000543r 3               ; ## ASSEMBLER_WORDLIST ( -- u ) "WID for the Assembler wordlist"
000543r 3               ; ## "assembler-wordlist"  tested  Tali Assembler
000543r 3                       ; """ Commonly used like `assembler-wordlist >order` to add the
000543r 3                       ; assembler words to the search order so they can be used.
000543r 3                       ; See the tutorial on Wordlists and the Search Order for
000543r 3                       ; more information.
000543r 3                       ;
000543r 3                       ; This is a dummy entry, the code is shared with TWO
000543r 3                       ; """
000543r 3               
000543r 3               
000543r 3               ; ## AT_XY ( n m -- ) "Move cursor to position given"
000543r 3               ; ## "at-xy"  tested  ANS facility
000543r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/facility/AT-XY
000543r 3                       ; On an ANSI compatible terminal, place cursor at row n colum m.
000543r 3                       ; ANSI code is ESC[<n>;<m>H
000543r 3                       ;
000543r 3                       ; Do not use U. to print the numbers because the
000543r 3                       ; trailing space will not work with xterm
000543r 3                       ; """
000543r 3               xt_at_xy:
000543r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
000546r 3               
000546r 3  A9 1B                        lda #AscESC
000548r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
00054Br 3  A9 5B                        lda #$5B        ; ASCII for "["
00054Dr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000550r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_u
000553r 3  A9 3B                        lda #$3B        ; ASCII for ";"
000555r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000558r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_u
00055Br 3  A9 48                        lda #'H'
00055Dr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000560r 3               
000560r 3  60           z_at_xy:        rts
000561r 3               
000561r 3               
000561r 3               ; ## BACKSLASH ( -- ) "Ignore rest of line"
000561r 3               ; ## "\"  auto  ANS core ext
000561r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/bs"""
000561r 3               xt_backslash:
000561r 3  A5 rr                        lda ciblen
000563r 3  85 rr                        sta toin
000565r 3  A5 rr                        lda ciblen+1
000567r 3  85 rr                        sta toin+1
000569r 3               
000569r 3  60           z_backslash:    rts
00056Ar 3               
00056Ar 3               
00056Ar 3               ; ## BASE ( -- addr ) "Push address of radix base to stack"
00056Ar 3               ; ## "base"  auto  ANS core
00056Ar 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/BASE
00056Ar 3                       ; The ANS Forth standard sees the base up to 36, so we can cheat and
00056Ar 3                       ; ingore the MSB
00056Ar 3                       ; """
00056Ar 3               xt_base:
00056Ar 3  CA                           dex
00056Br 3  CA                           dex
00056Cr 3  A9 rr                        lda #<base
00056Er 3  95 00                        sta 0,x         ; LSB
000570r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x         ; MSB is always 0
000572r 3               
000572r 3  60           z_base:         rts
000573r 3               
000573r 3               
000573r 3               ; ## BEGIN ( -- addr ) "Mark entry point for loop"
000573r 3               ; ## "begin"  auto  ANS core
000573r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/BEGIN
000573r 3                       ;
000573r 3                       ; This is just an immediate version of here which could just
000573r 3                       ; as well be coded in Forth as
000573r 3                       ;       : BEGIN HERE ; IMMEDIATE COMPILE-ONLY
000573r 3                       ; Since this is a compiling word, we don't care that much about
000573r 3                       ; about speed
000573r 3                       ; """
000573r 3               
000573r 3               xt_begin:
000573r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_here
000576r 3  60           z_begin:        rts
000577r 3               
000577r 3               
000577r 3               
000577r 3               ; ## BELL ( -- ) "Emit ASCII BELL"
000577r 3               ; ## "bell"  tested  Tali Forth
000577r 3               xt_bell:
000577r 3  A9 07                        lda #7          ; ASCII value for BELl
000579r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
00057Cr 3               
00057Cr 3  60           z_bell:         rts
00057Dr 3               
00057Dr 3               
00057Dr 3               ; ## BL ( -- c ) "Push ASCII value of SPACE to stack"
00057Dr 3               ; ## "bl"  auto  ANS core
00057Dr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/BL"""
00057Dr 3               
00057Dr 3               xt_bl:
00057Dr 3  CA                           dex
00057Er 3  CA                           dex
00057Fr 3  A9 20                        lda #AscSP
000581r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000583r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
000585r 3               
000585r 3  60           z_bl:           rts
000586r 3               
000586r 3               
000586r 3               ; ## BLK ( -- addr ) "Push address of block being interpreted"
000586r 3               ; ## "block"  auto  ANS block
000586r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/BLK"""
000586r 3               xt_blk:
000586r 3                               ; BLK is at UP + blk_offset
000586r 3  CA                           dex
000587r 3  CA                           dex
000588r 3  18                           clc
000589r 3  A5 rr                        lda up
00058Br 3  69 00                        adc #blk_offset ; Add offset
00058Dr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
00058Fr 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
000591r 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; Adding carry
000593r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
000595r 3               
000595r 3  60           z_blk:          rts
000596r 3               
000596r 3               
000596r 3               ; ## BLKBUFFER ( -- addr ) "Push address of block buffer"
000596r 3               ; ## "blkbuffer"  auto  Tali block
000596r 3               xt_blkbuffer:
000596r 3                               ; blkbuffer address is at UP + blkbuffer_offset.
000596r 3                               ; Unlike some of the other user variables, we actually
000596r 3                               ; want to push the address stored here, which will
000596r 3                               ; point to somewhere outside of the user variables.
000596r 3  CA                           dex
000597r 3  CA                           dex
000598r 3                               ; Put the address on the stack.
000598r 3  A0 28                        ldy #blkbuffer_offset
00059Ar 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
00059Cr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
00059Er 3  C8                           iny             ; Move along to the next byte
00059Fr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0005A1r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0005A3r 3               
0005A3r 3  60           z_blkbuffer:    rts
0005A4r 3               
0005A4r 3               
0005A4r 3               ; ## BLOCK ( u -- a-addr ) "Fetch a block into a buffer"
0005A4r 3               ; ## "block"  auto  ANS block
0005A4r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/BLOCK"""
0005A4r 3               
0005A4r 3               xt_block:
0005A4r 3               
0005A4r 3                               ; See if the block requested is the same as the one we
0005A4r 3                               ; currently have in the buffer. Check the LSB.
0005A4r 3  A0 2A                        ldy #buffblocknum_offset
0005A6r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0005A8r 3  D5 00                        cmp 0,x
0005AAr 3  D0 0F                        bne @not_in_buffer
0005ACr 3               
0005ACr 3                               ; Check the MSB.
0005ACr 3  C8                           iny
0005ADr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0005AFr 3  D5 01                        cmp 1,x
0005B1r 3  D0 08                        bne @not_in_buffer
0005B3r 3               
0005B3r 3                               ; The block is in the buffer. See if the buffer is in use.
0005B3r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
0005B5r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0005B7r 3  29 01                        and #1          ; Check the in-use flag (bit 0)
0005B9r 3  D0 30                        bne @done       ; It's already in the buffer and in use.
0005BBr 3                                               ; @done will replace the block# with the
0005BBr 3                                               ; buffer address.
0005BBr 3               @not_in_buffer:
0005BBr 3                               ; Check the buffer status
0005BBr 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
0005BDr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y      ; Only bits 0 and 1 are used, so only
0005BFr 3  C9 03                        cmp #3          ; LSB is needed.
0005C1r 3  D0 0C                        bne @buffer_available ; Unused or not dirty = available
0005C3r 3               
0005C3r 3                               ; We need to save the block.
0005C3r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_blkbuffer
0005C6r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_buffblocknum
0005C9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_fetch
0005CCr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_block_write
0005CFr 3               
0005CFr 3               @buffer_available:
0005CFr 3                               ; Save the block number.
0005CFr 3  A0 2A                        ldy #buffblocknum_offset
0005D1r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0005D3r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0005D5r 3  C8                           iny
0005D6r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
0005D8r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0005DAr 3               
0005DAr 3                               ; Get the requested block.
0005DAr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_blkbuffer
0005DDr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_swap
0005E0r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_block_read
0005E3r 3               
0005E3r 3                               ; Mark the buffer as clean and in-use.
0005E3r 3  A9 01                        lda #1
0005E5r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
0005E7r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0005E9r 3               
0005E9r 3                               ; Make room on the stack for the return address.
0005E9r 3  CA                           dex
0005EAr 3  CA                           dex
0005EBr 3               
0005EBr 3               @done:
0005EBr 3                               ; It's in the buffer. Return the buffer address.
0005EBr 3  A0 28                        ldy #blkbuffer_offset
0005EDr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0005EFr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0005F1r 3  C8                           iny
0005F2r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0005F4r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0005F6r 3               
0005F6r 3  60           z_block:        rts
0005F7r 3               
0005F7r 3               
0005F7r 3               
0005F7r 3               ; ## BLOCK_RAMDRIVE_INIT ( u -- ) "Create a ramdrive for blocks"
0005F7r 3               ; ## "block-ramdrive-init"  auto  Tali block
0005F7r 3                       ; """Create a RAM drive, with the given number of
0005F7r 3                       ; blocks, in the dictionary along with setting up the block words to
0005F7r 3                       ; use it.  The read/write routines do not provide bounds checking.
0005F7r 3                       ; Expected use: `4 block-ramdrive-init` ( to create blocks 0-3 )
0005F7r 3                       ; """
0005F7r 3               
0005F7r 3               xt_block_ramdrive_init:
0005F7r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
0005FAr 3               
0005FAr 3                               ; Store the string to run here as a string literal.
0005FAr 3                               ; See SLITERAL for the format information. This way, we
0005FAr 3                               ; don't have the words defined below in the Dictionary until
0005FAr 3                               ; we really use them.
0005FAr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @after_ramdrive_code
0005FDr 3               
0005FDr 3               @ramdrive_code:
0005FDr 3  62 61 73 65          .byte "base @ swap decimal"
000601r 3  20 40 20 73  
000605r 3  77 61 70 20  
000610r 3  20 31 30 32          .byte " 1024 *" ; ( Calculate how many bytes are needed for numblocks blocks )
000614r 3  34 20 2A     
000617r 3  20 64 75 70          .byte " dup"    ; ( Save a copy for formatting it at the end )
00061Br 3  20 62 75 66          .byte " buffer: ramdrive" ; ( Create ramdrive )
00061Fr 3  66 65 72 3A  
000623r 3  20 72 61 6D  
00062Cr 3                       ; ( These routines just copy between the buffer and the ramdrive blocks )
00062Cr 3  20 3A 20 62          .byte " : block-read-ramdrive"  ; ( addr u -- )
000630r 3  6C 6F 63 6B  
000634r 3  2D 72 65 61  
000642r 3  20 72 61 6D          .byte " ramdrive swap 1024 * + swap 1024 move ;"
000646r 3  64 72 69 76  
00064Ar 3  65 20 73 77  
00066Ar 3  20 3A 20 62          .byte " : block-write-ramdrive" ; ( addr u -- )
00066Er 3  6C 6F 63 6B  
000672r 3  2D 77 72 69  
000681r 3  20 72 61 6D          .byte " ramdrive swap 1024 * + 1024 move ;"
000685r 3  64 72 69 76  
000689r 3  65 20 73 77  
0006A4r 3  20 27 20 62          .byte " ' block-read-ramdrive block-read-vector !" ; ( Replace I/O vectors )
0006A8r 3  6C 6F 63 6B  
0006ACr 3  2D 72 65 61  
0006CEr 3  20 27 20 62          .byte " ' block-write-ramdrive block-write-vector !"
0006D2r 3  6C 6F 63 6B  
0006D6r 3  2D 77 72 69  
0006FAr 3  20 72 61 6D          .byte " ramdrive swap blank base !"
0006FEr 3  64 72 69 76  
000702r 3  65 20 73 77  
000715r 3               
000715r 3               @after_ramdrive_code:
000715r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr sliteral_runtime
000718r 3               
000718r 3  rr rr 18 01  .word @ramdrive_code, @after_ramdrive_code-@ramdrive_code
00071Cr 3               
00071Cr 3                               ; The address and length of the ramdrive code is now on the
00071Cr 3                               ; stack. Call EVALUATE to run it.
00071Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_evaluate
00071Fr 3               
00071Fr 3               z_block_ramdrive_init:
00071Fr 3  60                           rts
000720r 3               
000720r 3               
000720r 3               
000720r 3               ; ## BLOCK_READ ( addr u -- ) "Read a block from storage (deferred word)"
000720r 3               ; ## "block-read"  auto  Tali block
000720r 3                       ; """BLOCK-READ is a vectored word that the user needs to override
000720r 3                       ; with their own version to read a block from storage.
000720r 3                       ; The stack parameters are ( buffer_address block# -- ).
000720r 3                       ; """
000720r 3               xt_block_read:
000720r 3                               ; Execute the BLOCK-READ-VECTOR
000720r 3  A0 2E                        ldy #blockread_offset
000722r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
000724r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
000726r 3  C8                           iny
000727r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
000729r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
00072Br 3               
00072Br 3  6C rr rr                     jmp (tmp1)
00072Er 3               
00072Er 3               z_block_read:   ; No RTS needed
00072Er 3               
00072Er 3               
00072Er 3               ; ## BLOCK_READ_VECTOR ( -- addr ) "Address of the block-read vector"
00072Er 3               ; ## "block-read-vector"  auto  Tali block
00072Er 3                       ; """BLOCK-READ is a vectored word that the user needs to override
00072Er 3                       ; with their own version to read a block from storage.
00072Er 3                       ; This word gives the address of the vector so it can be replaced.
00072Er 3                       ; """
00072Er 3               xt_block_read_vector:
00072Er 3                               ; Get the BLOCK-READ-VECTOR address
00072Er 3  CA                           dex
00072Fr 3  CA                           dex
000730r 3  18                           clc
000731r 3  A5 rr                        lda up
000733r 3  69 2E                        adc #blockread_offset
000735r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000737r 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
000739r 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; Add carry
00073Br 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
00073Dr 3               
00073Dr 3               z_block_read_vector:
00073Dr 3  60                           rts
00073Er 3               
00073Er 3               
00073Er 3               ; This is the default error message the vectored words BLOCK-READ and
00073Er 3               ; BLOCK-WRITE start with. This word is not included in the dictionary.
00073Er 3               xt_block_word_error:
00073Er 3  A9 0C                        lda #err_blockwords
000740r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error       ; no RTS needed
000743r 3               z_block_word_error:
000743r 3               
000743r 3               ; ## BLOCK_WRITE ( addr u -- ) "Write a block to storage (deferred word)"
000743r 3               ; ## "block-write"  auto  Tali block
000743r 3                       ; """BLOCK-WRITE is a vectored word that the user needs to override
000743r 3                       ; with their own version to write a block to storage.
000743r 3                       ; The stack parameters are ( buffer_address block# -- ).
000743r 3                       ; """
000743r 3               xt_block_write:
000743r 3                               ; Execute the BLOCK-READ-VECTOR
000743r 3  A0 30                        ldy #blockwrite_offset
000745r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
000747r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
000749r 3  C8                           iny
00074Ar 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
00074Cr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
00074Er 3  6C rr rr                     jmp (tmp1)
000751r 3               
000751r 3               z_block_write:  ; No RTS needed
000751r 3               
000751r 3               
000751r 3               ; ## BLOCK_WRITE_VECTOR ( -- addr ) "Address of the block-write vector"
000751r 3               ; ## "block-write-vector"  auto  Tali block
000751r 3                       ; """BLOCK-WRITE is a vectored word that the user needs to override
000751r 3                       ; with their own version to write a block to storage.
000751r 3                       ; This word gives the address of the vector so it can be replaced.
000751r 3                       ; """
000751r 3               xt_block_write_vector:
000751r 3                               ; Get the BLOCK-WRITE-VECTOR address
000751r 3  CA                           dex
000752r 3  CA                           dex
000753r 3  18                           clc
000754r 3  A5 rr                        lda up
000756r 3  69 30                        adc #blockwrite_offset
000758r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
00075Ar 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
00075Cr 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; Add carry
00075Er 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
000760r 3               
000760r 3               z_block_write_vector:
000760r 3  60                           rts
000761r 3               
000761r 3               
000761r 3               ; ## BOUNDS ( addr u -- addr+u addr ) "Prepare address for looping"
000761r 3               ; ## "bounds"  auto  Gforth
000761r 3                       ; """http://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/Memory-Blocks.html
000761r 3                       ; Given a string, return the correct Data Stack parameters for
000761r 3                       ; a DO/LOOP loop over its characters. This is realized as
000761r 3                       ; OVER + SWAP in Forth, but we do it a lot faster in assembler
000761r 3                       ; """
000761r 3               xt_bounds:
000761r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
000764r 3               
000764r 3  18                           clc
000765r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x                 ; LSB u
000767r 3  B4 02                        ldy 2,x                 ; LSB addr
000769r 3  75 02                        adc 2,x
00076Br 3  95 02                        sta 2,x                 ; LSB addr+u
00076Dr 3  94 00                        sty 0,x
00076Fr 3               
00076Fr 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x                 ; MSB u
000771r 3  B4 03                        ldy 3,x                 ; MSB addr
000773r 3  75 03                        adc 3,x
000775r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x                 ; MSB addr+u
000777r 3  94 01                        sty 1,x
000779r 3               
000779r 3  60           z_bounds:       rts
00077Ar 3               
00077Ar 3               
00077Ar 3               ; ## BRACKET_CHAR ( "c" -- ) "Compile character"
00077Ar 3               ; ## "[char]"  auto  ANS core
00077Ar 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/BracketCHAR
00077Ar 3                       ; Compile the ASCII value of a character as a literal. This is an
00077Ar 3                       ; immediate, compile-only word.
00077Ar 3                       ;
00077Ar 3                       ; A definition given in
00077Ar 3                       ; http://forth-standard.org/standard/implement is
00077Ar 3                       ; : [CHAR]  CHAR POSTPONE LITERAL ; IMMEDIATE
00077Ar 3                       ; """
00077Ar 3               xt_bracket_char:
00077Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_char
00077Dr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_literal
000780r 3  60           z_bracket_char: rts
000781r 3               
000781r 3               
000781r 3               ; ## BRACKET_TICK ( -- ) "Store xt of following word during compilation"
000781r 3               ; ## "[']"  auto  ANS core
000781r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/BracketTick"""
000781r 3               xt_bracket_tick:
000781r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_tick
000784r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_literal
000787r 3  60           z_bracket_tick: rts
000788r 3               
000788r 3               
000788r 3               ; ## BUFFBLOCKNUM ( -- addr ) "Push address of variable holding block in buffer"
000788r 3               ; ## "buffblocknum"  auto  Tali block
000788r 3               xt_buffblocknum:
000788r 3                               ; BUFFBLOCKNUM is at UP + buffblocknum_offset
000788r 3  CA                           dex
000789r 3  CA                           dex
00078Ar 3  18                           clc
00078Br 3  A5 rr                        lda up
00078Dr 3  69 2A                        adc #buffblocknum_offset        ; Add offset
00078Fr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000791r 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
000793r 3  69 00                        adc #0                          ; Adding carry
000795r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
000797r 3               
000797r 3  60           z_buffblocknum: rts
000798r 3               
000798r 3               
000798r 3               ; ## BUFFER ( u -- a-addr ) "Get a buffer for a block"
000798r 3               ; ## "buffer"  auto  ANS block
000798r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/BUFFER"""
000798r 3               
000798r 3               xt_buffer:
000798r 3                               ; Check the buffer status
000798r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
00079Ar 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y      ; Only bits 0 and 1 are used, so only
00079Cr 3  C9 03                        cmp #3          ; LSB is needed.
00079Er 3  D0 0C                        bne @buffer_available ; Unused or not dirty = available
0007A0r 3               
0007A0r 3                               ; We need to save the block.
0007A0r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_blkbuffer
0007A3r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_buffblocknum
0007A6r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_fetch
0007A9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_block_write
0007ACr 3               
0007ACr 3               @buffer_available:
0007ACr 3                               ; Save the block number.
0007ACr 3  A0 2A                        ldy #buffblocknum_offset
0007AEr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0007B0r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0007B2r 3  C8                           iny
0007B3r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
0007B5r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0007B7r 3               
0007B7r 3                               ; Mark the buffer as clean and in-use.
0007B7r 3  A9 01                        lda #1
0007B9r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
0007BBr 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0007BDr 3               
0007BDr 3               @done:
0007BDr 3                               ; Return the buffer address.
0007BDr 3  A0 28                        ldy #blkbuffer_offset
0007BFr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0007C1r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0007C3r 3  C8                           iny
0007C4r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0007C6r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0007C8r 3               
0007C8r 3  60           z_buffer:       rts
0007C9r 3               
0007C9r 3               
0007C9r 3               
0007C9r 3               ; ## BUFFER_COLON ( u "<name>" -- ; -- addr ) "Create an uninitialized buffer"
0007C9r 3               ; ## "buffer:"  auto  ANS core ext
0007C9r 3                               ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/BUFFERColon
0007C9r 3                               ; Create a buffer of size u that puts its address on the stack
0007C9r 3                               ; when its name is used.
0007C9r 3                               ; """
0007C9r 3               xt_buffer_colon:
0007C9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_create
0007CCr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_allot
0007CFr 3  60           z_buffer_colon: rts
0007D0r 3               
0007D0r 3               
0007D0r 3               ; ## BUFFSTATUS ( -- addr ) "Push address of variable holding buffer status"
0007D0r 3               ; ## "buffstatus"  auto  Tali block
0007D0r 3               xt_buffstatus:
0007D0r 3                               ; BUFFSTATUS is at UP + buffstatus_offset
0007D0r 3  CA                           dex
0007D1r 3  CA                           dex
0007D2r 3  18                           clc
0007D3r 3  A5 rr                        lda up
0007D5r 3  69 2C                        adc #buffstatus_offset  ; Add offset
0007D7r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0007D9r 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
0007DBr 3  69 00                        adc #0                  ; Adding carry
0007DDr 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0007DFr 3               
0007DFr 3  60           z_buffstatus:   rts
0007E0r 3               
0007E0r 3               
0007E0r 3               ; ## BYE ( -- ) "Break"
0007E0r 3               ; ## "bye"  tested  ANS tools ext
0007E0r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/tools/BYE"""
0007E0r 3               
0007E0r 3               xt_bye:
0007E0r 3                               ;brk
0007E0r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp platform_bye
0007E3r 3               z_bye:          ;rts             ; never reached
0007E3r 3               
0007E3r 3               
0007E3r 3               
0007E3r 3               ; ## C_COMMA ( c -- ) "Store one byte/char in the Dictionary"
0007E3r 3               ; ## "c,"  auto  ANS core
0007E3r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CComma"""
0007E3r 3               
0007E3r 3               xt_c_comma:
0007E3r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
0007E6r 3               
0007E6r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0007E8r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
0007EBr 3               
0007EBr 3  E8                           inx
0007ECr 3  E8                           inx
0007EDr 3               
0007EDr 3  60           z_c_comma:      rts
0007EEr 3               
0007EEr 3               
0007EEr 3               
0007EEr 3               ; ## C_FETCH ( addr -- c ) "Get a character/byte from given address"
0007EEr 3               ; ## "c@"  auto  ANS core
0007EEr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CFetch"""
0007EEr 3               xt_c_fetch:
0007EEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
0007F1r 3               
0007F1r 3  A1 00                        lda (0,x)
0007F3r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0007F5r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x         ; Ignore LSB
0007F7r 3               
0007F7r 3  60           z_c_fetch:      rts
0007F8r 3               
0007F8r 3               
0007F8r 3               ; ## C_STORE ( c addr -- ) "Store character at address given"
0007F8r 3               ; ## "c!"  auto  ANS core
0007F8r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CStore"""
0007F8r 3               xt_c_store:
0007F8r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
0007FBr 3               
0007FBr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
0007FDr 3  81 00                        sta (0,x)
0007FFr 3               
0007FFr 3  E8                           inx
000800r 3  E8                           inx
000801r 3  E8                           inx
000802r 3  E8                           inx
000803r 3               
000803r 3  60           z_c_store:      rts
000804r 3               
000804r 3               
000804r 3               ; ## CASE (C: -- 0) ( -- ) "Conditional flow control"
000804r 3               ; ## "case"  auto  ANS core ext
000804r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CASE
000804r 3                       ;
000804r 3                       ; This is a dummy header, CASE shares the actual code with ZERO.
000804r 3                       ; """
000804r 3               
000804r 3               
000804r 3               ; ## CELL_PLUS ( u -- u ) "Add cell size in bytes"
000804r 3               ; ## "cell+"  auto  ANS core
000804r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CELLPlus
000804r 3                       ; Add the number of bytes ("address units") that one cell needs.
000804r 3                       ; Since this is an 8 bit machine with 16 bit cells, we add two bytes.
000804r 3                       ; """
000804r 3               
000804r 3               xt_cell_plus:
000804r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
000807r 3               
000807r 3  F6 00                        inc 0,x
000809r 3  D0 02                        bne @1
00080Br 3  F6 01                        inc 1,x
00080Dr 3               @1:
00080Dr 3  F6 00                        inc 0,x
00080Fr 3  D0 02                        bne @done
000811r 3  F6 01                        inc 1,x
000813r 3               @done:
000813r 3  60           z_cell_plus:    rts
000814r 3               
000814r 3               
000814r 3               
000814r 3               ; ## CELLS ( u -- u ) "Convert cells to size in bytes"
000814r 3               ; ## "cells"  auto  ANS core
000814r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CELLS
000814r 3                       ;
000814r 3                       ; Dummy entry for the CELLS word, the code is the same as for
000814r 3                       ; 2*, which is where the header directs us to
000814r 3                       ; """
000814r 3               
000814r 3               
000814r 3               ; ## CHAR ( "c" -- u ) "Convert character to ASCII value"
000814r 3               ; ## "char"  auto  ANS core
000814r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CHAR"""
000814r 3               
000814r 3               xt_char:
000814r 3                               ; get character from string, returns ( addr u )
000814r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_parse_name
000817r 3               
000817r 3                               ; if we got back a zero, we have a problem
000817r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000819r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
00081Br 3  D0 05                        bne @not_empty
00081Dr 3               
00081Dr 3  A9 05                        lda #err_noname
00081Fr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
000822r 3               
000822r 3               @not_empty:
000822r 3  E8                           inx             ; drop number of characters, leave addr
000823r 3  E8                           inx
000824r 3  A1 00                        lda (0,x)       ; get character (equivalent to C@)
000826r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000828r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x         ; MSB is always zero
00082Ar 3               
00082Ar 3  60           z_char:         rts
00082Br 3               
00082Br 3               
00082Br 3               
00082Br 3               ; ## CHAR_PLUS ( addr -- addr+1 ) "Add the size of a character unit to address"
00082Br 3               ; ## "char+"  auto  ANS core
00082Br 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CHARPlus
00082Br 3                       ;
00082Br 3                       ; This is a dummy entry, the code is shared with ONE_PLUS
00082Br 3                       ; """
00082Br 3               
00082Br 3               
00082Br 3               ; ## CHARS ( n -- n ) "Number of bytes that n chars need"
00082Br 3               ; ## "chars"  auto  ANS core
00082Br 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/CHARS
00082Br 3                       ; Return how many address units n chars are. Since this is an 8 bit
00082Br 3                       ; machine, this does absolutely nothing and is included for
00082Br 3                       ; compatibility with other Forth versions
00082Br 3                       ; """
00082Br 3               
00082Br 3               xt_chars:
00082Br 3                               ; Checking for underflow seems a bit stupid because this
00082Br 3                               ; routine does nothing on this machine. However, the user
00082Br 3                               ; should be warned that there is something wrong with the
00082Br 3                               ; code if this occurs.
00082Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
00082Er 3               
00082Er 3  60           z_chars:        rts
00082Fr 3               
00082Fr 3               
00082Fr 3               ; ## CLEAVE ( addr u -- addr2 u2 addr1 u1 ) "Split off word from string"
00082Fr 3               ; ## "cleave"  auto  Tali Forth
00082Fr 3               
00082Fr 3                       ; """Given a range of memory with words delimited by whitespace,return
00082Fr 3                       ; the first word at the top of the stack and the rest of the word
00082Fr 3                       ; following it.
00082Fr 3                       ;
00082Fr 3                       ; Example:
00082Fr 3                       ; s" w1 w2 w3" cleave  -> "w2 w3" "w1"
00082Fr 3                       ; s" w1" cleave        -> "" "w1"
00082Fr 3                       ;
00082Fr 3                       ; Since it will be used in loops a lot, we want it to work in pure
00082Fr 3                       ; assembler and be as fast as we can make it. Calls PARSE-NAME so we
00082Fr 3                       ; strip leading delimiters.
00082Fr 3                       ; """
00082Fr 3               
00082Fr 3               xt_cleave:
00082Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
000832r 3               
000832r 3                               ; We arrive here with ( addr u ). We need to strip any leading
000832r 3                               ; spaces by hand: PARSE-NAME does do that, but it doesn't
000832r 3                               ; remember how many spaces were stripped. This means we can't
000832r 3                               ; calculate the length of the remainder. Fortunately, Tali
000832r 3                               ; Forth has just the word we need for this:
000832r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_minus_leading    ; -LEADING ( addr u )
000835r 3               
000835r 3                               ; The main part we can turn over to PARSE-NAME, except that we
000835r 3                               ; have a string ( addr u ) and not stuff in the input buffer.
000835r 3                               ; We get around this by cheating: We place ( addr u ) in the
000835r 3                               ; input buffer and then call PARSE-NAME.
000835r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_input_to_r       ; save old imput state
000838r 3               
000838r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x         ; u is new ciblen
00083Ar 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen
00083Cr 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
00083Er 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen+1
000840r 3               
000840r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x         ; addr is new cib
000842r 3  85 rr                        sta cib
000844r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
000846r 3  85 rr                        sta cib+1
000848r 3               
000848r 3  64 rr                        stz toin        ; >IN pointer is zero
00084Ar 3  64 rr                        stz toin+1
00084Cr 3               
00084Cr 3                               ; PARSE-NAME gives us back the substring of the first word
00084Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_parse_name       ; ( addr u addr-s u-s )
00084Fr 3               
00084Fr 3                               ; If we were given an empty string, then we're done. It's the
00084Fr 3                               ; resposibility of the user to catch this as a sign to end the
00084Fr 3                               ; any loop
00084Fr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000851r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
000853r 3  F0 23                        beq @done
000855r 3               
000855r 3                               ; Now we have to adjust the original string
000855r 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x         ; LSB of original u
000857r 3  38                           sec
000858r 3  F5 00                        sbc 0,x
00085Ar 3  95 04                        sta 4,x
00085Cr 3               
00085Cr 3  B5 05                        lda 5,x         ; MSB of original u
00085Er 3  F5 01                        sbc 1,x
000860r 3  95 05                        sta 5,x
000862r 3               
000862r 3  B5 06                        lda 6,x         ; LSB of original addr
000864r 3  18                           clc
000865r 3  75 00                        adc 0,x
000867r 3  95 06                        sta 6,x
000869r 3               
000869r 3  B5 07                        lda 7,x         ; MSB of original addr
00086Br 3  75 01                        adc 1,x
00086Dr 3  95 07                        sta 7,x
00086Fr 3               
00086Fr 3                               ; There is one small problem: PARSE-NAME will probably have
00086Fr 3                               ; left the string with the rest of the words with leading
00086Fr 3                               ; delimiters. We use our magic -LEADING again
00086Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_two_swap         ; ( addr-s u-s addr u )
000872r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_minus_leading
000875r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_two_swap         ; ( addr u addr-s u-s )
000878r 3               @done:
000878r 3                               ; Restore input
000878r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_r_to_input
00087Br 3               
00087Br 3  60           z_cleave:       rts
00087Cr 3               
00087Cr 3               
00087Cr 3               
00087Cr 3               ; ## CMOVE ( addr1 addr2 u -- ) "Copy bytes going from low to high"
00087Cr 3               ; ## "cmove"  auto  ANS string
00087Cr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/string/CMOVE
00087Cr 3                       ; Copy u bytes from addr1 to addr2, going low to high (addr2 is
00087Cr 3                       ; larger than addr1). Based on code in Leventhal, Lance A.
00087Cr 3                       ; "6502 Assembly Language Routines", p. 201, where it is called
00087Cr 3                       ; "move left".
00087Cr 3                       ;
00087Cr 3                       ; There are no official tests for this word.
00087Cr 3                       ; """
00087Cr 3               
00087Cr 3               xt_cmove:
00087Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
00087Fr 3               
00087Fr 3                               ; move destination address to where we can work with it
00087Fr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
000881r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2        ; use tmp2 because easier to remember
000883r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
000885r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
000887r 3               
000887r 3                               ; move source address to where we can work with it
000887r 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x
000889r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1        ; use tmp1 because easier to remember
00088Br 3  B5 05                        lda 5,x
00088Dr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
00088Fr 3               
00088Fr 3  A0 00                        ldy #0
000891r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x         ; number of whole pages to move
000893r 3  F0 0F                        beq @dopartial
000895r 3               
000895r 3               @page:
000895r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
000897r 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp2),y
000899r 3  C8                           iny
00089Ar 3  D0 F9                        bne @page
00089Cr 3               
00089Cr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1+1
00089Er 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2+1
0008A0r 3  D6 01                        dec 1,x
0008A2r 3  D0 F1                        bne @page
0008A4r 3               
0008A4r 3               @dopartial:
0008A4r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x         ; length of last page
0008A6r 3  F0 09                        beq @done
0008A8r 3               
0008A8r 3               @partial:
0008A8r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
0008AAr 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp2),y
0008ACr 3  C8                           iny
0008ADr 3               
0008ADr 3  D6 00                        dec 0,x
0008AFr 3  D0 F7                        bne @partial
0008B1r 3               
0008B1r 3               @done:          ; clear the stack
0008B1r 3  8A                           txa
0008B2r 3  18                           clc
0008B3r 3  69 06                        adc #6
0008B5r 3  AA                           tax
0008B6r 3               
0008B6r 3  60           z_cmove:        rts
0008B7r 3               
0008B7r 3               
0008B7r 3               
0008B7r 3               ; ## CMOVE_UP ( add1 add2 u -- ) "Copy bytes from high to low"
0008B7r 3               ; ## "cmove>"  auto  ANS string
0008B7r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/string/CMOVEtop
0008B7r 3                       ; Based on code in Leventhal, Lance A. "6502 Assembly Language
0008B7r 3                       ; Routines", p. 201, where it is called "move right".
0008B7r 3                       ;
0008B7r 3                       ; There are no official tests for this word.
0008B7r 3                       ; """
0008B7r 3               
0008B7r 3               xt_cmove_up:
0008B7r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
0008BAr 3               
0008BAr 3                               ; Move destination address to where we can work with it
0008BAr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
0008BCr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2        ; use tmp2 because easier to remember
0008BEr 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
0008C0r 3  18                           clc
0008C1r 3  75 01                        adc 1,x
0008C3r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1      ; point to last page of destination
0008C5r 3               
0008C5r 3                               ; Move source address to where we can work with it
0008C5r 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x
0008C7r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1        ; use tmp1 because easier to remember
0008C9r 3  B5 05                        lda 5,x
0008CBr 3  18                           clc
0008CCr 3  75 01                        adc 1,x
0008CEr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1      ; point to last page of source
0008D0r 3  F6 01                        inc 1,x         ; allows us to use bne with dec 1,x below
0008D2r 3               
0008D2r 3                               ; Move the last partial page first
0008D2r 3  B4 00                        ldy 0,x         ; length of last page
0008D4r 3  F0 0E                        beq @nopartial
0008D6r 3               
0008D6r 3               @outerloop:
0008D6r 3  88                           dey
0008D7r 3  F0 07                        beq @finishpage
0008D9r 3               
0008D9r 3               @innerloop:
0008D9r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
0008DBr 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp2),y
0008DDr 3  88                           dey
0008DEr 3  D0 F9                        bne @innerloop
0008E0r 3               
0008E0r 3               @finishpage:
0008E0r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)      ; handle y = 0 separately
0008E2r 3  92 rr                        sta (tmp2)
0008E4r 3               
0008E4r 3               @nopartial:
0008E4r 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp1+1      ; back up to previous pages
0008E6r 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp2+1
0008E8r 3  D6 01                        dec 1,x
0008EAr 3  D0 EA                        bne @outerloop
0008ECr 3               @done:
0008ECr 3                               ; clear up the stack and leave
0008ECr 3  8A                           txa
0008EDr 3  18                           clc
0008EEr 3  69 06                        adc #6
0008F0r 3  AA                           tax
0008F1r 3               
0008F1r 3  60           z_cmove_up:     rts
0008F2r 3               
0008F2r 3               
0008F2r 3               
0008F2r 3               ; ## COLON ( "name" -- ) "Start compilation of a new word"
0008F2r 3               ; ## ":"  auto  ANS core
0008F2r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Colon
0008F2r 3                       ;
0008F2r 3                       ; Use the CREATE routine and fill in the rest by hand.
0008F2r 3                       ; """
0008F2r 3               
0008F2r 3               xt_colon:
0008F2r 3                               ; If we're already in the compile state, complain
0008F2r 3                               ; and quit
0008F2r 3  A5 rr                        lda state
0008F4r 3  05 rr                        ora state+1
0008F6r 3  F0 05                        beq @1
0008F8r 3               
0008F8r 3  A9 07                        lda #err_state
0008FAr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
0008FDr 3               @1:
0008FDr 3                               ; switch to compile state
0008FDr 3  C6 rr                        dec state
0008FFr 3  C6 rr                        dec state+1
000901r 3               
000901r 3                               ; Set bit 6 in status to tell ";" and RECURSE this is a normal
000901r 3                               ; word
000901r 3  A9 40                        lda #%01000000
000903r 3  04 rr                        tsb status
000905r 3               
000905r 3                               ; CREATE is going to change the DP to point to the new word's
000905r 3                               ; header. While this is fine for (say) variables, it would mean
000905r 3                               ; that FIND-NAME etc would find a half-finished word when
000905r 3                               ; looking in the Dictionary. To prevent this, we save the old
000905r 3                               ; version of DP and restore it later. The new DP is placed in
000905r 3                               ; the variable WORKWORD until we're finished with a SEMICOLON.
000905r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr current_to_dp
000908r 3  A5 rr                        lda dp+1            ; CREATE uses a lot of variables
00090Ar 3  48                           pha
00090Br 3  A5 rr                        lda dp
00090Dr 3  48                           pha
00090Er 3               
00090Er 3                               ; Tell create not to print warning for duplicate name.
00090Er 3  A9 80                        lda #%10000000
000910r 3  04 rr                        tsb status
000912r 3               
000912r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_create
000915r 3               
000915r 3                               ; Get the nt (not the xt!) of the new word as described above.
000915r 3                               ; Only COLON, SEMICOLON and RECURSE get to access WORKWORD
000915r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr current_to_dp   ; This might be able to be omitted
000918r 3  A5 rr                        lda dp
00091Ar 3  85 rr                        sta workword
00091Cr 3  A5 rr                        lda dp+1
00091Er 3  85 rr                        sta workword+1
000920r 3               
000920r 3                               ; Restore original DP
000920r 3  68                           pla
000921r 3  85 rr                        sta dp
000923r 3  68                           pla
000924r 3  85 rr                        sta dp+1
000926r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr dp_to_current
000929r 3               
000929r 3                               ; CREATE includes a subroutine jump to DOVAR by default. We
000929r 3                               ; back up three bytes and overwrite that.
000929r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
00092Br 3  38                           sec
00092Cr 3  E9 03                        sbc #3
00092Er 3  85 rr                        sta cp
000930r 3  B0 02                        bcs @done
000932r 3  C6 rr                        dec cp+1
000934r 3               @done:
000934r 3  60           z_colon:        rts
000935r 3               
000935r 3               
000935r 3               ; ## COLON_NONAME ( -- ) "Start compilation of a new word""
000935r 3               ; ## ":NONAME"  auto  ANS core
000935r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ColonNONAME
000935r 3                       ; Compile a word with no nt.  ";" will put its xt on the stack.
000935r 3                       ; """
000935r 3               
000935r 3               xt_colon_noname:
000935r 3                               ; If we're already in the compile state, complain
000935r 3                               ; and quit
000935r 3  A5 rr                        lda state
000937r 3  05 rr                        ora state+1
000939r 3  F0 05                        beq @1
00093Br 3               
00093Br 3  A9 07                        lda #err_state
00093Dr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
000940r 3               @1:
000940r 3                               ; switch to compile state
000940r 3  C6 rr                        dec state
000942r 3  C6 rr                        dec state+1
000944r 3               
000944r 3                               ; Clear bit 6 in status to tell ";" and RECURSE this is
000944r 3                               ; a :NONAME word.
000944r 3  A9 40                        lda #%01000000
000946r 3  14 rr                        trb status
000948r 3               
000948r 3                               ; Put cp (the xt for this word) in WORKWORD. The flag above
000948r 3                               ; lets both ";" and RECURSE know that is is an xt instead of an
000948r 3                               ; nt and they will modify their behavior.
000948r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
00094Ar 3  85 rr                        sta workword
00094Cr 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
00094Er 3  85 rr                        sta workword+1
000950r 3               @done:
000950r 3  60           z_colon_noname:        rts
000951r 3               
000951r 3               
000951r 3               
000951r 3               ; ## COMMA ( n -- ) "Allot and store one cell in memory"
000951r 3               ; ## ","  auto  ANS core
000951r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Comma
000951r 3                       ; Store TOS at current place in memory.
000951r 3                       ;
000951r 3                       ; Since this an eight-bit machine, we can ignore all alignment issues.
000951r 3                       ; """
000951r 3               
000951r 3               xt_comma:
000951r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
000954r 3               
000954r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000956r 3  92 rr                        sta (cp)
000958r 3               
000958r 3  E6 rr                        inc cp
00095Ar 3  D0 02                        bne @1
00095Cr 3  E6 rr                        inc cp+1
00095Er 3               @1:
00095Er 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
000960r 3  92 rr                        sta (cp)
000962r 3               
000962r 3  E6 rr                        inc cp
000964r 3  D0 02                        bne @done
000966r 3  E6 rr                        inc cp+1
000968r 3               @done:
000968r 3  E8                           inx
000969r 3  E8                           inx
00096Ar 3               
00096Ar 3  60           z_comma:        rts
00096Br 3               
00096Br 3               
00096Br 3               
00096Br 3               ; ## COMPARE ( addr1 u1 addr2 u2 -- -1 | 0 | 1) "Compare two strings"
00096Br 3               ; ## "compare"   auto  ANS string
00096Br 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/string/COMPARE
00096Br 3                       ; Compare string1 (denoted by addr1 u1) to string2 (denoted by
00096Br 3                       ; addr2 u2).  Return -1 if string1 < string2, 0 if string1 = string2
00096Br 3                       ; and 1 if string1 > string2 (ASCIIbetical comparison).  A string
00096Br 3                       ; that entirely matches the beginning of the other string, but is
00096Br 3                       ; shorter, is considered less than the longer string.
00096Br 3                       ; """
00096Br 3               
00096Br 3               xt_compare:
00096Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_4
00096Er 3               
00096Er 3                               ; Load the two string addresses into tmp1 and tmp2.
00096Er 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
000970r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
000972r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
000974r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
000976r 3  B5 06                        lda 6,x
000978r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
00097Ar 3  B5 07                        lda 7,x
00097Cr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
00097Er 3                               ; The counts will be used in-place on the stack.
00097Er 3               
00097Er 3               @compare_loop:
00097Er 3                               ; Check to see if we are out of letters.
00097Er 3               
00097Er 3                               ; Check string1
00097Er 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x
000980r 3  15 05                        ora 5,x
000982r 3  F0 2C                        beq @str1_done
000984r 3               
000984r 3                               ; Check string2
000984r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000986r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
000988r 3  F0 3A                        beq @greater    ; Str2 empty first
00098Ar 3               
00098Ar 3               @check_letter:
00098Ar 3                               ; Both strings have at least one letter left.
00098Ar 3                               ; Check the letters against each other.
00098Ar 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
00098Cr 3  D2 rr                        cmp (tmp2)
00098Er 3  90 26                        bcc @less
000990r 3  D0 32                        bne @greater
000992r 3               @next_letter:
000992r 3                               ; Move both tmp pointers and decrement the counts
000992r 3                               ; on the stack.
000992r 3                               ; Increment tmp1
000992r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1
000994r 3  D0 02                        bne @1
000996r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1+1
000998r 3               @1:
000998r 3                               ; Increment tmp2
000998r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2
00099Ar 3  D0 02                        bne @2
00099Cr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2+1
00099Er 3               @2:
00099Er 3                               ; Decrement count1 on the stack.
00099Er 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x
0009A0r 3  D0 02                        bne @3
0009A2r 3  D6 05                        dec 5,x
0009A4r 3               @3:
0009A4r 3  D6 04                        dec 4,x
0009A6r 3               
0009A6r 3                               ; Decrement count2 on the stack.
0009A6r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0009A8r 3  D0 02                        bne @4
0009AAr 3  D6 01                        dec 1,x
0009ACr 3               @4:
0009ACr 3  D6 00                        dec 0,x
0009AEr 3               
0009AEr 3                               ; Loop around and check again.
0009AEr 3  80 CE                        bra @compare_loop
0009B0r 3               
0009B0r 3               @str1_done:
0009B0r 3                               ; String 1 is out of letters. Check string 2.
0009B0r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0009B2r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
0009B4r 3  F0 08                        beq @equal      ; Both out of letters
0009B6r 3               
0009B6r 3                               ; Falls into less (str1 is out but str2 has more)
