000E83r 3                       ; followed by the Data Stack content (if any).
000E83r 3                       ;
000E83r 3                       ; Since this is for humans, we don't have to worry about speed.
000E83r 3                       ; """
000E83r 3               
000E83r 3               xt_dot_s:
000E83r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_depth    ; ( -- u )
000E86r 3               
000E86r 3                               ; Print stack depth in brackets
000E86r 3  A9 3C                        lda #$3c        ; ASCII for "<"
000E88r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000E8Br 3               
000E8Br 3                               ; We keep a copy of the number of the things on the stack
000E8Br 3                               ; to use as a counter later down. This assumes that there
000E8Br 3                               ; are less than 255 elements on the stack
000E8Br 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000E8Dr 3  48                           pha
000E8Er 3               
000E8Er 3                               ; print unsigned number without the trailing space
000E8Er 3  CA                           dex             ; DUP
000E8Fr 3  CA                           dex
000E90r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000E92r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
000E94r 3               
000E94r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_u
000E97r 3               
000E97r 3  A9 3E                        lda #$3e        ; ASCII for ">"
000E99r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000E9Cr 3  A9 20                        lda #AscSP      ; ASCII for SPACE
000E9Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000EA1r 3               
000EA1r 3  E8                           inx
000EA2r 3  E8                           inx
000EA3r 3               
000EA3r 3                               ; There will be lots of cases where the stack is empty. If that
000EA3r 3                               ; is so, get out of here quickly
000EA3r 3  E0 rr                        cpx #dsp0
000EA5r 3  F0 1E                        beq @done
000EA7r 3               
000EA7r 3               @have_stack:
000EA7r 3                               ; We have at least one element on the stack. The depth of the
000EA7r 3                               ; stack is on the stack, we can use it as a counter. We go
000EA7r 3                               ; from bottom to top
000EA7r 3  7A                           ply
000EA8r 3               
000EA8r 3  A9 rr                        lda #dsp0-1     ; go up one to avoid garbage
000EAAr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3
000EACr 3  64 rr                        stz tmp3+1      ; must be zero page on the 65c02
000EAEr 3               @loop:
000EAEr 3  CA                           dex
000EAFr 3  CA                           dex
000EB0r 3               
000EB0r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp3)
000EB2r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
000EB4r 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp3
000EB6r 3               
000EB6r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp3)
000EB8r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000EBAr 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp3
000EBCr 3  5A                           phy
000EBDr 3               
000EBDr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dot
000EC0r 3               
000EC0r 3  7A                           ply
000EC1r 3  88                           dey
000EC2r 3  D0 EA                        bne @loop
000EC4r 3               
000EC4r 3  48                           pha             ; dummy to balance stack
000EC5r 3               @done:
000EC5r 3  68                           pla
000EC6r 3  60           z_dot_s:        rts
000EC7r 3               
000EC7r 3               
000EC7r 3               
000EC7r 3               ; ## D_DOT ( d -- ) "Print double"
000EC7r 3               ; ## "d."  tested  ANS double
000EC7r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/double/Dd"""
000EC7r 3                       ;
000EC7r 3                       ; From the Forth code:
000EC7r 3                       ; : D. TUCK DABS <# #S ROT SIGN #> TYPE SPACE ;
000EC7r 3                       ; """
000EC7r 3               
000EC7r 3               xt_d_dot:
000EC7r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
000ECAr 3               
000ECAr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_tuck
000ECDr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dabs
000ED0r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_less_number_sign
000ED3r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_number_sign_s
000ED6r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_rot
000ED9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_sign
000EDCr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_number_sign_greater
000EDFr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_type
000EE2r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000EE5r 3               
000EE5r 3  60           z_d_dot:        rts
000EE6r 3               
000EE6r 3               
000EE6r 3               
000EE6r 3               ; ## D_DOT_R ( d u -- ) "Print double right-justified u wide"
000EE6r 3               ; ## "d.r"  tested  ANS double
000EE6r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/double/DDotR"""
000EE6r 3                       ; Based on the Forth code
000EE6r 3                       ;  : D.R >R TUCK DABS <# #S ROT SIGN #> R> OVER - SPACES TYPE ;
000EE6r 3                       ; """
000EE6r 3               
000EE6r 3               xt_d_dot_r:
000EE6r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
000EE9r 3                               ; From the forth code:
000EE9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_to_r
000EECr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_tuck
000EEFr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dabs
000EF2r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_less_number_sign
000EF5r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_number_sign_s
000EF8r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_rot
000EFBr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_sign
000EFEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_number_sign_greater
000F01r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_r_from
000F04r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_over
000F07r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_minus
000F0Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_spaces
000F0Dr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_type
000F10r 3               
000F10r 3  60           z_d_dot_r:      rts
000F11r 3               
000F11r 3               
000F11r 3               
000F11r 3               ; ## DROP ( u -- ) "Pop top entry on Data Stack"
000F11r 3               ; ## "drop"  auto  ANS core
000F11r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/DROP"""
000F11r 3               xt_drop:
000F11r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
000F14r 3               
000F14r 3  E8                           inx
000F15r 3  E8                           inx
000F16r 3               
000F16r 3  60           z_drop:         rts
000F17r 3               
000F17r 3               
000F17r 3               ; ## DUMP ( addr u -- ) "Display a memory region"
000F17r 3               ; ## "dump"  tested  ANS tools
000F17r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/tools/DUMP
000F17r 3                       ;
000F17r 3                       ; DUMP's exact output is defined as "implementation dependent".
000F17r 3                       ; This is in assembler because it is
000F17r 3                       ; useful for testing and development, so we want to have it work
000F17r 3                       ; as soon as possible. Uses TMP2
000F17r 3                       ; """
000F17r 3               
000F17r 3               xt_dump:
000F17r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
000F1Ar 3               @row:
000F1Ar 3                               ; start counter for 16 numbers per row
000F1Ar 3  A0 10                        ldy #16
000F1Cr 3               
000F1Cr 3                               ; We use TMP2 as the index for the ASCII characters
000F1Cr 3                               ; that we print at the and of the hex block. We
000F1Cr 3                               ; start saving them at HERE (CP)
000F1Cr 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2
000F1Er 3               
000F1Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_cr
000F21r 3               
000F21r 3                               ; print address number
000F21r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
000F23r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr byte_to_ascii
000F26r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
000F28r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr byte_to_ascii
000F2Br 3               
000F2Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F2Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F31r 3               @loop:
000F31r 3                               ; if there are zero bytes left to display, we're done
000F31r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000F33r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
000F35r 3  F0 39                        beq @all_printed
000F37r 3               
000F37r 3                               ; dump the contents
000F37r 3  A1 02                        lda (2,x)
000F39r 3  48                           pha                     ; byte_to_ascii destroys A
000F3Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr byte_to_ascii
000F3Dr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F40r 3  68                           pla
000F41r 3               
000F41r 3                               ; Handle ASCII printing
000F41r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr is_printable
000F44r 3  B0 02                        bcs @printable
000F46r 3  A9 2E                        lda #'.'                 ; Print dot if not printable
000F48r 3               @printable:
000F48r 3  5A                           phy                     ; save counter
000F49r 3  A4 rr                        ldy tmp2
000F4Br 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
000F4Dr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2
000F4Fr 3  7A                           ply
000F50r 3               
000F50r 3                               ; extra space after eight bytes
000F50r 3  C0 09                        cpy #9
000F52r 3  D0 03                        bne @next_char
000F54r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F57r 3               
000F57r 3               @next_char:
000F57r 3  F6 02                        inc 2,x
000F59r 3  D0 02                        bne @counter
000F5Br 3  F6 03                        inc 3,x
000F5Dr 3               
000F5Dr 3               @counter:
000F5Dr 3                               ; loop counter
000F5Dr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000F5Fr 3  D0 02                        bne @1
000F61r 3  D6 01                        dec 1,x
000F63r 3               @1:
000F63r 3  D6 00                        dec 0,x
000F65r 3  88                           dey
000F66r 3  D0 C9                        bne @loop               ; next byte
000F68r 3               
000F68r 3                               ; Done with one line, print the ASCII version of these
000F68r 3                               ; characters
000F68r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F6Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_ascii
000F6Er 3               
000F6Er 3  80 AA                        bra @row                ; new row
000F70r 3               
000F70r 3               @all_printed:
000F70r 3                               ; See if there are any ASCII characters in the buffer
000F70r 3                               ; left to print
000F70r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2
000F72r 3  F0 06                        beq @done
000F74r 3               
000F74r 3                               ; In theory, we could try to make the ASCII part line
000F74r 3                               ; up with the line before it. But that is a hassle (we
000F74r 3                               ; use three bytes for each missed hex entry, and
000F74r 3                               ; then there is the gap after eight entries) and it
000F74r 3                               ; makes it harder to read. We settle for one extra
000F74r 3                               ; space instead for the moment
000F74r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F77r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_ascii
000F7Ar 3               @done:
000F7Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_two_drop         ; one byte less than 4x INX
000F7Dr 3  60           z_dump:         rts
000F7Er 3               
000F7Er 3               
000F7Er 3               print_ascii:
000F7Er 3                               ; Print the ASCII characters that we have saved from
000F7Er 3                               ; HERE (CP) to HERE plus whatever is in TMP2. This routine
000F7Er 3                               ; is not compiled (DUMP is probably never compiled anyway)
000F7Er 3                               ; but we keep it inside the scope of DUMP.
000F7Er 3  A0 00                        ldy #0
000F80r 3               @ascii_loop:
000F80r 3  B1 rr                        lda (cp),y
000F82r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
000F85r 3  C8                           iny
000F86r 3               
000F86r 3                               ; extra space after eight chars
000F86r 3  C0 08                        cpy #8
000F88r 3  D0 03                        bne @1
000F8Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
000F8Dr 3               @1:
000F8Dr 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp2
000F8Fr 3  D0 EF                        bne @ascii_loop
000F91r 3               
000F91r 3  60                           rts
000F92r 3               
000F92r 3               
000F92r 3               
000F92r 3               ; ## DUP ( u -- u u ) "Duplicate TOS"
000F92r 3               ; ## "dup"  auto  ANS core
000F92r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/DUP"""
000F92r 3               xt_dup:
000F92r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
000F95r 3               
000F95r 3  CA                           dex
000F96r 3  CA                           dex
000F97r 3               
000F97r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x         ; LSB
000F99r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
000F9Br 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x         ; MSB
000F9Dr 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
000F9Fr 3               
000F9Fr 3  60           z_dup:          rts
000FA0r 3               
000FA0r 3               
000FA0r 3               ; ## ED ( -- u ) "Line-based editor"
000FA0r 3               ; ## "ed"  fragment  Tali Forth
000FA0r 3                       ; """Start the line-based editor ed6502. See separate file
000FA0r 3                       ; ed.asm or the manual for details.
000FA0r 3                       ; """
000FA0r 3               xt_ed:
000FA0r 3                       .ifdef ed6502
000FA0r 3                               jsr ed6502      ; kept in separate file
000FA0r 3                       .endif
000FA0r 3               
000FA0r 3  60           z_ed:           rts
000FA1r 3               
000FA1r 3               
000FA1r 3               ; ## EDITOR_WORDLIST ( -- u ) "WID for the Editor wordlist"
000FA1r 3               ; ## "editor-wordlist"  tested  Tali Editor
000FA1r 3                       ; """ Commonly used like `editor-wordlist >order` to add the editor
000FA1r 3                       ; words to the search order so they can be used.  This will need
000FA1r 3                       ; to be done before any of the words marked "Tali Editor" can be
000FA1r 3                       ; used.  See the tutorial on Wordlists and the Search Order for
000FA1r 3                       ; more information.
000FA1r 3               
000FA1r 3                       ;
000FA1r 3                       ; This is a dummy entry, the code is shared with ONE
000FA1r 3                       ; """
000FA1r 3               
000FA1r 3               
000FA1r 3               ; ## ELSE (C: orig -- orig) ( -- ) "Conditional flow control"
000FA1r 3               ; ## "else"  auto  ANS core
000FA1r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ELSE
000FA1r 3                       ;
000FA1r 3                       ; The code is shared with ENDOF
000FA1r 3                       ; """
000FA1r 3               
000FA1r 3               xt_else:
000FA1r 3               xt_endof:
000FA1r 3                               ; Put an unconditional branch.
000FA1r 3  A0 rr                        ldy #>branch_runtime
000FA3r 3  A9 rr                        lda #<branch_runtime
000FA5r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_subroutine
000FA8r 3               
000FA8r 3                               ; Put the address of the branch address on the stack.
000FA8r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_here
000FABr 3               
000FABr 3                               ; Use zero for the branch address for now.
000FABr 3                               ; THEN will fill it in later.
000FABr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_zero
000FAEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_comma
000FB1r 3               
000FB1r 3                               ; Get the address to jump to (just after the
000FB1r 3                               ; unconditional branch) for the IF to jump to
000FB1r 3                               ; when false.
000FB1r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_here
000FB4r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_rot
000FB7r 3               
000FB7r 3                               ; Update the original if 0branch address.
000FB7r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_store
000FBAr 3               z_else:
000FBAr 3               z_endof:
000FBAr 3  60                           rts
000FBBr 3               
000FBBr 3               
000FBBr 3               
000FBBr 3               branch_runtime:
000FBBr 3                       ; """Runtime component for a branch. Used by ELSE and ENDOF. This was
000FBBr 3                       ; formally part of a separate word BRANCH which was later removed.
000FBBr 3                       ; """
000FBBr 3               
000FBBr 3                               ; The address on the Return Stack points to the last byte
000FBBr 3                               ; of the JSR address, one byte below the branch literal
000FBBr 3  68                           pla
000FBCr 3  85 rr                        sta tmpbranch
000FBEr 3  68                           pla
000FBFr 3  85 rr                        sta tmpbranch+1
000FC1r 3               
000FC1r 3                               ; Keep in mind: the address we just popped points one byte
000FC1r 3                               ; lower than the branch literal we want to grab
000FC1r 3  A0 01                        ldy #1
000FC3r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmpbranch),y  ; LSB
000FC5r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
000FC7r 3  C8                           iny
000FC8r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmpbranch),y  ; MSB
000FCAr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
000FCCr 3               
000FCCr 3  6C rr rr                     jmp (tmp1)
000FCFr 3               
000FCFr 3               
000FCFr 3               
000FCFr 3               ; ## EMIT ( char -- ) "Print character to current output"
000FCFr 3               ; ## "emit"  auto  ANS core
000FCFr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/EMIT
000FCFr 3                       ; Run-time default for EMIT. The user can revector this by changing
000FCFr 3                       ; the value of the OUTPUT variable. We ignore the MSB completely, and
000FCFr 3                       ; do not check to see if we have been given a valid ASCII character.
000FCFr 3                       ; Don't make this native compile.
000FCFr 3                       ; """
000FCFr 3               
000FCFr 3               xt_emit:
000FCFr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
000FD2r 3               
000FD2r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000FD4r 3  E8                           inx
000FD5r 3  E8                           inx
000FD6r 3               
000FD6r 3               emit_a:
000FD6r 3                       ; We frequently want to print the character in A without fooling
000FD6r 3                       ; around with the Data Stack. This is emit_a's job, which still
000FD6r 3                       ; allows the output to be vectored. Call it with JSR as you
000FD6r 3                       ; would XT_EMIT
000FD6r 3  6C rr rr                     jmp (output)            ; JSR/RTS
000FD9r 3               
000FD9r 3               z_emit:         ; never reached
000FD9r 3               
000FD9r 3               
000FD9r 3               
000FD9r 3               ; ## EMPTY_BUFFERS ( -- ) "Empty all buffers without saving"
000FD9r 3               ; ## "empty-buffers"  tested  ANS block ext
000FD9r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/EMPTY-BUFFERS"""
000FD9r 3               xt_empty_buffers:
000FD9r 3                               ; Set the buffer status to empty.
000FD9r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
000FDBr 3  A9 00                        lda #0
000FDDr 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y      ; Only LSB is used.
000FDFr 3               z_empty_buffers:
000FDFr 3  60                           rts
000FE0r 3               
000FE0r 3               
000FE0r 3               ; ## ENDCASE (C: case-sys -- ) ( x -- ) "Conditional flow control"
000FE0r 3               ; ## "endcase"  auto  ANS core ext
000FE0r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ENDCASE"""
000FE0r 3               
000FE0r 3               xt_endcase:
000FE0r 3                               ; Postpone DROP to remove the item
000FE0r 3                               ; being checked.
000FE0r 3  A0 rr                        ldy #>xt_drop
000FE2r 3  A9 rr                        lda #<xt_drop
000FE4r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_subroutine
000FE7r 3               
000FE7r 3                               ; There are a number of address (of branches that need their
000FE7r 3                               ; jump addressed filled in with the address of right here).
000FE7r 3                               ; Keep calling THEN to deal with them until we reach the
000FE7r 3                               ; 0 that CASE put on the stack at the beginning.
000FE7r 3               @endcase_loop:
000FE7r 3                               ; Check for 0 on the stack.
000FE7r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
000FE9r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
000FEBr 3  F0 05                        beq @done
000FEDr 3               
000FEDr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_then
000FF0r 3  80 F5                        bra @endcase_loop
000FF2r 3               @done:
000FF2r 3                               ; Remove the 0 from the stack.
000FF2r 3  E8                           inx
000FF3r 3  E8                           inx
000FF4r 3  60           z_endcase:      rts
000FF5r 3               
000FF5r 3               
000FF5r 3               
000FF5r 3               ; ## ENDOF (C: case-sys1 of-sys1-- case-sys2) ( -- ) "Conditional flow control"
000FF5r 3               ; ## "endof"  auto  ANS core ext
000FF5r 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; This is a dummy entry, the code is shared with ELSE
000FF5r 3                       ; """
000FF5r 3               
000FF5r 3               
000FF5r 3               ; ## ENVIRONMENT_Q  ( addr u -- 0 | i*x true )  "Return system information"
000FF5r 3               ; ## "environment?"  auto  ANS core
000FF5r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ENVIRONMENTq
000FF5r 3                       ;
000FF5r 3                       ; By ANS definition, we use upper-case strings here, see the
000FF5r 3                       ; string file for details. This can be realized as a high-level
000FF5r 3                       ; Forth word as
000FF5r 3                       ;
000FF5r 3                       ; : STRING_OF POSTPONE 2OVER POSTPONE COMPARE POSTPONE 0=
000FF5r 3                       ;    POSTPONE IF POSTPONE 2DROP ; IMMEDIATE COMPILE-ONLY
000FF5r 3                       ; HEX
000FF5r 3                       ; : ENVIRONMENT? ( C-ADDR U -- FALSE | I*X TRUE )
000FF5r 3                       ; CASE
000FF5r 3                       ; S" /COUNTED-STRING"    STRING_OF  7FFF TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" /HOLD"              STRING_OF    FF TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" /PAD"               STRING_OF    54 TRUE ENDOF ( 84 DECIMAL )
000FF5r 3                       ; S" ADDRESS-UNIT-BITS"  STRING_OF     8 TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" FLOORED"            STRING_OF FALSE TRUE ENDOF ( WE HAVE SYMMETRIC )
000FF5r 3                       ; S" MAX-CHAR"           STRING_OF   255 TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" MAX-D"              STRING_OF
000FF5r 3                                                    ; 7FFFFFFF. TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" MAX-N"              STRING_OF  7FFF TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" MAX-U"              STRING_OF  FFFF TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" MAX-UD"             STRING_OF
000FF5r 3                                                    ; FFFFFFFF. TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" RETURN-STACK-CELLS" STRING_OF    80 TRUE ENDOF
000FF5r 3                       ; S" STACK-CELLS"        STRING_OF    20 TRUE ENDOF ( FROM DEFINITIONS.ASM )
000FF5r 3                       ; ( DEFAULT ) 2DROP FALSE FALSE ( ONE FALSE WILL DROPPED BY ENDCASE )
000FF5r 3                       ; ENDCASE ;
000FF5r 3                       ;
000FF5r 3                       ; but that uses lots of memory and increases the start up time. This
000FF5r 3                       ; word is rarely used so we can try to keep it short at the expense
000FF5r 3                       ; of speed.
000FF5r 3                       ; """
000FF5r 3               
000FF5r 3               xt_environment_q:
000FF5r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
000FF8r 3               
000FF8r 3                               ; This code is table-driven: We walk through the list of
000FF8r 3                               ; strings until we find one that matches, and then we take
000FF8r 3                               ; the equivalent data from the results table. This is made
000FF8r 3                               ; a bit harder by the fact that some of these return a
000FF8r 3                               ; double-cell number and some a single-cell one.
000FF8r 3               
000FF8r 3                               ; We will walk through the table with variables that return
000FF8r 3                               ; a single-cell result
000FF8r 3  A0 00                        ldy #00                 ; counter for table
000FFAr 3               
000FFAr 3                               ; We use a flag on the the stack to signal if we have a single-cell
000FFAr 3                               ; or double-cell number. We use 0 to signal single-cell and 1 for
000FFAr 3                               ; double-cell.
000FFAr 3  5A                           phy
000FFBr 3               @table_loop:
000FFBr 3                               ; We arrived here with the address of the string to be checked
000FFBr 3                               ; on the stack. We make a copy. Index is in Y
000FFBr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_two_dup          ; ( addr u addr u ) 2DUP does not use Y
000FFEr 3               
000FFEr 3                               ; We do our work on the TOS to speed things up
000FFEr 3  CA                           dex
000FFFr 3  CA                           dex                     ; ( addr u addr u ? )
001000r 3               
001000r 3                               ; Get address of string to check from table
001000r 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_table_single,y
001003r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001005r 3  C8                           iny
001006r 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_table_single,y
001009r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x                 ; ( addr u addr u addr-t )
00100Br 3  C8                           iny
00100Cr 3               
00100Cr 3                               ; See if this is the last entry. The LSB is still in A
00100Cr 3  15 00                        ora 0,x
00100Er 3  F0 4D                        beq @table_done
001010r 3               
001010r 3                               ; We have a string entry. The address there is stored in
001010r 3                               ; old-style address format, that is, the first byte is the
001010r 3                               ; length of the string
001010r 3  5A                           phy                     ; save Y, which is used by COUNT
001011r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_count            ; ( addr u addr u addr-s u-s )
001014r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_compare          ; ( addr u f )
001017r 3  7A                           ply
001018r 3               
001018r 3                               ; If we found a match (flag is zero -- COMPARE is weird
001018r 3                               ; that way), return the result
001018r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
00101Ar 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
00101Cr 3  F0 04                        beq @got_result
00101Er 3               
00101Er 3                               ; Flag is not zero, so not a perfect match, so try next
00101Er 3                               ; word
00101Er 3  E8                           inx                     ; DROP, now ( addr u )
00101Fr 3  E8                           inx
001020r 3               
001020r 3  80 D9                        bra @table_loop
001022r 3               
001022r 3               @got_result:
001022r 3                               ; We arrive here with ( addr u -1 ) and know that we've found
001022r 3                               ; a match. The index of the match+2 is in Y.
001022r 3  E8                           inx                     ; drop flag, now ( addr u )
001023r 3  E8                           inx
001024r 3  88                           dey                     ; go back to index we had
001025r 3  88                           dey
001026r 3               
001026r 3                               ; See if this is a single-cell word.
001026r 3  68                           pla
001027r 3  D0 0D                        bne @double_result
001029r 3               
001029r 3                               ; Single-cell result
001029r 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_results_single,y
00102Cr 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
00102Er 3  C8                           iny
00102Fr 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_results_single,y
001032r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x                 ; ( res u )
001034r 3               
001034r 3  80 1F                        bra @set_flag
001036r 3               
001036r 3               @double_result:
001036r 3                               ; This is a double-celled result, which means we have to
001036r 3                               ; fool around with the index some more. We also need a
001036r 3                               ; further cell on the stack
001036r 3  CA                           dex                     ; ( addr u ? )
001037r 3  CA                           dex
001038r 3               
001038r 3                               ; We have 11 single-cell words we check, plus the 0000 as
001038r 3                               ; a marker for the end of the table, so we arrive here
001038r 3                               ; with Y as 22 or more. To get the index for the double-
001038r 3                               ; cell words, we move the result
001038r 3  98                           tya
001039r 3  38                           sec
00103Ar 3  E9 18                        sbc #24
00103Cr 3               
00103Cr 3                               ; We have four bytes per entry in the table, but the index
00103Cr 3                               ; keeps increasing by two, so we only have to multiply by
00103Cr 3                               ; two (shift left once) to get the right result
00103Cr 3  0A                           asl
00103Dr 3  A8                           tay
00103Er 3               
00103Er 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_results_double,y
001041r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
001043r 3  C8                           iny
001044r 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_results_double,y
001047r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x                 ; ( res u ? )
001049r 3  C8                           iny
00104Ar 3               
00104Ar 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_results_double,y
00104Dr 3  95 04                        sta 4,x
00104Fr 3  C8                           iny
001050r 3  B9 rr rr                     lda env_results_double,y
001053r 3  95 05                        sta 5,x                 ; ( res res ? )
001055r 3               
001055r 3                               ; fall through to @set_flag
001055r 3               @set_flag:
001055r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$ff
001057r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001059r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x                 ; ( res f )
00105Br 3               
00105Br 3  80 14                        bra @done
00105Dr 3               @table_done:
00105Dr 3                               ; We're done with a table, because the entry was a zero.
00105Dr 3                               ; We arrive here with ( addr u addr u 0 )
00105Dr 3               
00105Dr 3                               ; We take the flag from stack and increase it by one. If the
00105Dr 3                               ; flag is zero, we have just completed the single-cell number
00105Dr 3                               ; strings, so we in increase the flag and try again. Otherwise,
00105Dr 3                               ; we're done with the double-cell table without having found
00105Dr 3                               ; a match, and we're done
00105Dr 3  68                           pla
00105Er 3  D0 09                        bne @no_match
001060r 3               
001060r 3                               ; Flag is zero, increase it to one and start over to check
001060r 3                               ; double-cell values
001060r 3  1A                           inc
001061r 3  48                           pha
001062r 3               
001062r 3  8A                           txa
001063r 3  18                           clc
001064r 3  69 06                        adc #6                  ; skip six bytes
001066r 3  AA                           tax                     ; ( addr u )
001067r 3               
001067r 3  80 92                        bra @table_loop
001069r 3               @no_match:
001069r 3                               ; Bummer, not found. We arrive here with
001069r 3                               ; ( addr u addr u 0 ) and need to return just a zero
001069r 3  8A                           txa
00106Ar 3  18                           clc
00106Br 3  69 0A                        adc #10
00106Dr 3  AA                           tax                     ; ( addr ) - not ( 0 ) !
00106Er 3               
00106Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_false
001071r 3               @done:
001071r 3               z_environment_q:
001071r 3  60                           rts
001072r 3               
001072r 3               
001072r 3               ; Tables for ENVIRONMENT?. We use two separate ones, one for the single-cell
001072r 3               ; results and one for the double-celled results. The zero cell at the
001072r 3               ; end of each table marks its, uh, end. The strings themselves are defined
001072r 3               ; in strings.asm. Note if we add more entries to the single-cell table, we
001072r 3               ; have to adapt the result code for double printout, where we subtract 22
001072r 3               ; (two bytes each single-cell string and two bytes for the end-of-table
001072r 3               ; marker 0000
001072r 3               env_table_single:
001072r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word envs_cs, envs_hold, envs_pad, envs_aub, envs_floored
001076r 3  rr rr rr rr  
00107Ar 3  rr rr        
00107Cr 3  rr rr rr rr          .word envs_max_char, envs_max_n, envs_max_u, envs_rsc
001080r 3  rr rr rr rr  
001084r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word envs_sc, envs_wl, 0000
001088r 3  00 00        
00108Ar 3               
00108Ar 3               env_table_double:
00108Ar 3  rr rr rr rr          .word envs_max_d, envs_max_ud, 0000
00108Er 3  00 00        
001090r 3               
001090r 3               env_results_single:
001090r 3  FF 7F                .word $7FFF     ; /COUNTED-STRING
001092r 3  FF 00                .word $00FF     ; /HOLD
001094r 3  54 00                .word $0054     ; /PAD (this is 84 decimal)
001096r 3  08 00                .word $0008     ; ADDRESS-UNIT-BITS (keep "$" to avoid octal!)
001098r 3  00 00                .word 0000      ; FLOORED ("FALSE", we have symmetric)
00109Ar 3  FF 00                .word $00FF     ; MAX-CHAR
00109Cr 3  FF 7F                .word $7FFF     ; MAX-N
00109Er 3  FF FF                .word $FFFF     ; MAX-U
0010A0r 3  80 00                .word $0080     ; RETURN-STACK-CELLS
0010A2r 3  20 00                .word $0020     ; STACK-CELLS (from definitions.asm)
0010A4r 3  09 00                .word $0009     ; WORDLISTS
0010A6r 3               
0010A6r 3               env_results_double:
0010A6r 3  FF 7F FF FF          .word $7FFF, $FFFF      ; MAX-D
0010AAr 3  FF FF FF FF          .word $FFFF, $FFFF      ; MAX-UD
0010AEr 3               
0010AEr 3               
0010AEr 3               ; ## EQUAL ( n n -- f ) "See if TOS and NOS are equal"
0010AEr 3               ; ## "="  auto  ANS core
0010AEr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Equal"""
0010AEr 3               
0010AEr 3               xt_equal:
0010AEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
0010B1r 3               
0010B1r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x                 ; LSB
0010B3r 3  D5 02                        cmp 2,x
0010B5r 3  D0 0A                        bne @false
0010B7r 3               
0010B7r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x                 ; MSB
0010B9r 3  D5 03                        cmp 3,x
0010BBr 3  D0 04                        bne @false
0010BDr 3               
0010BDr 3  A9 FF                        lda #$ff
0010BFr 3  80 02                        bra @done
0010C1r 3               
0010C1r 3  A9 00        @false:         lda #0                  ; drop thru to done
0010C3r 3               
0010C3r 3  95 02        @done:          sta 2,x
0010C5r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
0010C7r 3               
0010C7r 3  E8                           inx
0010C8r 3  E8                           inx
0010C9r 3               
0010C9r 3  60           z_equal:        rts
0010CAr 3               
0010CAr 3               
0010CAr 3               
0010CAr 3               ; ## BLANK ( addr u -- ) "Fill memory region with spaces"
0010CAr 3               ; ## "blank"  auto  ANS string
0010CAr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/string/BLANK"""
0010CAr 3               xt_blank:
0010CAr 3                               ; We don't check for underflow here because
0010CAr 3                               ; we deal with that in FILL
0010CAr 3  CA                           dex
0010CBr 3  CA                           dex
0010CCr 3  A9 20                        lda #AscSP
0010CEr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0010D0r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
0010D2r 3               
0010D2r 3  80 06                        bra xt_fill     ; skip over code for ERASE
0010D4r 3               
0010D4r 3               
0010D4r 3               ; ## ERASE ( addr u -- ) "Fill memory region with zeros"
0010D4r 3               ; ## "erase"  auto  ANS core ext
0010D4r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ERASE
0010D4r 3                       ; Note that ERASE works with "address" units
0010D4r 3                       ; (bytes), not cells.
0010D4r 3                       ; """
0010D4r 3               
0010D4r 3               xt_erase:
0010D4r 3                               ; We don't check for underflow here because
0010D4r 3                               ; we deal with that in FILL
0010D4r 3  CA                           dex
0010D5r 3  CA                           dex
0010D6r 3  74 00                        stz 0,x
0010D8r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
0010DAr 3               
0010DAr 3                               ; fall through to FILL
0010DAr 3               
0010DAr 3               ; ## FILL ( addr u char -- ) "Fill a memory region with a character"
0010DAr 3               ; ## "fill"  auto  ANS core
0010DAr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/FILL
0010DAr 3                       ; Fill u bytes of memory with char starting at addr. Note that
0010DAr 3                       ; this works on bytes, not on cells. On an 8-bit machine such as the
0010DAr 3                       ; 65c02, this is a serious pain in the rear. It is not defined what
0010DAr 3                       ; happens when we reach the end of the address space
0010DAr 3                       ; """
0010DAr 3               xt_fill:
0010DAr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
0010DDr 3               
0010DDr 3                               ; We use tmp1 to hold the address
0010DDr 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x         ; LSB
0010DFr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
0010E1r 3  B5 05                        lda 5,x
0010E3r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
0010E5r 3               
0010E5r 3                               ; We use tmp2 to hold the counter
0010E5r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
0010E7r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
0010E9r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
0010EBr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
0010EDr 3               
0010EDr 3                               ; We use Y to hold the character
0010EDr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0010EFr 3  A8                           tay
0010F0r 3               @loop:
0010F0r 3                               ; Unfortunately, we also need to make sure that we don't
0010F0r 3                               ; write further than the end of the RAM. So RAM_END must
0010F0r 3                               ; be larger or equal to the current address
0010F0r 3  A9 80                        lda #>ram_end           ; MSB
0010F2r 3  C5 rr                        cmp tmp1+1
0010F4r 3  90 21                        bcc @done               ; RAM_END < TMP1, so leave
0010F6r 3  D0 06                        bne @check_counter      ; RAM_END is not smaller and not equal
0010F8r 3               
0010F8r 3  A9 00                        lda #<ram_end           ; LSB, because MSBs were equal
0010FAr 3  C5 rr                        cmp tmp1
0010FCr 3  90 19                        bcc @done               ; RAM_END < TMP1, so leave
0010FEr 3               
0010FEr 3               @check_counter:
0010FEr 3                               ; See if our counter has reached zero
0010FEr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2
001100r 3  05 rr                        ora tmp2+1
001102r 3  F0 13                        beq @done
001104r 3               
001104r 3                               ; We're not in ROM and we still have stuff on the counter, so
001104r 3                               ; let's actually do what we came here to do
001104r 3  98                           tya
001105r 3  92 rr                        sta (tmp1)
001107r 3               
001107r 3                               ; Adjust the counter
001107r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2
001109r 3  D0 02                        bne @1
00110Br 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp2+1
00110Dr 3  C6 rr        @1:               dec tmp2
00110Fr 3               
00110Fr 3                               ; Next address
00110Fr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1
001111r 3  D0 DD                        bne @loop
001113r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1+1
001115r 3               
001115r 3  80 D9                        bra @loop
001117r 3               
001117r 3               @done:
001117r 3                               ; Drop three cells off the Data Stack. This uses one byte
001117r 3                               ; less than six times INX
001117r 3  8A                           txa
001118r 3  18                           clc
001119r 3  69 06                        adc #6
00111Br 3  AA                           tax
00111Cr 3               z_blank:
00111Cr 3               z_erase:
00111Cr 3  60           z_fill:         rts
00111Dr 3               
00111Dr 3               
00111Dr 3               
00111Dr 3               ; ## EXECUTE ( xt -- ) "Jump to word based on execution token"
00111Dr 3               ; ## "execute"  auto  ANS core
00111Dr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/EXECUTE"""
00111Dr 3               xt_execute:
00111Dr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
001120r 3               
001120r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr doexecute   ; do not combine to JMP (native coding)
001123r 3               
001123r 3  60           z_execute:      rts
001124r 3               
001124r 3               doexecute:
001124r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001126r 3  85 rr                        sta ip
001128r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
00112Ar 3  85 rr                        sta ip+1
00112Cr 3               
00112Cr 3  E8                           inx
00112Dr 3  E8                           inx
00112Er 3               
00112Er 3                               ; we don't need a RTS here because we highjack the RTS of
00112Er 3                               ; the word we're calling to get back to xt_execute
00112Er 3  6C rr rr                     jmp (ip)
001131r 3               
001131r 3               ; end of doexecute
001131r 3               
001131r 3               
001131r 3               ; ## EXECUTE_PARSING ( addr u xt -- ) "Pass a string to a parsing word"
001131r 3               ; ## "execute-parsing"  auto  Gforth
001131r 3                       ; """https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/The-Input-Stream.html
001131r 3                       ; Execute the parsing word defined by the execution token (xt) on the
001131r 3                       ; string as if it were passed on the command line. See the file
001131r 3                       ; tests/tali.fs for examples.
001131r 3                       ;
001131r 3                       ; Note that this word is coded completely
001131r 3                       ; different in its Gforth version, see the file execute-parsing.fs
001131r 3                       ; (in /usr/share/gforth/0.7.3/compat/ on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS) for details.
001131r 3                       ; """
001131r 3               xt_execute_parsing:
001131r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
001134r 3               
001134r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_input_to_r       ; save normal input for later
001137r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_not_rote         ; -ROT ( xt addr u )
00113Ar 3               
00113Ar 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x                 ; TOS is new ciblen
00113Cr 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen
00113Er 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
001140r 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen+1
001142r 3               
001142r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x                 ; NOS is new cib
001144r 3  85 rr                        sta cib
001146r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
001148r 3  85 rr                        sta cib+1
00114Ar 3               
00114Ar 3  64 rr                        stz toin                ; Set >IN to zero
00114Cr 3  64 rr                        stz toin+1
00114Er 3               
00114Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_two_drop         ; 2DROP ( xt )
001151r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_execute
001154r 3               
001154r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_r_to_input
001157r 3               
001157r 3               z_execute_parsing:
001157r 3  60                           rts
001158r 3               
001158r 3               
001158r 3               ; ## EXIT ( -- ) "Return control to the calling word immediately"
001158r 3               ; ## "exit"  auto  ANS core
001158r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/EXIT
001158r 3                       ; If we're in a loop, we need to UNLOOP first and get everything
001158r 3                       ; we we might have put on the Return Stack off as well. This should
001158r 3                       ; be natively compiled.
001158r 3                       ; """
001158r 3               
001158r 3               xt_exit:
001158r 3  60                           rts             ; keep before z_exit
001159r 3               z_exit:                         ; never reached
001159r 3               
001159r 3               
001159r 3               
001159r 3               ; ## FALSE ( -- f ) "Push flag FALSE to Data Stack"
001159r 3               ; ## "false"  auto  ANS core ext
001159r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/FALSE"""
001159r 3               xt_false:
001159r 3  CA                           dex
00115Ar 3  CA                           dex
00115Br 3  74 00                        stz 0,x
00115Dr 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
00115Fr 3               
00115Fr 3  60           z_false:        rts
001160r 3               
001160r 3               
001160r 3               ; ## FETCH ( addr -- n ) "Push cell content from memory to stack"
001160r 3               ; ## "@"  auto  ANS core
001160r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Fetch"""
001160r 3               xt_fetch:
001160r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
001163r 3               
001163r 3  A1 00                        lda (0,x)               ; LSB
001165r 3  A8                           tay
001166r 3  F6 00                        inc 0,x
001168r 3  D0 02                        bne @1
00116Ar 3  F6 01                        inc 1,x
00116Cr 3               @1:
00116Cr 3  A1 00                        lda (0,x)               ; MSB
00116Er 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
001170r 3  94 00                        sty 0,x
001172r 3               
001172r 3  60           z_fetch:        rts
001173r 3               
001173r 3               
001173r 3               ; ## FIND ( caddr -- addr 0 | xt 1 | xt -1 ) "Find word in Dictionary"
001173r 3               ; ## "find"  auto  ANS core
001173r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/FIND
001173r 3                       ; Included for backwards compatibility only, because it still
001173r 3                       ; can be found in so may examples. It should, however, be replaced
001173r 3                       ; by FIND-NAME. Counted string either returns address with a FALSE
001173r 3                       ; flag if not found in the Dictionary, or the xt with a flag to
001173r 3                       ; indicate if this is immediate or not. FIND is a wrapper around
001173r 3                       ; FIND-NAME, we get this all over with as quickly as possible. See
001173r 3                       ; https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/Word-Lists.html
001173r 3                       ; https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/Name-token.html
001173r 3                       ; """
001173r 3               
001173r 3               xt_find:
001173r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
001176r 3               
001176r 3                               ; Save address in case conversion fails. We use the
001176r 3                               ; Return Stack instead of temporary variables like TMP1
001176r 3                               ; because this is shorter and anybody still using FIND
001176r 3                               ; can't be worried about speed anyway
001176r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x                 ; MSB
001178r 3  48                           pha
001179r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x                 ; LSB
00117Br 3  48                           pha
00117Cr 3               
00117Cr 3                               ; Convert ancient-type counted string address to
00117Cr 3                               ; modern format
00117Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_count            ; ( caddr -- addr u )
00117Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_find_name        ; ( addr u -- nt | 0 )
001182r 3               
001182r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001184r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
001186r 3  D0 0B                        bne @found_word
001188r 3               
001188r 3                               ; No word found. Return address of the string and a false
001188r 3                               ; flag
001188r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_false            ; ( 0 0 )
00118Br 3               
00118Br 3                               ; The address needs to be restored.
00118Br 3  68                           pla                     ; LSB of address
00118Cr 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
00118Er 3  68                           pla
00118Fr 3  95 03                        sta 3,x                 ; MSB of address
001191r 3               
001191r 3  80 27                        bra @done               ; ( addr 0 )
001193r 3               
001193r 3               @found_word:
001193r 3                               ; We don't need the address after all, dump it
001193r 3  68                           pla
001194r 3  68                           pla
001195r 3               
001195r 3                               ; We arrive here with ( nt ) on the TOS. Now we have to
001195r 3                               ; convert the return values to FIND's format
001195r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dup              ; ( nt nt )
001198r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_name_to_int      ; ( nt xt )
00119Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_swap             ; ( xt nt )
00119Er 3               
00119Er 3  A0 00                        ldy #0                  ; Prepare flag
0011A0r 3               
0011A0r 3                               ; The flags are in the second byte of the header
0011A0r 3  F6 00                        inc 0,x
0011A2r 3  D0 02                        bne @1
0011A4r 3  F6 01                        inc 1,x                 ; ( xt nt+1 )
0011A6r 3               @1:
0011A6r 3  A1 00                        lda (0,x)               ; ( xt char )
0011A8r 3  29 04                        and #IM
0011AAr 3  D0 08                        bne @immediate          ; bit set, we're immediate
0011ACr 3               
0011ACr 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF                ; We're not immediate, return -1
0011AEr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0011B0r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0011B2r 3  80 06                        bra @done
0011B4r 3               
0011B4r 3               @immediate:
0011B4r 3  A9 01                        lda #1                  ; We're immediate, return 1
0011B6r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
0011B8r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
0011BAr 3               @done:
0011BAr 3  60           z_find:         rts
0011BBr 3               
0011BBr 3               
0011BBr 3               
0011BBr 3               ; ## FIND_NAME ( addr u -- nt|0 ) "Get the name token of input word"
0011BBr 3               ; ## "find-name"  auto  Gforth
0011BBr 3               
0011BBr 3               xt_find_name:
0011BBr 3                       ; """www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/Name-token.html
0011BBr 3                       ; Given a string, find the Name Token (nt) of a word or return
0011BBr 3                       ; zero if the word is not in the dictionary. We use this instead of
0011BBr 3                       ; ancient FIND to look up words in the Dictionary passed by
0011BBr 3                       ; PARSE-NAME. Note this returns the nt, not the xt of a word like
0011BBr 3                       ; FIND. To convert, use NAME>INT. This is a Gforth word. See
0011BBr 3                       ; https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/Name-token.html
0011BBr 3                       ; FIND calls this word
0011BBr 3                       ; """
0011BBr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
0011BEr 3               
0011BEr 3                               ; check for special case of an empty string (length zero)
0011BEr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0011C0r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
0011C2r 3  D0 03                        bne @nonempty
0011C4r 3               
0011C4r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @fail_done
0011C7r 3               
0011C7r 3               @nonempty:
0011C7r 3                               ; Set up for traversing the wordlist search order.
0011C7r 3  64 rr                        stz tmp3                ; Start at the beginning
0011C9r 3               
0011C9r 3               @wordlist_loop:
0011C9r 3  A0 1E                        ldy #num_order_offset   ; Compare to byte variable #ORDER
0011CBr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp3
0011CDr 3  D1 rr                        cmp (up),y              ; Check to see if we are done
0011CFr 3  D0 03                        bne @have_string
0011D1r 3               
0011D1r 3                               ; We ran out of wordlists to search.
0011D1r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @fail_done
0011D4r 3               
0011D4r 3               @have_string:
0011D4r 3                               ; set up first loop iteration
0011D4r 3               
0011D4r 3                               ; Get the current wordlist id
0011D4r 3  18                           clc             ; SEARCH-ORDER is array of bytes.
0011D5r 3  69 1F                        adc #search_order_offset
0011D7r 3  A8                           tay
0011D8r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y      ; Get the id byte, which is the offset
0011DAr 3                                               ; into the cell array WORDLISTS
0011DAr 3               
0011DAr 3                               ; Get the DP for that wordlist.
0011DAr 3  0A                           asl                     ; Turn offset into cells offset.
0011DBr 3  18                           clc
0011DCr 3  69 06                        adc #wordlists_offset
0011DEr 3  A8                           tay
0011DFr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0011E1r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
0011E3r 3  C8                           iny
0011E4r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0011E6r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
0011E8r 3               
0011E8r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x                 ; Address of mystery string
0011EAr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
0011ECr 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
0011EEr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
0011F0r 3               
0011F0r 3               @loop:
0011F0r 3                               ; first quick test: Are strings the same length?
0011F0r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
0011F2r 3  D5 00                        cmp 0,x
0011F4r 3  D0 54                        bne @next_entry
0011F6r 3               
0011F6r 3               @compare_string:
0011F6r 3                               ; are the same length, so we now have to compare each
0011F6r 3                               ; character
0011F6r 3               
0011F6r 3                               ; second quick test: Is the first character the same?
0011F6r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp2)      ; first character of mystery string
0011F8r 3               
0011F8r 3                               ; Lowercase the incoming charcter.
0011F8r 3  C9 5B                        cmp #$5B        ; ASCII '[' (one past Z)
0011FAr 3  B0 07                        bcs @compare_first
0011FCr 3  C9 41                        cmp #$41        ; ASCII 'A'
0011FEr 3  90 03                        bcc @compare_first
001200r 3               
001200r 3                               ; An uppercase letter has been located.  Make it
001200r 3                               ; lowercase.
001200r 3  18                           clc
001201r 3  69 20                        adc #$20
001203r 3               
001203r 3               @compare_first:
001203r 3  A0 08                        ldy #8          ; Offset in nt to name
001205r 3  D1 rr                        cmp (tmp1),y    ; first character of current word
001207r 3  D0 41                        bne @next_entry
001209r 3               
001209r 3                               ; String length is the same and the first character is the
001209r 3                               ; same. If the length of the string is 1, we're already done
001209r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
00120Br 3  3A                           dec
00120Cr 3  F0 2C                        beq @success
00120Er 3               
00120Er 3                               ; No such luck: The strings are the same length and the first
00120Er 3                               ; char is the same, but the word is more than one char long.
00120Er 3                               ; So we suck it up and compare every single character. We go
00120Er 3                               ; from back to front, because words like CELLS and CELL+ would
00120Er 3                               ; take longer otherwise. We can also shorten the loop by one
00120Er 3                               ; because we've already compared the first char.
00120Er 3               
00120Er 3                               ; The string of the word we're testing against is 8 bytes down
00120Er 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1
001210r 3  48                           pha             ; Preserve tmp1 on the return stack.
001211r 3  18                           clc
001212r 3  69 08                        adc #8
001214r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1        ; Reusing tmp1 temporarily for string check.
001216r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1+1
001218r 3  48                           pha             ; Preserve tmp1+1 on the return stack.
001219r 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; we only need the carry
00121Br 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
00121Dr 3               
00121Dr 3  B4 00                        ldy 0,x         ; index is length of string minus 1
00121Fr 3  88                           dey
001220r 3               
001220r 3               @string_loop:
001220r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp2),y    ; last char of mystery string
001222r 3               
001222r 3                               ; Lowercase the incoming charcter.
001222r 3  C9 5B                        cmp #$5B         ; ASCII '[' (one past Z)
001224r 3  B0 07                        bcs @check_char
001226r 3  C9 41                        cmp #$41        ; ASCII 'A'
001228r 3  90 03                        bcc @check_char
00122Ar 3               
00122Ar 3                               ; An uppercase letter has been located.  Make it
00122Ar 3                               ; lowercase.
00122Ar 3  18                           clc
00122Br 3  69 20                        adc #$20
00122Dr 3               
00122Dr 3               @check_char:
00122Dr 3  D1 rr                        cmp (tmp1),y    ; last char of word we're testing against
00122Fr 3  D0 13                        bne @next_entry_tmp1
001231r 3               
001231r 3  88                           dey
001232r 3  D0 EC                        bne @string_loop
001234r 3               
001234r 3               @success_tmp1:
001234r 3  68                           pla             ; Restore tmp1 from the return stack.
001235r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001237r 3  68                           pla
001238r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
00123Ar 3               
00123Ar 3               @success:
00123Ar 3                               ; The strings match. Put correct nt NOS, because we'll drop
00123Ar 3                               ; TOS before we leave
00123Ar 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1
00123Cr 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
00123Er 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1+1
001240r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
001242r 3               
001242r 3  80 20                        bra @done
001244r 3               
001244r 3               @next_entry_tmp1:
001244r 3  68                           pla             ; Restore tmp1 from the return stack.
001245r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001247r 3  68                           pla
001248r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
00124Ar 3               
00124Ar 3               @next_entry:
00124Ar 3                               ; Not the same, so we get the next word. Next header
00124Ar 3                               ; address is two bytes down
00124Ar 3  A0 02                        ldy #2
00124Cr 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
00124Er 3  48                           pha
00124Fr 3  C8                           iny
001250r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
001252r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001254r 3  68                           pla
001255r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001257r 3               
001257r 3                               ; If we got a zero, we've walked the whole Dictionary and
001257r 3                               ; return as a failure, otherwise try again
001257r 3  05 rr                        ora tmp1+1
001259r 3  D0 95                        bne @loop
00125Br 3               
00125Br 3                               ; Move on to the next wordlist in the search order.
00125Br 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp3
00125Dr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @wordlist_loop
001260r 3               
001260r 3               @fail_done:
001260r 3  74 02                        stz 2,x         ; failure flag
001262r 3  74 03                        stz 3,x
001264r 3               @done:
001264r 3  E8                           inx
001265r 3  E8                           inx
001266r 3               
001266r 3  60           z_find_name:    rts
001267r 3               
001267r 3               
001267r 3               
001267r 3               ; ## FLUSH ( -- ) "Save dirty buffers and empty buffers"
001267r 3               ; ## "flush"  auto  ANS block
001267r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/FLUSH"""
001267r 3               xt_flush:
001267r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_save_buffers
00126Ar 3               
00126Ar 3                               ; Set the buffer status to empty.
00126Ar 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
00126Cr 3  A9 00                        lda #0
00126Er 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y      ; Only LSB is used.
001270r 3               z_flush:
001270r 3  60                           rts
001271r 3               
001271r 3               
001271r 3               ; ## FM_SLASH_MOD ( d n1  -- rem n2 ) "Floored signed division"
001271r 3               ; ## "fm/mod"  auto  ANS core
001271r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/FMDivMOD
001271r 3                       ; Note that by default, Tali Forth uses SM/REM for most things.
001271r 3                       ;
001271r 3                       ; There are various ways to realize this. We follow EForth with
001271r 3                       ;    DUP 0< DUP >R  IF NEGATE >R DNEGATE R> THEN >R DUP
001271r 3                       ;    0<  IF R@ + THEN  R> UM/MOD R> IF SWAP NEGATE SWAP THEN
001271r 3                       ; See (http://www.forth.org/eforth.html). However you can also
001271r 3                       ; go FM/MOD via SM/REM (http://www.figuk.plus.com/build/arith.htm):
001271r 3                       ;     DUP >R  SM/REM DUP 0< IF SWAP R> + SWAP 1+ ELSE  R> DROP THEN
001271r 3                       ; """
001271r 3               
001271r 3               xt_fm_slash_mod:
001271r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
001274r 3               
001274r 3                               ; if sign of n1 is negative, negate both n1 and d
001274r 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2        ; default: n is positive
001276r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x         ; MSB of n1
001278r 3  10 0E                        bpl @check_d
00127Ar 3               
00127Ar 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2        ; set flag to negative for n1
00127Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_negate   ; NEGATE
00127Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_to_r     ; >R
001282r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dnegate  ; DNEGATE
001285r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_r_from   ; R>
001288r 3               
001288r 3               @check_d:
001288r 3                               ; If d is negative, add n1 to high cell of d
001288r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x         ; MSB of high word of d
00128Ar 3  10 0D                        bpl @multiply
00128Cr 3               
00128Cr 3  18                           clc
00128Dr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x         ; LSB of n1
00128Fr 3  75 02                        adc 2,x         ; LSB of dh
001291r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
001293r 3               
001293r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x         ; MSB of n1
001295r 3  75 03                        adc 3,x         ; MSB of dh
001297r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
001299r 3               
001299r 3               @multiply:
001299r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_um_slash_mod     ; ( d n1 -- rem n2 )
00129Cr 3               
00129Cr 3                               ; if n was negative, negate the result
00129Cr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2
00129Er 3  F0 07                        beq @done
0012A0r 3               
0012A0r 3  E8                           inx             ; pretend that we SWAP
0012A1r 3  E8                           inx
0012A2r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_negate
0012A5r 3  CA                           dex
0012A6r 3  CA                           dex
0012A7r 3               @done:
0012A7r 3  60           z_fm_slash_mod: rts
0012A8r 3               
0012A8r 3               
0012A8r 3               
0012A8r 3               ; ## FORTH ( -- ) "Replace first WID in search order with Forth-Wordlist"
0012A8r 3               ; ## "forth"  auto  ANS search ext
0012A8r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/FORTH"""
0012A8r 3               xt_forth:
0012A8r 3  A0 1F                        ldy #search_order_offset
0012AAr 3  A9 00                        lda #0          ; The WID for Forth is 0.
0012ACr 3               
0012ACr 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0012AEr 3               z_forth:
0012AEr 3  60                           rts
0012AFr 3               
0012AFr 3               
0012AFr 3               ; This is a special jsr target to skip the zeroing of BLK at the beginning
0012AFr 3               ; of evaluate.  It's used by LOAD to allow setting BLK while the block is
0012AFr 3               ; being evaluated.  Evaluate's normal behavior is to zero BLK.
0012AFr 3               load_evaluate:
0012AFr 3                               ; Set a flag (using tmp1) to not zero BLK
0012AFr 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF
0012B1r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
0012B3r 3  80 11                        bra load_evaluate_start
0012B5r 3               
0012B5r 3               ; ## EVALUATE ( addr u -- ) "Execute a string"
0012B5r 3               ; ## "evaluate"  auto  ANS core
0012B5r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/EVALUATE
0012B5r 3                       ; Set SOURCE-ID to -1, make addr u the input source, set >IN to zero.
0012B5r 3                       ; After processing the line, revert to old input source. We use this
0012B5r 3                       ; to compile high-level Forth words and user-defined words during
0012B5r 3                       ; start up and cold boot. In contrast to ACCEPT, we need to, uh,
0012B5r 3                       ; accept more than 255 characters here, even though it's a pain in
0012B5r 3                       ; the 8-bit.
0012B5r 3                       ; """
0012B5r 3               
0012B5r 3               xt_evaluate:
0012B5r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
0012B8r 3               
0012B8r 3                               ; Clear the flag to zero BLK.  Only LOAD will set the flag,
0012B8r 3                               ; and will set the block number.
0012B8r 3  64 rr                        stz tmp1
0012BAr 3               
0012BAr 3                               ; If u is zero (which can happen a lot for the user-defined
0012BAr 3                               ; words), just leave again
0012BAr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0012BCr 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
0012BEr 3  D0 06                        bne _eval_got_work
0012C0r 3               
0012C0r 3  E8                           inx
0012C1r 3  E8                           inx
0012C2r 3  E8                           inx
0012C3r 3  E8                           inx
0012C4r 3               
0012C4r 3  80 42                        bra _eval_done
0012C6r 3               
0012C6r 3               ; Special entry point for LOAD to bypass the zeroing of BLK.
0012C6r 3               load_evaluate_start:
0012C6r 3               _eval_got_work:
0012C6r 3                               ; Save the current value of BLK on the return stack.
0012C6r 3  A0 01                        ldy #blk_offset+1
0012C8r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0012CAr 3  48                           pha
0012CBr 3  88                           dey
0012CCr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
0012CEr 3  48                           pha
0012CFr 3               
0012CFr 3                               ; See if we should zero BLK.
0012CFr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1
0012D1r 3  D0 05                        bne @nozero
0012D3r 3               
0012D3r 3                               ; Set BLK to zero.
0012D3r 3                               ; lda #0        ; A is already zero from loading tmp1
0012D3r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0012D5r 3  C8                           iny
0012D6r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
0012D8r 3               
0012D8r 3               @nozero:
0012D8r 3                               ; Save the input state to the Return Stack
0012D8r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_input_to_r
0012DBr 3               
0012DBr 3                               ; set SOURCE-ID to -1
0012DBr 3  A9 FF                        lda #$ff
0012DDr 3  85 rr                        sta insrc
0012DFr 3  85 rr                        sta insrc+1
0012E1r 3               
0012E1r 3                               ; set >IN to zero
0012E1r 3  64 rr                        stz toin
0012E3r 3  64 rr                        stz toin+1
0012E5r 3               
0012E5r 3                               ; move TOS and NOS to input buffers
0012E5r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0012E7r 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen
0012E9r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
0012EBr 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen+1
0012EDr 3               
0012EDr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
0012EFr 3  85 rr                        sta cib
0012F1r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
0012F3r 3  85 rr                        sta cib+1
0012F5r 3               
0012F5r 3  E8                           inx             ; A clean stack is a clean mind
0012F6r 3  E8                           inx
0012F7r 3  E8                           inx
0012F8r 3  E8                           inx
0012F9r 3               
0012F9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr interpret   ; ( -- )
0012FCr 3               
0012FCr 3                               ; restore variables
0012FCr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_r_to_input
0012FFr 3               
0012FFr 3                               ; Restore BLK from the return stack.
0012FFr 3  A0 00                        ldy #blk_offset
001301r 3  68                           pla
001302r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
001304r 3  C8                           iny
001305r 3  68                           pla
001306r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
001308r 3               
001308r 3               _eval_done:
001308r 3  60           z_evaluate:     rts
001309r 3               
001309r 3               
001309r 3               
001309r 3               ; ## FORTH_WORDLIST ( -- u ) "WID for the Forth Wordlist"
001309r 3               ; ## "forth-wordlist"  auto  ANS search
001309r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/FORTH-WORDLIST"""
001309r 3                       ; This is a dummy entry, the actual code is shared with ZERO.
001309r 3               
001309r 3               
001309r 3               ; ## GET_CURRENT ( -- wid ) "Get the id of the compilation wordlist"
001309r 3               ; ## "get-current" auto ANS search
001309r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/GET-CURRENT"""
001309r 3               
001309r 3               xt_get_current:
001309r 3                               ; This is a little different than some of the variables
001309r 3                               ; in the user area as we want the value rather than
001309r 3                               ; the address.
001309r 3  CA                           dex
00130Ar 3  CA                           dex
00130Br 3  A0 04                        ldy #current_offset
00130Dr 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
00130Fr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x         ; CURRENT is a byte variable
001311r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x         ; so the MSB is zero.
001313r 3               
001313r 3  60           z_get_current:  rts
001314r 3               
001314r 3               
001314r 3               
001314r 3               ; ## GET_ORDER ( -- wid_n .. wid_1 n) "Get the current search order"
001314r 3               ; ## "get-order" auto ANS search
001314r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/GET-ORDER"""
001314r 3               
001314r 3               xt_get_order:
001314r 3                               ; Get #ORDER - the number of wordlists in the search order.
001314r 3  A0 1E                        ldy #num_order_offset
001316r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
001318r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
00131Ar 3  F0 16                        beq @done       ; If zero, there are no wordlists.
00131Cr 3               
00131Cr 3               @loop:
00131Cr 3                               ; Count down towards the front of the list.
00131Cr 3                               ; By decrementing first, we also turn the length into an offset.
00131Cr 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp1        ; Count down by bytes.
00131Er 3               
00131Er 3                               ; Get a pointer to the current wordlist, working back to front.
00131Er 3  A9 1F                        lda #search_order_offset
001320r 3  18                           clc
001321r 3  65 rr                        adc tmp1
001323r 3  A8                           tay
001324r 3               
001324r 3                               ; Put that wordlist id on the stack.
001324r 3  CA                           dex
001325r 3  CA                           dex
001326r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y
