001C2Dr 3                       ; This word may not be natively compiled
001C2Dr 3                       ; """
001C2Dr 3               
001C2Dr 3               xt_recurse:
001C2Dr 3                               ; The whole routine amounts to compiling a reference to
001C2Dr 3                               ; the word that is being compiled. First, we save the JSR
001C2Dr 3                               ; instruction
001C2Dr 3  A0 00                        ldy #0
001C2Fr 3               
001C2Fr 3  A9 20                        lda #$20        ; opcode for JSR
001C31r 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
001C33r 3  C8                           iny
001C34r 3               
001C34r 3                               ; Next, we save the LSB and MSB of the xt of the word
001C34r 3                               ; we are currently working on. We first need to see if
001C34r 3                               ; WORKWORD has the nt (: started the word) or the
001C34r 3                               ; xt (:NONAME started the word). Bit 6 in status tells us.
001C34r 3  24 rr                        bit status
001C36r 3  70 0C                        bvs @nt_in_workword
001C38r 3               
001C38r 3                               ; This is a special :NONAME word. Just copy the xt
001C38r 3                               ; from WORKWORD into the dictionary.
001C38r 3  A5 rr                        lda workword
001C3Ar 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
001C3Cr 3  C8                           iny
001C3Dr 3  A5 rr                        lda workword+1
001C3Fr 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
001C41r 3  C8                           iny
001C42r 3  80 1B                        bra @update_cp
001C44r 3               
001C44r 3               @nt_in_workword:
001C44r 3                               ; This is a regular : word, so the xt is four bytes down
001C44r 3                               ; from the nt which we saved in WORKWORD. We could probably
001C44r 3                               ; use NAME>INT here but this is going to be faster, and
001C44r 3                               ; fast counts with recursion
001C44r 3  A5 rr                        lda workword            ; LSB
001C46r 3  18                           clc
001C47r 3  69 04                        adc #4
001C49r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001C4Br 3  A5 rr                        lda workword+1          ; MSB
001C4Dr 3  69 00                        adc #0
001C4Fr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001C51r 3               
001C51r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
001C53r 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
001C55r 3  5A                           phy
001C56r 3  A0 01                        ldy #1
001C58r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
001C5Ar 3  7A                           ply
001C5Br 3  C8                           iny
001C5Cr 3  91 rr                        sta (cp),y
001C5Er 3  C8                           iny
001C5Fr 3               
001C5Fr 3               @update_cp:
001C5Fr 3  98                           tya
001C60r 3  18                           clc
001C61r 3  65 rr                        adc cp
001C63r 3  85 rr                        sta cp
001C65r 3  90 02                        bcc @done
001C67r 3  E6 rr                        inc cp+1
001C69r 3               @done:
001C69r 3  60           z_recurse:      rts
001C6Ar 3               
001C6Ar 3               
001C6Ar 3               
001C6Ar 3               ; ## REFILL ( -- f ) "Refill the input buffer"
001C6Ar 3               ; ## "refill"  tested  ANS core ext
001C6Ar 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/REFILL
001C6Ar 3                       ; Attempt to fill the input buffer from the input source, returning
001C6Ar 3                       ; a true flag if successful. When the input source is the user input
001C6Ar 3                       ; device, attempt to receive input into the terminal input buffer. If
001C6Ar 3                       ; successful, make the result the input buffer, set >IN to zero, and
001C6Ar 3                       ; return true. Receipt of a line containing no characters is considered
001C6Ar 3                       ; successful. If there is no input available from the current input
001C6Ar 3                       ; source, return false. When the input source is a string from EVALUATE,
001C6Ar 3                       ; return false and perform no other action." See
001C6Ar 3                       ; https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/forth/gforth/Docs-html/The-Input-Stream.html
001C6Ar 3                       ; and Conklin & Rather p. 156. Note we don't have to care about blocks
001C6Ar 3                       ; because REFILL is never used on blocks - Tali is able to evaluate the
001C6Ar 3                       ; entire block as a 1024 byte string.
001C6Ar 3                       ; """"
001C6Ar 3               
001C6Ar 3               xt_refill:
001C6Ar 3                               ; Get input source from SOURCE-ID. This is an
001C6Ar 3                               ; optimized version of a subroutine jump to SOURCE-ID
001C6Ar 3  A5 rr                        lda insrc               ; cheat: We only check LSB
001C6Cr 3  D0 2D                        bne @src_not_kbd
001C6Er 3               
001C6Er 3                               ; SOURCE-ID of zero means we're getting stuff from the keyboard
001C6Er 3                               ; with ACCEPT, which wants the address of the current input
001C6Er 3                               ; buffer NOS and the max number of characters to accept TOS
001C6Er 3  CA                           dex
001C6Fr 3  CA                           dex
001C70r 3  CA                           dex
001C71r 3  CA                           dex
001C72r 3               
001C72r 3  A5 rr                        lda cib                 ; address of CIB is NOS
001C74r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
001C76r 3  A5 rr                        lda cib+1
001C78r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
001C7Ar 3               
001C7Ar 3  64 rr                        stz ciblen              ; go in with empty buffer
001C7Cr 3  64 rr                        stz ciblen+1
001C7Er 3               
001C7Er 3  A9 FF                        lda #bsize              ; max number of chars is TOS
001C80r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001C82r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x                 ; cheat: We only accept max 255
001C84r 3               
001C84r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_accept           ; ( addr n1 -- n2)
001C87r 3               
001C87r 3                               ; ACCEPT returns the number of characters accepted, which
001C87r 3                               ; belong in CIBLEN
001C87r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001C89r 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen
001C8Br 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
001C8Dr 3  85 rr                        sta ciblen+1            ; though we only accept 255 chars
001C8Fr 3               
001C8Fr 3                               ; make >IN point to beginning of buffer
001C8Fr 3  64 rr                        stz toin
001C91r 3  64 rr                        stz toin+1
001C93r 3               
001C93r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF                ; overwrite with TRUE flag
001C95r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001C97r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
001C99r 3               
001C99r 3  80 10                        bra @done
001C9Br 3               
001C9Br 3               @src_not_kbd:
001C9Br 3                               ; If SOURCE-ID doesn't return a zero, it must be a string in
001C9Br 3                               ; memory or a file (remember, no blocks in this version).
001C9Br 3                               ; If source is a string, we were given the flag -1 ($FFFF)
001C9Br 3  1A                           inc
001C9Cr 3  D0 08                        bne @src_not_string
001C9Er 3               
001C9Er 3                               ; Simply return FALSE flag as per specification
001C9Er 3  CA                           dex
001C9Fr 3  CA                           dex
001CA0r 3  74 00                        stz 0,x
001CA2r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
001CA4r 3               
001CA4r 3  80 05                        bra z_refill
001CA6r 3               
001CA6r 3               @src_not_string:
001CA6r 3                               ; Since we don't have blocks, this must mean that we are trying
001CA6r 3                               ; to read from a file. However, we don't have files yet, so we
001CA6r 3                               ; report an error and jump to ABORT.
001CA6r 3  A9 01                        lda #err_badsource
001CA8r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
001CABr 3               @done:
001CABr 3  60           z_refill:       rts
001CACr 3               
001CACr 3               
001CACr 3               
001CACr 3               ; ## REPEAT (C: orig dest -- ) ( -- ) "Loop flow control"
001CACr 3               ; ## "repeat"  auto  ANS core
001CACr 3                       ; """http://forth-standard.org/standard/core/REPEAT"""
001CACr 3               
001CACr 3               xt_repeat:
001CACr 3                               ; Run again first
001CACr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_again
001CAFr 3               
001CAFr 3                               ; Stuff HERE in for the branch address
001CAFr 3                               ; to get out of the loop
001CAFr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_here
001CB2r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_swap
001CB5r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_store
001CB8r 3               
001CB8r 3  60           z_repeat:       rts
001CB9r 3               
001CB9r 3               
001CB9r 3               
001CB9r 3               ; ## RIGHT_BRACKET ( -- ) "Enter the compile state"
001CB9r 3               ; ## "]"  auto  ANS core
001CB9r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/right-bracket
001CB9r 3                       ; This is an immediate word.
001CB9r 3                       ; """
001CB9r 3               xt_right_bracket:
001CB9r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF
001CBBr 3  85 rr                        sta state
001CBDr 3  85 rr                        sta state+1
001CBFr 3               z_right_bracket:
001CBFr 3  60                           rts
001CC0r 3               
001CC0r 3               
001CC0r 3               ; ## ROOT_WORDLIST ( -- u ) "WID for the Root (minimal) wordlist"
001CC0r 3               ; ## "root-wordlist"  tested  Tali Editor
001CC0r 3               xt_root_wordlist:
001CC0r 3  CA                           dex             ; The WID for the Root wordlist is 3.
001CC1r 3  CA                           dex
001CC2r 3  A9 03                        lda #3
001CC4r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001CC6r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
001CC8r 3               
001CC8r 3               z_root_wordlist:
001CC8r 3  60                           rts
001CC9r 3               
001CC9r 3               
001CC9r 3               ; ## ROT ( a b c -- b c a ) "Rotate first three stack entries downwards"
001CC9r 3               ; ## "rot"  auto  ANS core
001CC9r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/ROT
001CC9r 3                       ; Remember "R for 'Revolution'" - the bottom entry comes out
001CC9r 3                       ; on top!
001CC9r 3                       ; """
001CC9r 3               
001CC9r 3               xt_rot:
001CC9r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
001CCCr 3               
001CCCr 3  B4 05                        ldy 5,x         ; MSB first
001CCEr 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
001CD0r 3  95 05                        sta 5,x
001CD2r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
001CD4r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
001CD6r 3  94 01                        sty 1,x
001CD8r 3               
001CD8r 3  B4 04                        ldy 4,x         ; LSB next
001CDAr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
001CDCr 3  95 04                        sta 4,x
001CDEr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001CE0r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
001CE2r 3  94 00                        sty 0,x
001CE4r 3               
001CE4r 3  60           z_rot:          rts
001CE5r 3               
001CE5r 3               
001CE5r 3               
001CE5r 3               ; ## RSHIFT ( x u -- x ) "Shift TOS to the right"
001CE5r 3               ; ## "rshift"  auto  ANS core
001CE5r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/RSHIFT"""
001CE5r 3               xt_rshift:
001CE5r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_2
001CE8r 3               
001CE8r 3                               ; We shift maximal by 16 bits, mask everything else
001CE8r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001CEAr 3  29 0F                        and #%00001111
001CECr 3  F0 08                        beq @done               ; if 0 shifts, quit
001CEEr 3               
001CEEr 3  A8                           tay
001CEFr 3               @loop:
001CEFr 3  56 03                        lsr 3,x
001CF1r 3  76 02                        ror 2,x
001CF3r 3  88                           dey
001CF4r 3  D0 F9                        bne @loop
001CF6r 3               @done:
001CF6r 3  E8                           inx
001CF7r 3  E8                           inx
001CF8r 3               
001CF8r 3  60           z_rshift:       rts
001CF9r 3               
001CF9r 3               
001CF9r 3               ; ## S_BACKSLASH_QUOTE ( "string" -- )( -- addr u ) "Store string in memory"
001CF9r 3               ; ## "s\""  auto  ANS core
001CF9r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Seq
001CF9r 3                       ; Store address and length of string given, returning ( addr u ).
001CF9r 3                       ; ANS core claims this is compile-only, but the file set expands it
001CF9r 3                       ; to be interpreted, so it is a state-sensitive word, which in theory
001CF9r 3                       ; are evil. We follow general usage. This is just like S" except
001CF9r 3                       ; that it allows for some special escaped characters.
001CF9r 3                       ; """
001CF9r 3               
001CF9r 3               xt_s_backslash_quote:
001CF9r 3                               ; tmp2 will be used to determine if we are handling
001CF9r 3                               ; escaped characters or not. In this case, we are,
001CF9r 3                               ; so set it to $FF (the upper byte will be used to
001CF9r 3                               ; determine if we just had a \ and the next character
001CF9r 3                               ; needs to be modifed as an escaped character).
001CF9r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF
001CFBr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
001CFDr 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2+1
001CFFr 3               
001CFFr 3                               ; Now that the flag is set, jump into s_quote to process
001CFFr 3                               ; the string.
001CFFr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr s_quote_start
001D02r 3               @done:
001D02r 3               z_s_backslash_quote:
001D02r 3  60                           rts
001D03r 3               
001D03r 3               
001D03r 3               ; This is a helper function for s_backslash_quote to convert a character
001D03r 3               ; from ASCII to the corresponding hex value, eg 'F'->15
001D03r 3               convert_hex_value:
001D03r 3               
001D03r 3  C9 41                cmp #'A'
001D05r 3  90 07                bcc @digit
001D07r 3               
001D07r 3                       ; It's A-F
001D07r 3  29 DF                and #$DF                ; Make it uppercase.
001D09r 3  38                   sec
001D0Ar 3  E9 37                sbc #'7'                 ; gives value 10 for 'A'
001D0Cr 3  80 03                bra @done
001D0Er 3               
001D0Er 3               @digit:
001D0Er 3                       ; It's 0-9
001D0Er 3  38                   sec
001D0Fr 3  E9 30                sbc #'0'
001D11r 3               
001D11r 3               @done:
001D11r 3  60                   rts
001D12r 3               
001D12r 3               
001D12r 3               
001D12r 3               ; ## SEARCH_WORDLIST ( caddr u wid -- 0 | xt 1 | xt -1) "Search for a word in a wordlist"
001D12r 3               ; ## "search-wordlist" auto ANS search
001D12r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/SEARCH_WORDLIST"""
001D12r 3               
001D12r 3               xt_search_wordlist:
001D12r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_3
001D15r 3               
001D15r 3                               ; Set up tmp1 with the wordlist indicated by wid
001D15r 3                               ; on the stack. Start by putting the base address
001D15r 3                               ; of the wordlists in tmp2.
001D15r 3  A5 rr                        lda up
001D17r 3  18                           clc
001D18r 3  69 06                        adc #wordlists_offset
001D1Ar 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
001D1Cr 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
001D1Er 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; Adding carry
001D20r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
001D22r 3               
001D22r 3                               ; Add the wid (in cells) to the base address.
001D22r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001D24r 3  0A                           asl             ; Convert wid to offset in cells (x2)
001D25r 3  65 rr                        adc tmp2
001D27r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
001D29r 3  90 02                        bcc @1
001D2Br 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2+1      ; Propagate carry if needed.
001D2Dr 3               
001D2Dr 3                               ; tmp2 now holds the address of the dictionary pointer
001D2Dr 3                               ; for the given wordlist.
001D2Dr 3               @1:
001D2Dr 3                               ; Remove the wid from the stack.
001D2Dr 3  E8                           inx
001D2Er 3  E8                           inx
001D2Fr 3               
001D2Fr 3                               ; check for special case of an empty string (length zero)
001D2Fr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001D31r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
001D33r 3  D0 03                        bne @check_wordlist
001D35r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @done
001D38r 3               
001D38r 3               @check_wordlist:
001D38r 3                               ; Check for special case of empty wordlist
001D38r 3                               ; (dictionary pointer, in tmp2, is 0)
001D38r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2
001D3Ar 3  05 rr                        ora tmp2+1
001D3Cr 3  D0 03                        bne @have_string
001D3Er 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @done
001D41r 3               
001D41r 3               @have_string:
001D41r 3                               ; set up first loop iteration
001D41r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp2)              ; nt of first word in Dictionary
001D43r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001D45r 3               
001D45r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2                ; Move to the upper byte
001D47r 3  D0 02                        bne @2
001D49r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2+1
001D4Br 3               @2:
001D4Br 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp2)
001D4Dr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001D4Fr 3               
001D4Fr 3                               ; Reuse tmp2 to hold the address of the mystery string.
001D4Fr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x                 ; Address of mystery string
001D51r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
001D53r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
001D55r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
001D57r 3               
001D57r 3               @loop:
001D57r 3                               ; first quick test: Are strings the same length?
001D57r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
001D59r 3  D5 00                        cmp 0,x
001D5Br 3  D0 7B                        bne @next_entry
001D5Dr 3               
001D5Dr 3               @compare_string:
001D5Dr 3                               ; are the same length, so we now have to compare each
001D5Dr 3                               ; character
001D5Dr 3               
001D5Dr 3                               ; second quick test: Is the first character the same?
001D5Dr 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp2)      ; first character of mystery string
001D5Fr 3               
001D5Fr 3                               ; Lowercase the incoming charcter.
001D5Fr 3  C9 5B                        cmp #$5B        ; ASCII '[' (one past Z)
001D61r 3  B0 07                        bcs @compare_first
001D63r 3  C9 41                        cmp #$41        ; ASCII 'A'
001D65r 3  90 03                        bcc @compare_first
001D67r 3               
001D67r 3                               ; An uppercase letter has been located.  Make it
001D67r 3                               ; lowercase.
001D67r 3  18                           clc
001D68r 3  69 20                        adc #$20
001D6Ar 3               
001D6Ar 3               @compare_first:
001D6Ar 3  A0 08                        ldy #8          ; Offset in nt to name
001D6Cr 3  D1 rr                        cmp (tmp1),y    ; first character of current word
001D6Er 3  D0 68                        bne @next_entry
001D70r 3               
001D70r 3                               ; string length are the same and the first character is the
001D70r 3                               ; same. If the length of the string is 1, we're already done
001D70r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001D72r 3  3A                           dec
001D73r 3  F0 2C                        beq @success
001D75r 3               
001D75r 3                               ; No such luck: The strings are the same length and the first
001D75r 3                               ; char is the same, but the word is more than one char long.
001D75r 3                               ; So we suck it up and compare every single character. We go
001D75r 3                               ; from back to front, because words like CELLS and CELL+ would
001D75r 3                               ; take longer otherwise. We can also shorten the loop by one
001D75r 3                               ; because we've already compared the first char.
001D75r 3               
001D75r 3                               ; The string of the word we're testing against is 8 bytes down
001D75r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1
001D77r 3  48                           pha             ; Preserve tmp1 on the return stack.
001D78r 3  18                           clc
001D79r 3  69 08                        adc #8
001D7Br 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1        ; Reusing tmp1 temporarily for string check.
001D7Dr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1+1
001D7Fr 3  48                           pha             ; Preserve tmp1+1 on the return stack.
001D80r 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; we only need the carry
001D82r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001D84r 3               
001D84r 3  B4 00                        ldy 0,x         ; index is length of string minus 1
001D86r 3  88                           dey
001D87r 3               
001D87r 3               @string_loop:
001D87r 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp2),y    ; last char of mystery string
001D89r 3               
001D89r 3                               ; Lowercase the incoming charcter.
001D89r 3  C9 5B                        cmp #$5B         ; ASCII '[' (one past Z)
001D8Br 3  B0 07                        bcs @check_char
001D8Dr 3  C9 41                        cmp #$41        ; ASCII 'A'
001D8Fr 3  90 03                        bcc @check_char
001D91r 3               
001D91r 3                               ; An uppercase letter has been located.  Make it
001D91r 3                               ; lowercase.
001D91r 3  18                           clc
001D92r 3  69 20                        adc #$20
001D94r 3               @check_char:
001D94r 3  D1 rr                        cmp (tmp1),y    ; last char of word we're testing against
001D96r 3  D0 3A                        bne @next_entry_tmp1
001D98r 3               
001D98r 3  88                           dey
001D99r 3  D0 EC                        bne @string_loop
001D9Br 3               
001D9Br 3               @success_tmp1:
001D9Br 3  68                           pla             ; Restore tmp1 from the return stack.
001D9Cr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001D9Er 3  68                           pla
001D9Fr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001DA1r 3               
001DA1r 3               @success:
001DA1r 3                               ; The strings match. Drop the count and put correct nt TOS
001DA1r 3  E8                           inx
001DA2r 3  E8                           inx
001DA3r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1
001DA5r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001DA7r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1+1
001DA9r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
001DABr 3               
001DABr 3                               ; Change the nt into an xt, but save a copy of the nt
001DABr 3                               ; to look up whether the word is immediate or not.
001DABr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dup              ; ( nt nt )
001DAEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_name_to_int      ; ( nt xt )
001DB1r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_swap             ; ( xt nt )
001DB4r 3               
001DB4r 3  A0 00                        ldy #0                  ; Prepare flag
001DB6r 3               
001DB6r 3                               ; The flags are in the second byte of the header
001DB6r 3  F6 00                        inc 0,x
001DB8r 3  D0 02                        bne @3
001DBAr 3  F6 01                        inc 1,x                 ; ( xt nt+1 )
001DBCr 3               @3:
001DBCr 3  A1 00                        lda (0,x)               ; ( xt char )
001DBEr 3  29 04                        and #IM
001DC0r 3  D0 08                        bne @immediate          ; bit set, we're immediate
001DC2r 3               
001DC2r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF                ; We're not immediate, return -1
001DC4r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001DC6r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
001DC8r 3  80 28                        bra @done_nodrop
001DCAr 3               
001DCAr 3               @immediate:
001DCAr 3  A9 01                        lda #1                  ; We're immediate, return 1
001DCCr 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001DCEr 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
001DD0r 3               
001DD0r 3  80 20                        bra @done_nodrop
001DD2r 3               
001DD2r 3               @next_entry_tmp1:
001DD2r 3  68                           pla             ; Restore tmp1 from the return stack.
001DD3r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001DD5r 3  68                           pla
001DD6r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001DD8r 3               @next_entry:
001DD8r 3                               ; Not the same, so we get the next word. Next header
001DD8r 3                               ; address is two bytes down
001DD8r 3  A0 02                        ldy #2
001DDAr 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
001DDCr 3  48                           pha
001DDDr 3  C8                           iny
001DDEr 3  B1 rr                        lda (tmp1),y
001DE0r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001DE2r 3  68                           pla
001DE3r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001DE5r 3               
001DE5r 3                               ; If we got a zero, we've walked the whole Dictionary and
001DE5r 3                               ; return as a failure, otherwise try again
001DE5r 3  05 rr                        ora tmp1+1
001DE7r 3  F0 03                        beq @fail_done
001DE9r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @loop
001DECr 3               
001DECr 3               @fail_done:
001DECr 3  74 02                        stz 2,x         ; failure flag
001DEEr 3  74 03                        stz 3,x
001DF0r 3               @done:
001DF0r 3  E8                           inx
001DF1r 3  E8                           inx
001DF2r 3               @done_nodrop:
001DF2r 3               z_search_wordlist:
001DF2r 3  60                           rts
001DF3r 3               
001DF3r 3               
001DF3r 3               
001DF3r 3               ; ## SEE ( "name" -- ) "Print information about a Forth word"
001DF3r 3               ; ## "see" tested  ANS tools
001DF3r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/tools/SEE
001DF3r 3                       ; SEE takes the name of a word and prints its name token (nt),
001DF3r 3                       ; execution token (xt), size in bytes, flags used, and then dumps the
001DF3r 3                       ; code and disassembles it.
001DF3r 3                       ; """
001DF3r 3               
001DF3r 3               xt_see:
001DF3r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_parse_name       ; ( addr u )
001DF6r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_find_name        ; ( nt | 0 )
001DF9r 3               
001DF9r 3                               ; If we got back a zero we don't know that word and so we quit
001DF9r 3                               ; with an error
001DF9r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001DFBr 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
001DFDr 3  D0 05                        bne @1
001DFFr 3               
001DFFr 3  A9 05                        lda #err_noname
001E01r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
001E04r 3               @1:
001E04r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_cr
001E07r 3               
001E07r 3                               ; We have a legal word, so let's get serious. Save the current
001E07r 3                               ; number base and use hexadecimal instead.
001E07r 3  A5 rr                        lda base
001E09r 3  48                           pha
001E0Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_hex
001E0Dr 3               
001E0Dr 3  A9 0A                        lda #str_see_nt
001E0Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_string_no_lf
001E12r 3               
001E12r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dup              ; ( nt nt )
001E15r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_u_dot
001E18r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space            ; ( nt )
001E1Br 3               
001E1Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dup              ; ( nt nt )
001E1Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_name_to_int      ; ( nt xt )
001E21r 3               
001E21r 3  A9 0B                        lda #str_see_xt
001E23r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_string_no_lf
001E26r 3               
001E26r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dup              ; ( nt xt xt )
001E29r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_u_dot
001E2Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_cr               ; ( nt xt )
001E2Fr 3               
001E2Fr 3                               ; We print letters for flags and then later follow it with 1 or
001E2Fr 3                               ; 0 to mark if which flag is set
001E2Fr 3  A9 09                        lda #str_see_flags
001E31r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_string_no_lf
001E34r 3               
001E34r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_over             ; ( nt xt nt )
001E37r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_one_plus         ; ( nt xt nt+1 )
001E3Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_fetch            ; ( nt xt flags )
001E3Dr 3               
001E3Dr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001E3Fr 3               
001E3Fr 3                               ; This is crude, but for the moment it is good enough
001E3Fr 3  A0 06                        ldy #6                  ; Not all bits are used
001E41r 3               @flag_loop:
001E41r 3  48                           pha
001E42r 3  29 01                        and #%00000001
001E44r 3  18                           clc
001E45r 3  69 30                        adc #$30                ; ASCII "0"
001E47r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr emit_a
001E4Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
001E4Dr 3               
001E4Dr 3  68                           pla
001E4Er 3  6A                           ror                     ; Next flag
001E4Fr 3               
001E4Fr 3  88                           dey
001E50r 3  D0 EF                        bne @flag_loop
001E52r 3               
001E52r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_cr
001E55r 3               
001E55r 3  E8                           inx
001E56r 3  E8                           inx                     ; ( nt xt )
001E57r 3               
001E57r 3                               ; Figure out the size
001E57r 3  A9 0C                        lda #str_see_size
001E59r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_string_no_lf
001E5Cr 3               
001E5Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_swap             ; ( xt nt )
001E5Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_wordsize         ; ( xt u )
001E62r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dup              ; ( xt u u ) for DUMP and DISASM
001E65r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_decimal
001E68r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_u_dot            ; ( xt u )
001E6Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_hex
001E6Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_cr
001E71r 3               
001E71r 3                               ; Dump hex and disassemble
001E71r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_two_dup          ; ( xt u xt u )
001E74r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_dump
001E77r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_cr
001E7Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_disasm
001E7Dr 3               
001E7Dr 3  68                           pla
001E7Er 3  85 rr                        sta base
001E80r 3               
001E80r 3  60           z_see:          rts
001E81r 3               
001E81r 3               
001E81r 3               
001E81r 3               ; ## SET_CURRENT ( wid -- ) "Set the compilation wordlist"
001E81r 3               ; ## "set-current" auto ANS search
001E81r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/SET-CURRENT"""
001E81r 3               
001E81r 3               xt_set_current:
001E81r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
001E84r 3               
001E84r 3                               ; Save the value from the data stack.
001E84r 3  A0 04                        ldy #current_offset
001E86r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x         ; CURRENT is byte variable
001E88r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y      ; so only the LSB is used.
001E8Ar 3               
001E8Ar 3  E8                           inx
001E8Br 3  E8                           inx
001E8Cr 3               
001E8Cr 3  60           z_set_current:  rts
001E8Dr 3               
001E8Dr 3               
001E8Dr 3               
001E8Dr 3               ; ## SET_ORDER ( wid_n .. wid_1 n -- ) "Set the current search order"
001E8Dr 3               ; ## "set-order" auto ANS search
001E8Dr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/search/SET-ORDER"""
001E8Dr 3               
001E8Dr 3               xt_set_order:
001E8Dr 3                               ; Test for -1 TOS
001E8Dr 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF
001E8Fr 3  D5 01                        cmp 1,x
001E91r 3  D0 12                        bne @start
001E93r 3  D5 00                        cmp 0,x
001E95r 3  D0 0E                        bne @start
001E97r 3               
001E97r 3                               ; There is a -1 TOS.  Replace it with the default
001E97r 3                               ; search order, which is just the FORTH-WORDLIST.
001E97r 3  CA                           dex             ; Make room for the count.
001E98r 3  CA                           dex
001E99r 3  74 03                        stz 3,x         ; ROOT-WORDLIST is 3
001E9Br 3  A9 03                        lda #3
001E9Dr 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
001E9Fr 3  74 01                        stz 1,x         ; Count is 1.
001EA1r 3  A9 01                        lda #1
001EA3r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
001EA5r 3               
001EA5r 3                               ; Continue processing with ( forth-wordlist 1 -- )
001EA5r 3               @start:
001EA5r 3                               ; Set #ORDER - the number of wordlists in the search order.
001EA5r 3  A0 1E                        ldy #num_order_offset
001EA7r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001EA9r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y      ; #ORDER is a byte variable.
001EABr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1        ; Save a copy for zero check and looping.
001EADr 3                                               ; Only the low byte is saved in tmp1 as
001EADr 3                                               ; only 8 wordlists are allowed.
001EADr 3               
001EADr 3  E8                           inx             ; Drop the count off the data stack.
001EAEr 3  E8                           inx
001EAFr 3               
001EAFr 3                               ; Check if there are zero wordlists.
001EAFr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp1
001EB1r 3  F0 0D                        beq @done       ; If zero, there are no wordlists.
001EB3r 3               
001EB3r 3                               ; Move the wordlist ids from the data stack to the search order.
001EB3r 3  A0 1F                        ldy #search_order_offset
001EB5r 3               @loop:
001EB5r 3                               ; Move one wordlist id over into the search order.
001EB5r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x         ; The search order is a byte array
001EB7r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y      ; so only save the LSB
001EB9r 3  C8                           iny
001EBAr 3               
001EBAr 3                               ; Remove it from the data stack.
001EBAr 3  E8                           inx
001EBBr 3  E8                           inx
001EBCr 3               
001EBCr 3                               ; See if that was the last one to process (first in the list).
001EBCr 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp1
001EBEr 3  D0 F5                        bne @loop
001EC0r 3               
001EC0r 3               @done:
001EC0r 3  60           z_set_order:    rts
001EC1r 3               
001EC1r 3               
001EC1r 3               
001EC1r 3               
001EC1r 3               ; ## S_QUOTE ( "string" -- )( -- addr u ) "Store string in memory"
001EC1r 3               ; ## "s""  auto  ANS core
001EC1r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Sq
001EC1r 3                       ; Store address and length of string given, returning ( addr u ).
001EC1r 3                       ; ANS core claims this is compile-only, but the file set expands it
001EC1r 3                       ; to be interpreted, so it is a state-sensitive word, which in theory
001EC1r 3                       ; are evil. We follow general usage.
001EC1r 3                       ;
001EC1r 3                       ; Can also be realized as
001EC1r 3                       ;     : S" [CHAR] " PARSE POSTPONE SLITERAL ; IMMEDIATE
001EC1r 3                       ; but it is used so much we want it in code.
001EC1r 3                       ; """
001EC1r 3               
001EC1r 3               xt_s_quote:
001EC1r 3                               ; tmp2 will be used to determine if we are handling
001EC1r 3                               ; escaped characters or not.  In this case, we are
001EC1r 3                               ; not, so set it to zero.
001EC1r 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2
001EC3r 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2+1
001EC5r 3               
001EC5r 3               s_quote_start:
001EC5r 3                               ; Make room on the data stack for the address.
001EC5r 3  CA                           dex
001EC6r 3  CA                           dex
001EC7r 3                               ; Make room on the data stack for the count.
001EC7r 3  CA                           dex
001EC8r 3  CA                           dex
001EC9r 3               
001EC9r 3                               ; Put a jmp over the string data with address to be filled
001EC9r 3                               ; in later.
001EC9r 3  A9 4C                        lda #$4C
001ECBr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
001ECEr 3               
001ECEr 3                               ; Address to be filled in later, just use $4C for the moment
001ECEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
001ED1r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
001ED4r 3               
001ED4r 3                               ; Save the current value of HERE on the data stack for the
001ED4r 3                               ; address of the string.
001ED4r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
001ED6r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
001ED8r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
001EDAr 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
001EDCr 3               
001EDCr 3               @savechars_loop:
001EDCr 3                               ; Start saving the string into the dictionary up to the
001EDCr 3                               ; ending double quote. First, check to see if the input
001EDCr 3                               ; buffer is empty.
001EDCr 3  A5 rr                        lda toin+1              ; MSB
001EDEr 3  C5 rr                        cmp ciblen+1
001EE0r 3  90 2A                        bcc @input_fine         ; unsigned comparison
001EE2r 3               
001EE2r 3  A5 rr                        lda toin                ; LSB
001EE4r 3  C5 rr                        cmp ciblen
001EE6r 3  90 24                        bcc @input_fine
001EE8r 3               
001EE8r 3                               ; Input buffer is empty. Refill it. Refill calls accept,
001EE8r 3                               ; which uses tmp2 and tmp3. Save and restore them.
001EE8r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2
001EEAr 3  48                           pha
001EEBr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp2+1
001EEDr 3  48                           pha
001EEEr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp3    ; Only tmp3 used, so don't bother with tmp3+1
001EF0r 3  48                           pha
001EF1r 3               
001EF1r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_refill           ; ( -- f )
001EF4r 3               
001EF4r 3  68                           pla
001EF5r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3
001EF7r 3  68                           pla
001EF8r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
001EFAr 3  68                           pla
001EFBr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
001EFDr 3               
001EFDr 3                               ; Check result of refill.
001EFDr 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
001EFFr 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
001F01r 3  D0 05                        bne @refill_ok
001F03r 3               
001F03r 3                               ; Something when wrong with refill.
001F03r 3  A9 06                        lda #err_refill
001F05r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp error
001F08r 3               
001F08r 3               @refill_ok:
001F08r 3                               ; Remove the refill flag from the data stack.
001F08r 3  E8                           inx
001F09r 3  E8                           inx
001F0Ar 3               
001F0Ar 3                               ; For refill success, jump back up to the empty check, just in
001F0Ar 3                               ; case refill gave us an empty buffer (eg. empty/blank line of
001F0Ar 3                               ; input)
001F0Ar 3  80 D0                        bra @savechars_loop
001F0Cr 3               
001F0Cr 3               @input_fine:
001F0Cr 3                               ; There should be at least one valid char to use.
001F0Cr 3                               ; Calculate it's address at CIB+TOIN into tmp1
001F0Cr 3  A5 rr                        lda cib
001F0Er 3  18                           clc
001F0Fr 3  65 rr                        adc toin        ; LSB
001F11r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
001F13r 3  A5 rr                        lda cib+1
001F15r 3  65 rr                        adc toin+1      ; MSB
001F17r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
001F19r 3               
001F19r 3                               ; Get the character
001F19r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
001F1Br 3               
001F1Br 3                               ; Check to see if we are handling escaped characters.
001F1Br 3  24 rr                        bit tmp2
001F1Dr 3  30 03                        bmi @handle_escapes    ; Only checking bit 7
001F1Fr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @regular_char
001F22r 3               
001F22r 3               @handle_escapes:
001F22r 3                               ; We are handling escaped characters.  See if we have
001F22r 3                               ; already seen the backslash.
001F22r 3  24 rr                        bit tmp2+1
001F24r 3  30 03                        bmi @escaped
001F26r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @not_escaped
001F29r 3               
001F29r 3               @escaped:
001F29r 3               
001F29r 3                               ; We have seen a backslash (previous character). Check to see if
001F29r 3                               ; we are in the middle of a \x sequence (bit 6 of tmp2+1 will
001F29r 3                               ; be clear in that case )
001F29r 3  70 22                        bvs @check_esc_chars
001F2Br 3               
001F2Br 3                               ; We are in the middle of a \x sequence. Check to see if we
001F2Br 3                               ; are on the first or second digit.
001F2Br 3  A9 01                        lda #1
001F2Dr 3  24 rr                        bit tmp2+1
001F2Fr 3  D0 10                        bne @esc_x_second_digit
001F31r 3               
001F31r 3                               ; First digit.
001F31r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2+1  ; Adjust flag for second digit next time.
001F33r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)  ; Get the char again.
001F35r 3               
001F35r 3                               ; Convert to hex
001F35r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr convert_hex_value
001F38r 3               
001F38r 3                               ; This is the upper nybble, so move it up.
001F38r 3  0A                           asl
001F39r 3  0A                           asl
001F3Ar 3  0A                           asl
001F3Br 3  0A                           asl
001F3Cr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3    ; Save it for later.
001F3Er 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @next_character
001F41r 3               
001F41r 3               @esc_x_second_digit:
001F41r 3               
001F41r 3                               ; We are on the second hex digit of a \x sequence. Clear the
001F41r 3                               ; escaped character flag (because we are handling it right
001F41r 3                               ; here)
001F41r 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2+1
001F43r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
001F45r 3               
001F45r 3                               ; Convert to hex, combine with value in tmp3
001F45r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr convert_hex_value
001F48r 3  05 rr                        ora tmp3
001F4Ar 3               
001F4Ar 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @save_character
001F4Dr 3               
001F4Dr 3               @check_esc_chars:
001F4Dr 3                               ; Clear the escaped character flag (because we are
001F4Dr 3                               ; handling it right here)
001F4Dr 3  64 rr                        stz tmp2+1
001F4Fr 3               
001F4Fr 3                               ; Process the escaped character
001F4Fr 3               @check_esc_a:
001F4Fr 3  C9 61                        cmp #'a'
001F51r 3  D0 05                        bne @check_esc_b
001F53r 3               
001F53r 3                               ; BEL (ASCII value 7)
001F53r 3  A9 07                        lda #7
001F55r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @save_character
001F58r 3               
001F58r 3               @check_esc_b:
001F58r 3  C9 62                        cmp #'b'
001F5Ar 3  D0 05                        bne @check_esc_e
001F5Cr 3               
001F5Cr 3                               ; Backspace (ASCII value 8)
001F5Cr 3  A9 08                        lda #8
001F5Er 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @save_character
001F61r 3               
001F61r 3               @check_esc_e:
001F61r 3  C9 65                        cmp #'e'
001F63r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_f
001F65r 3               
001F65r 3                               ; ESC (ASCII value 27)
001F65r 3  A9 1B                        lda #27
001F67r 3  80 75                        bra @save_character
001F69r 3               
001F69r 3               @check_esc_f:
001F69r 3  C9 66                        cmp #'f'
001F6Br 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_l
001F6Dr 3               
001F6Dr 3                               ; FF (ASCII value 12)
001F6Dr 3  A9 0C                        lda #12
001F6Fr 3  80 6D                        bra @save_character
001F71r 3               
001F71r 3               @check_esc_l:
001F71r 3  C9 6C                        cmp #'l'
001F73r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_m
001F75r 3               
001F75r 3                               ; LF (ASCII value 10)
001F75r 3  A9 0A                        lda #10
001F77r 3  80 65                        bra @save_character
001F79r 3               
001F79r 3               @check_esc_m:
001F79r 3                               ; This one is not like the others because we save two
001F79r 3                               ; characters
001F79r 3  C9 6D                        cmp #'m'
001F7Br 3  D0 09                        bne @check_esc_n
001F7Dr 3               
001F7Dr 3                               ; CR/LF pair (ASCII values 13, 10)
001F7Dr 3  A9 0D                        lda #13
001F7Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
001F82r 3  A9 0A                        lda #10
001F84r 3  80 58                        bra @save_character
001F86r 3               
001F86r 3               @check_esc_n:
001F86r 3  C9 6E                        cmp #'n'
001F88r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_q
001F8Ar 3               
001F8Ar 3                               ; newline, impl. dependant, using LF (ASCII values 10)
001F8Ar 3  A9 0A                        lda #10
001F8Cr 3  80 50                        bra @save_character
001F8Er 3               
001F8Er 3               @check_esc_q:
001F8Er 3  C9 71                        cmp #'q'
001F90r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_r
001F92r 3               
001F92r 3                               ; Double quote (ASCII value 34)
001F92r 3  A9 22                        lda #34
001F94r 3  80 48                        bra @save_character
001F96r 3               
001F96r 3               @check_esc_r:
001F96r 3  C9 72                        cmp #'r'
001F98r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_t
001F9Ar 3               
001F9Ar 3                               ; CR (ASCII value 13)
001F9Ar 3  A9 0D                        lda #13
001F9Cr 3  80 40                        bra @save_character
001F9Er 3               
001F9Er 3               @check_esc_t:
001F9Er 3  C9 74                        cmp #'t'
001FA0r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_v
001FA2r 3               
001FA2r 3                               ; Horizontal TAB (ASCII value 9)
001FA2r 3  A9 09                        lda #9
001FA4r 3  80 38                        bra @save_character
001FA6r 3               
001FA6r 3               @check_esc_v:
001FA6r 3  C9 76                        cmp #'v'
001FA8r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_z
001FAAr 3               
001FAAr 3                               ; Vertical TAB (ASCII value 11)
001FAAr 3  A9 0B                        lda #11
001FACr 3  80 30                        bra @save_character
001FAEr 3               
001FAEr 3               @check_esc_z:
001FAEr 3  C9 7A                        cmp #'z'
001FB0r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_quote
001FB2r 3               
001FB2r 3                               ; NULL (ASCII value 0)
001FB2r 3  A9 00                        lda #0
001FB4r 3  80 28                        bra @save_character
001FB6r 3               
001FB6r 3               @check_esc_quote:
001FB6r 3  C9 22                        cmp #$22
001FB8r 3  D0 04                        bne @check_esc_x
001FBAr 3               
001FBAr 3                               ; Double quote (ASCII value 34)
001FBAr 3  A9 22                        lda #34
001FBCr 3  80 20                        bra @save_character
001FBEr 3               
001FBEr 3               @check_esc_x:
001FBEr 3  C9 78                        cmp #'x'
001FC0r 3  D0 06                        bne @check_esc_backslash
001FC2r 3               
001FC2r 3                               ; This one is difficult. We need to get the next TWO
001FC2r 3                               ; characters (which might require a refill in the middle)
001FC2r 3                               ; and combine them as two hex digits. We do this by
001FC2r 3                               ; clearing bit 6 of tmp2+1 to indicate we are in a digit
001FC2r 3                               ; and using bit 0 to keep track of which digit we are on.
001FC2r 3  A9 BE                        lda #$BE        ; Clear bits 6 and 0
001FC4r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
001FC6r 3  80 19                        bra @next_character
001FC8r 3               
001FC8r 3               @check_esc_backslash:
001FC8r 3  C9 5C                        cmp #$5C
001FCAr 3  D0 04                        bne @not_escaped
001FCCr 3               
001FCCr 3                               ; Backslash (ASCII value 92)
001FCCr 3  A9 5C                        lda #92
001FCEr 3  80 0E                        bra @save_character
001FD0r 3               
001FD0r 3               @not_escaped:
001FD0r 3                               ; Check for the backslash to see if we should escape
001FD0r 3                               ; the next char.
001FD0r 3  C9 5C                        cmp #$5C        ; The backslash char
001FD2r 3  D0 06                        bne @regular_char
001FD4r 3               
001FD4r 3                               ; We found a backslash.  Don't save anyhing, but set
001FD4r 3                               ; a flag (in tmp2+1) to handle the next char. We don't
001FD4r 3                               ; try to get the next char here as it may require a
001FD4r 3                               ; refill of the input buffer.
001FD4r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF
001FD6r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
001FD8r 3  80 07                        bra @next_character
001FDAr 3               
001FDAr 3               @regular_char:
001FDAr 3                               ; Check if the current character is the end of the string.
001FDAr 3  C9 22                        cmp #$22        ; ASCII for "
001FDCr 3  F0 0C                        beq @found_string_end
001FDEr 3               
001FDEr 3               @save_character:
001FDEr 3                               ; If we didn't reach the end of the string, compile this
001FDEr 3                               ; character into the dictionary
001FDEr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
001FE1r 3               
001FE1r 3               @next_character:
001FE1r 3                               ; Move on to the next character.
001FE1r 3  E6 rr                        inc toin
001FE3r 3  D0 02                        bne @savechars_loop_longjump
001FE5r 3  E6 rr                        inc toin+1
001FE7r 3               
001FE7r 3               @savechars_loop_longjump:
001FE7r 3  4C rr rr                     jmp @savechars_loop
001FEAr 3               
001FEAr 3               @found_string_end:
001FEAr 3                               ; Use up the delimiter.
001FEAr 3  E6 rr                        inc toin
001FECr 3  D0 02                        bne @1
001FEEr 3  E6 rr                        inc toin+1
001FF0r 3               @1:
001FF0r 3                               ; Calculate the length of the string, which is the
001FF0r 3                               ; difference between cp and the address of the start
001FF0r 3                               ; of the string (currently saved on the stack).
001FF0r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
001FF2r 3  38                           sec
001FF3r 3  F5 02                        sbc 2,x
001FF5r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x         ; LSB
001FF7r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
001FF9r 3  F5 03                        sbc 3,x
001FFBr 3  95 01                        sta 1,x         ; MSB
001FFDr 3               
001FFDr 3                               ; Update the address of the jump-over jmp instruction.
001FFDr 3                               ; First determine location of jmp instructions address.
001FFDr 3                               ; It should be 2 bytes before the start of the string.
001FFDr 3                               ; Compute it into tmp1, which is no longer being used.
001FFDr 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
001FFFr 3  38                           sec
002000r 3  E9 02                        sbc #2
002002r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
002004r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
002006r 3  E9 00                        sbc #0          ; Propagate borrow
002008r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
00200Ar 3               
00200Ar 3                               ; Update the address of the jump to HERE.
00200Ar 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
00200Cr 3  92 rr                        sta (tmp1)
00200Er 3  A0 01                        ldy #1
002010r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
002012r 3  91 rr                        sta (tmp1),y
002014r 3               
002014r 3                               ; What happens next depends on the state (which is bad, but
002014r 3                               ; that's the way it works at the moment). If we are
002014r 3                               ; interpretating, we save the string to a transient buffer
002014r 3                               ; and return that address (used for file calls, see
002014r 3                               ; https://forth-standard.org/standard/file/Sq . If we're
002014r 3                               ; compiling, we just need SLITERAL
002014r 3  A5 rr                        lda state
002016r 3  05 rr                        ora state+1             ; paranoid
002018r 3  F0 03                        beq @done
00201Ar 3               
00201Ar 3                               ; Jump into the middle of the sliteral word, after the
00201Ar 3                               ; string data has been compiled into the dictionary,
00201Ar 3                               ; because we've already done that step.
00201Ar 3  20 rr rr                     jsr sliteral_const_str         ; ( addr u -- )
00201Dr 3               
00201Dr 3               @done:
00201Dr 3  60           z_s_quote:      rts
00201Er 3               
00201Er 3               
00201Er 3               
00201Er 3               ; ## S_TO_D ( u -- d ) "Convert single cell number to double cell"
00201Er 3               ; ## "s>d"  auto  ANS core
00201Er 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/StoD"""
00201Er 3               
00201Er 3               xt_s_to_d:
00201Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
002021r 3               
002021r 3  CA                           dex
002022r 3  CA                           dex
002023r 3  74 00                        stz 0,x
002025r 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
002027r 3               
002027r 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
002029r 3  10 04                        bpl @done
00202Br 3               
00202Br 3                               ; negative, extend sign
00202Br 3  D6 00                        dec 0,x
00202Dr 3  D6 01                        dec 1,x
00202Fr 3               @done:
00202Fr 3  60           z_s_to_d:       rts
002030r 3               
002030r 3               
002030r 3               
002030r 3               ; ## SAVE_BUFFERS ( -- ) "Save all dirty buffers to storage"
002030r 3               ; ## "save-buffers"  tested  ANS block
002030r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/SAVE-BUFFERS"""
002030r 3               
002030r 3               xt_save_buffers:
002030r 3                               ; Check the buffer status
002030r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
002032r 3  B1 rr                        lda (up),y      ; Only bits 0 and 1 are used, so only
002034r 3  C9 03                        cmp #3          ; LSB is needed.
002036r 3  D0 12                        bne @done       ; Either not used or not dirty = done!
002038r 3               
002038r 3                               ; We need to save the block.
002038r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_blkbuffer
00203Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_buffblocknum
00203Er 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_fetch
002041r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_block_write
002044r 3               
002044r 3                               ; Mark the buffer as clean now.
002044r 3  A9 01                        lda #1
002046r 3  A0 2C                        ldy #buffstatus_offset
002048r 3  91 rr                        sta (up),y
00204Ar 3               
00204Ar 3               @done:
00204Ar 3  60           z_save_buffers: rts
00204Br 3               
00204Br 3               
00204Br 3               
00204Br 3               ; ## SCR ( -- addr ) "Push address of variable holding last screen listed"
00204Br 3               ; ## "scr"  auto  ANS block ext
00204Br 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/block/SCR"""
00204Br 3               xt_scr:
00204Br 3                               ; SCR is at UP + scr_offset
00204Br 3  CA                           dex
00204Cr 3  CA                           dex
00204Dr 3  18                           clc
00204Er 3  A5 rr                        lda up
002050r 3  69 02                        adc #scr_offset ; Add offset
002052r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
002054r 3  A5 rr                        lda up+1
002056r 3  69 00                        adc #0          ; Adding carry
002058r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
00205Ar 3               
00205Ar 3  60           z_scr:          rts
00205Br 3               
00205Br 3               
00205Br 3               ; ## SEARCH ( addr1 u1 addr2 u2 -- addr3 u3 flag) "Search for a substring"
00205Br 3               ; ## "search"   auto  ANS string
00205Br 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/string/SEARCH
00205Br 3                       ; Search for string2 (denoted by addr2 u2) in string1 (denoted by
00205Br 3                       ; addr1 u1). If a match is found the flag will be true and
00205Br 3                       ; addr3 will have the address of the start of the match and u3 will have
00205Br 3                       ; the number of characters remaining from the match point to the end
00205Br 3                       ; of the original string1. If a match is not found, the flag will be
00205Br 3                       ; false and addr3 and u3 will be the original string1's addr1 and u1.
00205Br 3                       ; """
00205Br 3               
00205Br 3               xt_search:
00205Br 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_4
00205Er 3               
00205Er 3                               ; ANS says if the second string is a zero-length string it
00205Er 3                               ; automatically matches.
00205Er 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
002060r 3  15 01                        ora 1,x
002062r 3  D0 0B                        bne @start_search
002064r 3               
002064r 3                               ; The second string is a zero length string.  Just remove
002064r 3                               ; the second string and put a true flag.
002064r 3  E8                           inx             ; Remove u2
002065r 3  E8                           inx
002066r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF        ; Turn addr2 into a true flag
002068r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
00206Ar 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
00206Cr 3  4C rr rr                     jmp z_search
00206Fr 3               
00206Fr 3               @start_search:
00206Fr 3                               ; Put an offset (starting at zero) on the stack.
00206Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_zero
002072r 3               
002072r 3               @search_loop:
002072r 3                               ; We stop (not found) when u2 + offset > u1
002072r 3                               ; Calculate u2+offset into tmp1
002072r 3  18                           clc
002073r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
002075r 3  75 02                        adc 2,x
002077r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
002079r 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
00207Br 3  75 03                        adc 3,x
00207Dr 3               
00207Dr 3               
00207Dr 3                               ; Compare to u1. Start with the high byte
00207Dr 3  D5 07                        cmp 7,x
00207Fr 3  90 12                        bcc @init_comparison ; Obviously less
002081r 3  D0 06                        bne @not_found
002083r 3               
002083r 3                               ; The upper address byte matched - check the lower byte
002083r 3                               ; Load u1 first so we can use just a carry to check.
002083r 3  B5 06                        lda 6,x
002085r 3  C5 rr                        cmp tmp1
002087r 3  B0 0A                        bcs @init_comparison
002089r 3               
002089r 3               @not_found:
002089r 3                               ; The substring isn't in the main string.
002089r 3                               ; Return just the main string and a false flag.
002089r 3  E8                           inx             ; Remove offset
00208Ar 3  E8                           inx
00208Br 3  E8                           inx             ; Remove u2
00208Cr 3  E8                           inx
00208Dr 3  74 00                        stz 0,x         ; Turn addr2 into a false flag
00208Fr 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
002091r 3  80 66                        bra z_search
002093r 3               
002093r 3               @init_comparison:
002093r 3                               ; Use tmp1 to hold address in string 1.
002093r 3                               ; Use tmp2 to hold address in string 2.
002093r 3                               ; Use tmp3 to hold the number of characters left to check.
002093r 3               
002093r 3                               ; Compute the starting address in string 1
002093r 3                               ; as addr1 + offset
002093r 3  18                           clc
002094r 3  B5 08                        lda 8,x
002096r 3  75 00                        adc 0,x
002098r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1
00209Ar 3  B5 09                        lda 9,x
00209Cr 3  75 01                        adc 1,x
00209Er 3  85 rr                        sta tmp1+1
0020A0r 3               
0020A0r 3                               ; The starting address in string 2 is just addr2.
0020A0r 3  B5 04                        lda 4,x
0020A2r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2
0020A4r 3  B5 05                        lda 5,x
0020A6r 3  85 rr                        sta tmp2+1
0020A8r 3               
0020A8r 3                               ; The number of characters to check is u2.
0020A8r 3  B5 02                        lda 2,x
0020AAr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3
0020ACr 3  B5 03                        lda 3,x
0020AEr 3  85 rr                        sta tmp3+1
0020B0r 3               
0020B0r 3               @comparison_loop:
0020B0r 3                               ; Check to see if the current characters match.
0020B0r 3  B2 rr                        lda (tmp1)
0020B2r 3  D2 rr                        cmp (tmp2)
0020B4r 3  F0 05                        beq @letters_match
0020B6r 3               
0020B6r 3                               ; One of the letters didn't match.
0020B6r 3                               ; Increment the offset and try again.
0020B6r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_one_plus
0020B9r 3  80 B7                        bra @search_loop
0020BBr 3               
0020BBr 3               @letters_match:
0020BBr 3                               ; The letters match.  Advance the pointers until the
0020BBr 3                               ; count reaches zero.
0020BBr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1
0020BDr 3  D0 02                        bne @1
0020BFr 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp1+1
0020C1r 3               @1:
0020C1r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2
0020C3r 3  D0 02                        bne @2
0020C5r 3  E6 rr                        inc tmp2+1
0020C7r 3               @2:
0020C7r 3                               ; Decrement the count of remaining letters to check.
0020C7r 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp3
0020C9r 3  D0 02                        bne @3
0020CBr 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp3+1
0020CDr 3               @3:
0020CDr 3  C6 rr                        dec tmp3
0020CFr 3               
0020CFr 3                               ; Check if we've reached zero.
0020CFr 3  A5 rr                        lda tmp3
0020D1r 3  05 rr                        ora tmp3+1
0020D3r 3  D0 DB                        bne @comparison_loop ; Check the next letter
0020D5r 3               
0020D5r 3                               ; We've run out of letters and they all match!
0020D5r 3                               ; Return (addr1+offset) (u1-offset) true
0020D5r 3                               ; Add offset to addr1.
0020D5r 3  18                           clc
0020D6r 3  B5 00                        lda 0,x
0020D8r 3  75 08                        adc 8,x
0020DAr 3  95 08                        sta 8,x
0020DCr 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x
0020DEr 3  75 09                        adc 9,x
0020E0r 3  95 09                        sta 9,x
0020E2r 3               
0020E2r 3                               ; Subtract offset from u1.
0020E2r 3  38                           sec
0020E3r 3  B5 06                        lda 6,x
0020E5r 3  F5 00                        sbc 0,x
0020E7r 3  95 06                        sta 6,x
0020E9r 3  B5 07                        lda 7,x
0020EBr 3  F5 01                        sbc 1,x
0020EDr 3  95 07                        sta 7,x
0020EFr 3               
0020EFr 3                               ; Replace addr2, u2, and offset with a true flag.
0020EFr 3  E8                           inx             ; drop offset
0020F0r 3  E8                           inx
0020F1r 3  E8                           inx             ; drop u2
0020F2r 3  E8                           inx
0020F3r 3  A9 FF                        lda #$FF
0020F5r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x         ; Turn addr2 into a true flag.
0020F7r 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
0020F9r 3               
0020F9r 3  60           z_search:       rts
0020FAr 3               
0020FAr 3               
0020FAr 3               
0020FAr 3               ; ## SEMICOLON ( -- ) "End compilation of new word"
0020FAr 3               ; ## ";"  auto  ANS core
0020FAr 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/Semi
0020FAr 3                       ; End the compilation of a new word into the Dictionary.
0020FAr 3                       ;
0020FAr 3                       ; When we
0020FAr 3                       ; enter this, WORKWORD is pointing to the nt_ of this word in the
0020FAr 3                       ; Dictionary, DP to the previous word, and CP to the next free byte.
0020FAr 3                       ; A Forth definition would be (see "Starting Forth"):
0020FAr 3                       ; : POSTPONE EXIT  REVEAL POSTPONE ; [ ; IMMEDIATE  Following the
0020FAr 3                       ; practice of Gforth, we warn here if a word has been redefined.
0020FAr 3                       ; """
0020FAr 3               
0020FAr 3               xt_semicolon:
0020FAr 3                               ; Check if this is a : word or a :NONAME word.
0020FAr 3  24 rr                        bit status
0020FCr 3  70 11                        bvs @colonword
0020FEr 3               
0020FEr 3                               ; This is a :NONAME word - just put an RTS on the end and
0020FEr 3                               ; the address (held in workword) on the stack.
0020FEr 3  A9 60                        lda #$60                ; opcode for RTS
002100r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
002103r 3               
002103r 3  CA                           dex
002104r 3  CA                           dex
002105r 3  A5 rr                        lda workword
002107r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
002109r 3  A5 rr                        lda workword+1
00210Br 3  95 01                        sta 1,x
00210Dr 3  80 45                        bra @semicolon_done
00210Fr 3               
00210Fr 3               @colonword:
00210Fr 3                               ; CP is the byte that will be the address we use in the
00210Fr 3                               ; header as the end-of-compile address (z_word). This is
00210Fr 3                               ; six bytes down from the header
00210Fr 3  A0 06                        ldy #6
002111r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp
002113r 3  91 rr                        sta (workword),y
002115r 3  C8                           iny
002116r 3  A5 rr                        lda cp+1
002118r 3  91 rr                        sta (workword),y
00211Ar 3               
00211Ar 3                               ; Allocate one further byte and save the RTS instruction
00211Ar 3                               ; there
00211Ar 3  A9 60                        lda #$60                ; opcode for RTS
00211Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr cmpl_a
00211Fr 3               
00211Fr 3                               ; Before we formally add the word to the Dictionary, we
00211Fr 3                               ; check to see if it is already present, and if yes, we
00211Fr 3                               ; warn the user.
00211Fr 3               
00211Fr 3                               ; See if word already in Dictionary.
00211Fr 3                               ; (STATUS bit 7 will be high as CREATE already
00211Fr 3                               ;  checked for us.)
00211Fr 3  24 rr                        bit status
002121r 3  10 26                        bpl @new_word   ; Bit 7 is clear = new word
002123r 3               
002123r 3                               ; We start by putting the string of the
002123r 3                               ; word we're defining on the stack
002123r 3  CA                           dex
002124r 3  CA                           dex
002125r 3  CA                           dex
002126r 3  CA                           dex
002127r 3               
002127r 3                               ; WORKWORD points to the beginning of the head of our new
002127r 3                               ; word, where the first byte is the length of the string
002127r 3                               ; We can't use LATESTNT because we haven't added the new
002127r 3                               ; word to the Dictionary yet
002127r 3  B2 rr                        lda (workword)
002129r 3  95 00                        sta 0,x
00212Br 3  74 01                        stz 1,x
00212Dr 3               
00212Dr 3                               ; Eight bytes below WORKWORD is the actual beginning of
00212Dr 3                               ; the string
00212Dr 3  A5 rr                        lda workword
00212Fr 3  18                           clc
002130r 3  69 08                        adc #8
002132r 3  95 02                        sta 2,x
002134r 3  A5 rr                        lda workword+1
002136r 3  69 00                        adc #0                  ; only want carry
002138r 3  95 03                        sta 3,x
00213Ar 3               
00213Ar 3                               ; This word is already in the Dictionary, so we print a
00213Ar 3                               ; warning to the user.
00213Ar 3  A9 02                        lda #str_redefined       ; address of string "redefined"
00213Cr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr print_string_no_lf
00213Fr 3               
00213Fr 3                               ; Now we print the offending word.
00213Fr 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_type
002142r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr xt_space
002145r 3               
002145r 3                               ; Clear bit 7 of status (so future words will print message
002145r 3                               ; by defaut)
002145r 3  A9 80                        lda #%10000000
002147r 3  14 rr                        trb status
002149r 3               
002149r 3               @new_word:
002149r 3                               ; Let's get this over with. Save beginning of our word
002149r 3                               ; as new last word in the Dictionary
002149r 3  A5 rr                        lda workword
00214Br 3  85 rr                        sta dp
00214Dr 3  A5 rr                        lda workword+1
00214Fr 3  85 rr                        sta dp+1
002151r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr dp_to_current       ; Save the updated DP to the
002154r 3                                                       ; CURRENT wordlist.
002154r 3               @semicolon_done:
002154r 3                               ; Word definition complete. Return compile flag to zero
002154r 3                               ; to return to interpret mode
002154r 3  64 rr                        stz state
002156r 3  64 rr                        stz state+1
002158r 3               
002158r 3  60           z_semicolon:    rts
002159r 3               
002159r 3               
002159r 3               
002159r 3               ; ## SIGN ( n -- ) "Add minus to pictured output"
002159r 3               ; ## "sign"  auto  ANS core
002159r 3                       ; """https://forth-standard.org/standard/core/SIGN
002159r 3                       ;
002159r 3                       ; Code based on
002159r 3                       ; http://pforth.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/fth/numberio.fth
002159r 3                       ; Original Forth code is   0< IF ASCII - HOLD THEN
002159r 3                       ; """
002159r 3               
002159r 3               xt_sign:
002159r 3  20 rr rr                     jsr underflow_1
00215Cr 3               
00215Cr 3  B5 01                        lda 1,x         ; check MSB of TOS
00215Er 3  30 04                        bmi @minus
002160r 3               
002160r 3  E8                           inx
002161r 3  E8                           inx
002162r 3  80 09                        bra @done
002164r 3               @minus:
002164r 3  A9 2D                        lda #$2D        ; ASCII for "-"
