002BBDr 3  B5 01                lda 1, x
002BBFr 3  8D rr rr             sta IO_SECTOR + 1
002BC2r 3  9C rr rr             stz IO_SECTOR + 2
002BC5r 3  9C rr rr             stz IO_SECTOR + 3
002BC8r 3               
002BC8r 3  0E rr rr             asl IO_SECTOR                   ; multiply by two to get first sector number
002BCBr 3  2E rr rr             rol IO_SECTOR + 1
002BCEr 3  2E rr rr             rol IO_SECTOR + 2
002BD1r 3               
002BD1r 3  20 rr rr             jsr io_write_sector
002BD4r 3  EE rr rr D0          inc32 IO_SECTOR
002BD8r 3  0D EE rr rr  
002BDCr 3  D0 08 EE rr  
002BE6r 3  E6 rr                inc io_buffer_ptr + 1
002BE8r 3  E6 rr                inc io_buffer_ptr + 1
002BEAr 3  20 rr rr             jsr io_write_sector
002BEDr 3               
002BEDr 3               
002BEDr 3                       ; inc io_buffer_ptr + 1           ; jump two pages forward
002BEDr 3                       ; inc io_buffer_ptr + 1
002BEDr 3                       ; jsr io_write_sector
002BEDr 3  E8                   inx
002BEEr 3  E8                   inx
002BEFr 3                       ; inx
002BEFr 3                       ; inx
002BEFr 3               .endif
002BEFr 3               z_io_writeblock:
002BEFr 3  60                   rts
002BF0r 3               ; END
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 2                   .include "headers.s"          ; Headers of native words
002BF0r 3               ; Dictionary Headers for Tali Forth 2
002BF0r 3               ; Scot W. Stevenson <scot.stevenson@gmail.com>
002BF0r 3               ; First version: 05. Dec 2016 (Liara Forth)
002BF0r 3               ; This version: 29. Dec 2018
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; Dictionary headers are kept separately from the code, which allows various
002BF0r 3               ; tricks in the code. We roughly follow the Gforth terminology: The Execution
002BF0r 3               ; Token (xt) is the address of the first byte of a word's code that can be, uh,
002BF0r 3               ; executed; the Name Token (nt) is a pointer to the beginning of the word's
002BF0r 3               ; header in the Dictionary. There the link to the next word in the Dictionary
002BF0r 3               ; is always one cell down from the current word's own nt. In the code itself,
002BF0r 3               ; we use "nt_<WORD>" for the nt and "xt_<WORD>" for the xt.
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; This gives us the following header structure:
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ;              8 bit     8 bit
002BF0r 3               ;               LSB       MSB
002BF0r 3               ; nt_word ->  +--------+--------+
002BF0r 3               ;          +0 | Length | Status |
002BF0r 3               ;             +--------+--------+
002BF0r 3               ;          +2 | Next Header     | -> nt_next_word
002BF0r 3               ;             +-----------------+
002BF0r 3               ;          +4 | Start of Code   | -> xt_word
002BF0r 3               ;             +-----------------+
002BF0r 3               ;          +6 | End of Code     | -> z_word
002BF0r 3               ;             +--------+--------+
002BF0r 3               ;          +8 | Name   |        |
002BF0r 3               ;             +--------+--------+
002BF0r 3               ;             |        |        |
002BF0r 3               ;             +--------+--------+
002BF0r 3               ;             |        |  ...   | (name string does not end with a zero)
002BF0r 3               ;          +n +--------+--------+
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; The Status Byte is created by adding the flags defined in definitions.asm,
002BF0r 3               ; which are:
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ;       CO - Compile Only
002BF0r 3               ;       IM - Immediate Word
002BF0r 3               ;       NN - Never Native Compile (must always be called by JSR)
002BF0r 3               ;       AN - Always Native Compile (may not be called by JSR)
002BF0r 3               ;       UF - Contains underflow check
002BF0r 3               ;       HC - Has CFA (words created by CREATE and DOES> only)
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; Note there are currently two bits unused.
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; By default, all existing words can be natively compiled (compiled inline) or
002BF0r 3               ; as a subroutine jump target; the system decides which variant to use based on
002BF0r 3               ; a threshold the user can set. By default, all user-created words are flagged
002BF0r 3               ; never-native. The user can override this by using the always-native word
002BF0r 3               ; just after defining their new word.  The NN flag forbids native compiling,
002BF0r 3               ; the AN flag forces it.
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; The last word (top word in code) is always BYE. It is marked as the last word
002BF0r 3               ; by its value of 0000 in its Next Header field. The words are sorted with the
002BF0r 3               ; more common ones first (further down in code) so they are found earlier.
002BF0r 3               ; Anything to do with output comes later (further up) because things will
002BF0r 3               ; always be slow if there is a human involved.
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               ; The initial skeleton of this list was automatically generated by a script
002BF0r 3               ; in the tools folder and then sorted by hand.
002BF0r 3               
002BF0r 3               nt_bye:
002BF0r 3  03                   .byte 3         ; length of word strings
002BF1r 3  00                   .byte 0         ; status byte
002BF2r 3  00 00                .word 0000      ; next word in Dictionary, 0000 signals end
002BF4r 3  rr rr                .word xt_bye    ; start of code block (xt of this word)
002BF6r 3  rr rr                .word z_bye     ; end of code (RTS)
002BF8r 3  62 79 65             .byte "bye"     ; word name, always lower case, not zero-terminated
002BFBr 3               
002BFBr 3               
002BFBr 3               nt_cold:
002BFBr 3  04 00                .byte 4, 0
002BFDr 3  rr rr rr rr          .word nt_bye, xt_cold, z_cold
002C01r 3  rr rr        
002C03r 3  63 6F 6C 64          .byte "cold"
002C07r 3               
002C07r 3               nt_lcdput:
002C07r 3  06 10                .byte 6, UF
002C09r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word nt_cold, xt_lcdput, z_lcdput
002C0Dr 3  rr rr        
002C0Fr 3  6C 63 64 70          .byte "lcdput"
002C13r 3  75 74        
002C15r 3               
002C15r 3               nt_lcdprint:

002C17r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word nt_lcdput, xt_lcdprint, z_lcdprint

002CA6r 3               .elseif .def(VIA1_BASE)

003A9Ar 3               ; ROOT-WORDLIST
003A9Ar 3                       ; This is a short wordlist that has just the words needed to

003B2Br 3               
003B2Br 3               ; ; ASSEMBLER-WORDLIST
003B2Br 3               
003B2Br 3               ; ; Labels for the opcodes have the format "nt_asm_<OPC>" where a futher
003B2Br 3               ; ; underscore replaces any dot present in the SAN mnemonic. The hash sign for
003B2Br 3               ; ; immediate addressing is replaced by an "h" (for example, the label code for
003B2Br 3               ; ; "lda.#" is "xt_adm_lda_h"). All opcodes are immediate.
003B2Br 3               .ifdef TALI_OPTIONAL_ASSEMBLER
003B2Br 3               assembler_dictionary_start:
003B2Br 3               nt_asm_adc_h:
003B2Br 3  05 04        		.byte 5, IM
003B2Dr 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_adc_x
003B2Fr 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_adc_h, z_asm_adc_h

003B37r 3  23           
003B38r 3

004343r 3               nt_asm_stz:
004343r 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
004345r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_stz_x
004347r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_stz, z_asm_stz
00434Br 3  73 74 7A     		.byte "stz"
00434Er 3               
00434Er 3               nt_asm_stz_x:
00434Er 3  05 04        		.byte 5, IM
004350r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_stz_z
004352r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_stz_x, z_asm_stz_x
004356r 3  73 74 7A 2E  		.byte "stz.x"
00435Ar 3  78           
00435Br 3               
00435Br 3               nt_asm_stz_z:
00435Br 3  05 04        		.byte 5, IM
00435Dr 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_stz_zx
00435Fr 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_stz_z, z_asm_stz_z
004363r 3  73 74 7A 2E  		.byte "stz.z"
004367r 3  7A           
004368r 3               
004368r 3               nt_asm_stz_zx:
004368r 3  06 04        		.byte 6, IM
00436Ar 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_tax
00436Cr 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_stz_zx, z_asm_stz_zx
004370r 3  73 74 7A 2E  		.byte "stz.zx"
004374r 3  7A 78        
004376r 3               
004376r 3               nt_asm_tax:
004376r 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
004378r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_tay
00437Ar 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_tax, z_asm_tax
00437Er 3  74 61 78     		.byte "tax"
004381r 3               
004381r 3               nt_asm_tay:
004381r 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
004383r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_trb
004385r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_tay, z_asm_tay
004389r 3  74 61 79     		.byte "tay"
00438Cr 3               
00438Cr 3               nt_asm_trb:
00438Cr 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
00438Er 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_trb_z
004390r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_trb, z_asm_trb
004394r 3  74 72 62     		.byte "trb"
004397r 3               
004397r 3               nt_asm_trb_z:
004397r 3  05 04        		.byte 5, IM
004399r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_tsb
00439Br 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_trb_z, z_asm_trb_z
00439Fr 3  74 72 62 2E  		.byte "trb.z"
0043A3r 3  7A           
0043A4r 3               
0043A4r 3               nt_asm_tsb:
0043A4r 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
0043A6r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_tsb_z
0043A8r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_tsb, z_asm_tsb
0043ACr 3  74 73 62     		.byte "tsb"
0043AFr 3               
0043AFr 3               nt_asm_tsb_z:
0043AFr 3  05 04        		.byte 5, IM
0043B1r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_tsx
0043B3r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_tsb_z, z_asm_tsb_z
0043B7r 3  74 73 62 2E  		.byte "tsb.z"
0043BBr 3  7A           
0043BCr 3               
0043BCr 3               nt_asm_tsx:
0043BCr 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
0043BEr 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_txa
0043C0r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_tsx, z_asm_tsx
0043C4r 3  74 73 78     		.byte "tsx"
0043C7r 3               
0043C7r 3               nt_asm_txa:
0043C7r 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
0043C9r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_txs
0043CBr 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_txa, z_asm_txa
0043CFr 3  74 78 61     		.byte "txa"
0043D2r 3               
0043D2r 3               nt_asm_txs:
0043D2r 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
0043D4r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_tya
0043D6r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_txs, z_asm_txs
0043DAr 3  74 78 73     		.byte "txs"
0043DDr 3               
0043DDr 3               nt_asm_tya:
0043DDr 3  03 04        		.byte 3, IM
0043DFr 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_arrow
0043E1r 3  rr rr rr rr  		.word xt_asm_tya, z_asm_tya
0043E5r 3  74 79 61     		.byte "tya"
0043E8r 3               
0043E8r 3               ; Assembler pseudo-instructions, directives and macros
0043E8r 3               
0043E8r 3               nt_asm_arrow:   ; uses same code as HERE, but immediate
0043E8r 3  03 04                        .byte 3, IM
0043EAr 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_back_jump
0043ECr 3  rr rr rr rr                  .word xt_asm_arrow, z_asm_arrow
0043F0r 3  2D 2D 3E                     .byte "-->"
0043F3r 3               
0043F3r 3               
0043F3r 3               nt_asm_back_jump:  ; syntactic sugar, does nothing
0043F3r 3  02 04                        .byte 2, IM
0043F5r 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_back_branch
0043F7r 3  rr rr rr rr                  .word xt_asm_back_jump, z_asm_back_jump
0043FBr 3  3C 6A                        .byte "<j"
0043FDr 3               
0043FDr 3               nt_asm_back_branch:
0043FDr 3  02 04                        .byte 2, IM
0043FFr 3  rr rr                        .word nt_asm_push_a
004401r 3  rr rr rr rr                  .word xt_asm_back_branch, z_asm_back_branch
004405r 3  3C 62                        .byte "<b"
004407r 3               
004407r 3               nt_asm_push_a:
004407r 3  06 04                        .byte 6, IM
004409r 3  00 00                        .word 0000
00440Br 3  rr rr rr rr                  .word xt_asm_push_a, z_asm_push_a
00440Fr 3  70 75 73 68                  .byte "push-a"
004413r 3  2D 61        
004415r 3               
004415r 3               .endif
004415r 3               
004415r 3               ; END of ASSEMBLER-WORDLIST
004415r 3               
004415r 3               ; END
004415r 3               
004415r 2                   .include "strings.s"          ; Headers of native words
004415r 3               ; List of Strings for Tali Forth 2
004415r 3               ; Scot W. Stevenson <scot.stevenson@gmail.com>
004415r 3               ; First version: 01. Apr 2016 (for Liara Forth)
004415r 3               ; This version: 28. Dec 2018
004415r 3               
004415r 3               ; This file is included by taliforth.asm
004415r 3               
004415r 3               ; ## GENERAL STRINGS
004415r 3               
004415r 3               ; All general strings must be zero-terminated, names start with "s_",
004415r 3               ; aliases with "str_"
004415r 3               
004415r 3               str_ok =              0
004415r 3               str_compile =         1
004415r 3               str_redefined =       2
004415r 3               str_wid_forth =       3
004415r 3               str_abc_lower =       4
004415r 3               str_abc_upper =       5
004415r 3               str_wid_editor =      6
004415r 3               str_wid_assembler =   7
004415r 3               str_wid_root =        8
004415r 3               str_see_flags =       9
004415r 3               str_see_nt =         10
004415r 3               str_see_xt =         11
004415r 3               str_see_size =       12
004415r 3               str_disasm_lit     = 13
004415r 3               str_disasm_sdc     = 14
004415r 3               str_disasm_bra     = 15
004415r 3               
004415r 3               ; Since we can't fit a 16-bit address in a register, we use indexes as offsets
004415r 3               ; to tables as error and string numbers.
004415r 3               string_table:
004415r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word s_ok, s_compiled, s_redefined, s_wid_forth, s_abc_lower ; 0-4
004419r 3  rr rr rr rr  
00441Dr 3  rr rr        
00441Fr 3  rr rr rr rr          .word s_abc_upper, s_wid_editor, s_wid_asm, s_wid_root        ; 5-8
004423r 3  rr rr rr rr  
004427r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word s_see_flags, s_see_nt, s_see_xt, s_see_size             ; 9-12
00442Br 3  rr rr rr rr  
00442Fr 3               
00442Fr 3  20 6F 6B 00  s_ok:         .byte " ok", 0         ; note space at beginning
004433r 3  20 63 6F 6D  s_compiled:   .byte " compiled", 0   ; note space at beginning
004437r 3  70 69 6C 65  
00443Br 3  64 00        
00443Dr 3  72 65 64 65  s_redefined:  .byte "redefined ", 0  ; note space at end
004441r 3  66 69 6E 65  
004445r 3  64 20 00     
004448r 3

00444Cr 3  34 35 36 37  
004450r 3  38 39 61 62  
00446Cr 3  30 31 32 33  s_abc_upper:  .byte "0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"
004470r 3  34 35 36 37  
004474r 3  38 39 41 42  
004490r 3               
004490r 3  41 73 73 65  s_wid_asm:    .byte "Assembler ", 0  ; Wordlist ID 2, note space at end
004494r 3  6D 62 6C 65  
004498r 3  72 20 00     
00449Br 3  45 64 69 74  s_wid_editor: .byte "Editor ", 0     ; Wordlist ID 1, note space at end
00449Fr 3  6F 72 20 00  
0044A3r 3  46 6F 72 74  s_wid_forth:  .byte "Forth ", 0      ; Wordlist ID 0, note space at end
0044A7r 3  68 20 00     
0044AAr 3  52 6F 6F 74  s_wid_root:   .byte "Root ", 0       ; Wordlist ID 3, note space at end
0044AEr 3  20 00        
0044B0r 3

0044B4r 3  73 20 28 43

0044D0r 3  00

0044D5r 3  00

0044DAr 3  20 28 64 65  
0044DEr 3  63 69 6D 61  
0044E7r 3  4C 49 54 45  s_disasm_lit: .byte "LITERAL ", 0
0044EBr 3  52 41 4C 20  
0044EFr 3  00           
0044F0r 3  53 54 41 43  s_disasm_sdc: .byte "STACK DEPTH CHECK", 0
0044F4r 3  4B 20 44 45  
0044F8r 3  50 54 48 20  
004502r 3  42 52 41 4E  s_disasm_bra: .byte "BRANCH ",0
004506r 3  43 48 20 00  
00450Ar 3               
00450Ar 3               
00450Ar 3               ; ## ERROR STRINGS
00450Ar 3               
00450Ar 3               ; All error strings must be zero-terminated, all names start with "es_",
00450Ar 3               ; aliases with "err_". If the string texts are changed, the test suite must be
00450Ar 3               ; as well
00450Ar 3               
00450Ar 3               err_allot =        0
00450Ar 3               err_badsource =    1
00450Ar 3               err_compileonly =  2
00450Ar 3               err_defer =        3
00450Ar 3               err_divzero =      4
00450Ar 3               err_noname =       5
00450Ar 3               err_refill =       6
00450Ar 3               err_state =        7
00450Ar 3               err_syntax =       8
00450Ar 3               err_underflow =    9
00450Ar 3               err_negallot =     10
00450Ar 3               err_wordlist =     11
00450Ar 3               err_blockwords =   12
00450Ar 3               
00450Ar 3               error_table:
00450Ar 3  rr rr rr rr          .word es_allot, es_badsource, es_compileonly, es_defer  ;  0-3
00450Er 3  rr rr rr rr  
004512r 3  rr rr rr rr          .word es_divzero, es_noname, es_refill, es_state        ;  4-7
004516r 3  rr rr rr rr  
00451Ar 3  rr rr rr rr          .word es_syntax, es_underflow, es_negallot, es_wordlist ;  8-11
00451Er 3  rr rr rr rr  
004522r 3  rr rr                .word es_blockwords                                    ; 12
004524r 3               
004524r 3  41 4C 4C 4F  es_allot:       .byte "ALLOT using all available memory", 0
004528r 3  54 20 75 73  
00452Cr 3  69 6E 67 20  
004545r 3  49 6C 6C 65  es_badsource:   .byte "Illegal SOURCE-ID during REFILL", 0
004549r 3  67 61 6C 20  
00454Dr 3  53 4F 55 52  
004565r 3  49 6E 74 65  es_compileonly: .byte "Interpreting a compile-only word", 0
004569r 3  72 70 72 65  
00456Dr 3  74 69 6E 67  
004586r 3  44 45 46 45  es_defer:       .byte "DEFERed word not defined yet", 0
00458Ar 3  52 65 64 20  
00458Er 3  77 6F 72 64  
0045A3r 3  44 69 76 69  es_divzero:     .byte "Division by zero", 0
0045A7r 3  73 69 6F 6E  
0045ABr 3  20 62 79 20  
0045B4r 3  50 61 72 73  es_noname:      .byte "Parsing failure", 0
0045B8r 3  69 6E 67 20  
0045BCr 3  66 61 69 6C  
0045C4r 3  51 55 49 54  es_refill:      .byte "QUIT could not get input (REFILL returned -1)", 0
0045C8r 3  20 63 6F 75  
0045CCr 3  6C 64 20 6E  
0045F2r 3  41 6C 72 65  es_state:       .byte "Already in compile mode", 0
0045F6r 3  61 64 79 20  
0045FAr 3  69 6E 20 63  
00460Ar 3  55 6E 64 65  es_syntax:      .byte "Undefined word", 0
00460Er 3  66 69 6E 65  
004612r 3  64 20 77 6F  
004619r 3  53 74 61 63  es_underflow:   .byte "Stack underflow", 0
00461Dr 3  6B 20 75 6E  
004621r 3  64 65 72 66  
004629r 3  4D 61 78 20  es_negallot:    .byte "Max memory freed with ALLOT", 0
00462Dr 3  6D 65 6D 6F  
004631r 3  72 79 20 66  
004645r 3  4E 6F 20 77  es_wordlist:    .byte "No wordlists available", 0
004649r 3  6F 72 64 6C  
00464Dr 3  69 73 74 73  
00465Cr 3  50 6C 65 61  es_blockwords:  .byte "Please assign vectors BLOCK-READ-VECTOR and BLOCK-WRITE-VECTOR",0
004660r 3  73 65 20 61  
004664r 3  73 73 69 67  
00469Br 3               
00469Br 3               ; ## ENVIRONMENT STRINGS
00469Br 3               
00469Br 3               ; These are used by the ENVIRONMENT? word and stored in the old string format:
00469Br 3               ; Length byte first, then the string itself that is not rpt. not
00469Br 3               ; zero-terminated. Note these are uppercase by ANS defintion. All start with
00469Br 3               ; "envs_".
00469Br 3               
00469Br 3               ; These return a single-cell number
00469Br 3  0F 2F 43 4F  envs_cs:        .byte 15, "/COUNTED-STRING"
00469Fr 3  55 4E 54 45  
0046A3r 3  44 2D 53 54  
0046ABr 3  05 2F 48 4F  envs_hold:      .byte 5, "/HOLD"
0046AFr 3  4C 44        
0046B1r 3  04 2F 50 41  envs_pad:       .byte 4, "/PAD"
0046B5r 3  44           
0046B6r 3  11 41 44 44  envs_aub:       .byte 17, "ADDRESS-UNIT-BITS"
0046BAr 3  52 45 53 53  
0046BEr 3  2D 55 4E 49  
0046C8r 3  07 46 4C 4F  envs_floored:   .byte 7, "FLOORED"
0046CCr 3  4F 52 45 44

0046D4r 3  2D 43 48 41

0046DDr 3  2D 4E

0046E3r 3  2D 55

0046E9r 3  55 52 4E 2D  
0046EDr 3  53 54 41 43

0046FCr 3  43 4B 2D 43  
004700r 3  45 4C 4C 53

004708r 3  44 4C 49 53  
00470Cr 3  54 53        
00470Er 3               
00470Er 3               ; These return a double-cell number
00470Er 3  05 4D 41 58  envs_max_d:     .byte 5, "MAX-D"
004712r 3  2D 44        
004714r 3  06 4D 41 58  envs_max_ud:    .byte 6, "MAX-UD"
004718r 3  2D 55 44     
00471Br 3               
00471Br 3               ; END
00471Br 3               
00471Br 2               
00471Br 2               ; High-level Forth words, see forth_code/README.md
00471Br 2               forth_words_start:
00471Br 2  20 63 72 20  .incbin "forth_code/forth_words.asc"
00471Fr 2  2E 28 20 52  
004723r 2  65 61 64 79  
00472Dr 2               forth_words_end:
00472Dr 2               
00472Dr 2               ; User-defined Forth words, see forth_code/README.md
00472Dr 2               user_words_start:
00472Dr 2  20 32 30 20  .incbin "forth_code/user_words.asc"
004731r 2  63 6F 6E 73  
004735r 2  74 61 6E 74  
004DE8r 2               user_words_end:
004DE8r 2               
004DE8r 2               
004DE8r 2               ; =====================================================================
004DE8r 2               ; COMPILE WORDS, JUMPS and SUBROUTINE JUMPS INTO CODE
004DE8r 2               
004DE8r 2               ; These three routines compile instructions such as "jsr xt_words" into a word
004DE8r 2               ; at compile time so they are available at run time. Words that use this
004DE8r 2               ; routine may not be natively compiled. We use "cmpl" as not to confuse these
004DE8r 2               ; routines with the COMPILE, word. Always call this with a subroutine jump.
004DE8r 2               ; This means combining JSR/RTS to JMP in those cases is not going to work. To
004DE8r 2               ; use, load the LSB of the address in A and the MSB in Y. You can remember
004DE8r 2               ; which comes first by thinking of the song "Young Americans" ("YA") by David
004DE8r 2               ; Bowie.
004DE8r 2               
004DE8r 2               ;               ldy #>addr      ; MSB   ; "Young"
004DE8r 2               ;               lda #<addr      ; LSB   ; "Americans"
004DE8r 2               ;               jsr cmpl_subroutine
004DE8r 2               
004DE8r 2               ; Also, we keep a routine here to compile a single byte passed through A.
004DE8r 2               
004DE8r 2               cmpl_subroutine:
004DE8r 2                   ; This is the entry point to compile JSR <ADDR>
004DE8r 2  48               pha             ; save LSB of address
004DE9r 2  A9 20            lda #$20        ; load opcode for JSR
004DEBr 2  80 03            bra cmpl_common
004DEDr 2               cmpl_jump:
004DEDr 2                   ; This is the entry point to compile JMP <ADDR>
004DEDr 2  48               pha             ; save LSB of address
004DEEr 2  A9 4C            lda #$4c        ; load opcode for JMP, fall thru to cmpl_common
004DF0r 2               cmpl_common:
004DF0r 2                   ; At this point, A contains the opcode to be compiled,
004DF0r 2                   ; the LSB of the address is on the 65c02 stack, and the MSB of
004DF0r 2                   ; the address is in Y
004DF0r 2  20 rr rr         jsr cmpl_a      ; compile opcode
004DF3r 2  68               pla             ; retrieve address LSB; fall thru to cmpl_word
004DF4r 2               cmpl_word:
004DF4r 2                   ; This is the entry point to compile a word (little-endian)
004DF4r 2  20 rr rr         jsr cmpl_a      ; compile LSB of address
004DF7r 2  98               tya             ; fall thru for MSB
004DF8r 2               cmpl_a:
004DF8r 2                   ; This is the entry point to compile a single byte which
004DF8r 2                   ; is passed in A. The built-in assembler assumes that this
004DF8r 2                   ; routine does not modify Y.
004DF8r 2  92 rr            sta (cp)
004DFAr 2  E6 rr            inc cp
004DFCr 2  D0 02            bne _done
004DFEr 2  E6 rr            inc cp+1
004E00r 2               _done:
004E00r 2  60               rts
004E01r 2               
004E01r 2               
004E01r 2               
004E01r 2               ; =====================================================================
004E01r 2               ; CODE FIELD ROUTINES
004E01r 2               
004E01r 2               doconst:
004E01r 2               ; """Execute a CONSTANT: Push the data in the first two bytes of
004E01r 2               ; the Data Field onto the Data Stack
004E01r 2               ; """
004E01r 2  CA               dex             ; make room for constant
004E02r 2  CA               dex
004E03r 2               
004E03r 2                   ; The value we need is stored in the two bytes after the
004E03r 2                   ; JSR return address, which in turn is what is on top of
004E03r 2                   ; the Return Stack
004E03r 2  68               pla             ; LSB of return address
004E04r 2  85 rr            sta tmp1
004E06r 2  68               pla             ; MSB of return address
004E07r 2  85 rr            sta tmp1+1
004E09r 2               
004E09r 2                   ; Start LDY with 1 instead of 0 because of how JSR stores
004E09r 2                   ; the return address on the 65c02
004E09r 2  A0 01            ldy #1
004E0Br 2  B1 rr            lda (tmp1),y
004E0Dr 2  95 00            sta 0,x
004E0Fr 2  C8               iny
004E10r 2  B1 rr            lda (tmp1),y
004E12r 2  95 01            sta 1,x
004E14r 2               
004E14r 2                   ; This takes us back to the original caller, not the
004E14r 2                   ; DOCONST caller
004E14r 2  60               rts
004E15r 2               
004E15r 2               
004E15r 2               dodefer:
004E15r 2               ; """Execute a DEFER statement at runtime: Execute the address we
004E15r 2               ; find after the caller in the Data Field
004E15r 2               ; """
004E15r 2                   ; The xt we need is stored in the two bytes after the JSR
004E15r 2                   ; return address, which is what is on top of the Return
004E15r 2                   ; Stack. So all we have to do is replace our return jump
004E15r 2                   ; with what we find there
004E15r 2  68               pla             ; LSB
004E16r 2  85 rr            sta tmp1
004E18r 2  68               pla             ; MSB
004E19r 2  85 rr            sta tmp1+1
004E1Br 2               
004E1Br 2  A0 01            ldy #1
004E1Dr 2  B1 rr            lda (tmp1),y
004E1Fr 2  85 rr            sta tmp2
004E21r 2  C8               iny
004E22r 2  B1 rr            lda (tmp1),y
004E24r 2  85 rr            sta tmp2+1
004E26r 2               
004E26r 2  6C rr rr         jmp (tmp2)      ; This is actually a jump to the new target
004E29r 2               
004E29r 2               defer_error:
004E29r 2                   ; """Error routine for undefined DEFER: Complain and abort"""
004E29r 2  A9 03            lda #err_defer
004E2Br 2  4C rr rr         jmp error
004E2Er 2               
004E2Er 2               dodoes:
004E2Er 2               ; """Execute the runtime portion of DOES>. See DOES> and
004E2Er 2               ; docs/create-does.txt for details and
004E2Er 2               ; http://www.bradrodriguez.com/papers/moving3.htm
004E2Er 2               ; """
004E2Er 2                   ; Assumes the address of the CFA of the original defining word
004E2Er 2                   ; (say, CONSTANT) is on the top of the Return Stack. Save it
004E2Er 2                   ; for a later jump, adding one byte because of the way the
004E2Er 2                   ; 6502 works
004E2Er 2  7A               ply             ; LSB
004E2Fr 2  68               pla             ; MSB
004E30r 2  C8               iny
004E31r 2  D0 01            bne @1
004E33r 2  1A               inc
004E34r 2               @1:
004E34r 2  84 rr            sty tmp2
004E36r 2  85 rr            sta tmp2+1
004E38r 2               
004E38r 2                   ; Next on the Return Stack should be the address of the PFA of
004E38r 2                   ; the calling defined word (say, the name of whatever constant we
004E38r 2                   ; just defined). Move this to the Data Stack, again adding one.
004E38r 2  CA               dex
004E39r 2  CA               dex
004E3Ar 2               
004E3Ar 2  7A               ply
004E3Br 2  68               pla
004E3Cr 2  C8               iny
004E3Dr 2  D0 01            bne @2
004E3Fr 2  1A               inc
004E40r 2               @2:
004E40r 2  94 00            sty 0,x         ; LSB
004E42r 2  95 01            sta 1,x         ; MSB
004E44r 2               
004E44r 2                   ; This leaves the return address from the original main routine
004E44r 2                   ; on top of the Return Stack. We leave that untouched and jump
004E44r 2                   ; to the special code of the defining word. It's RTS instruction
004E44r 2                   ; will take us back to the main routine
004E44r 2  6C rr rr         jmp (tmp2)
004E47r 2               
004E47r 2               
004E47r 2               dovar:
004E47r 2               ; """Execute a variable: Push the address of the first bytes of
004E47r 2               ; the Data Field onto the stack. This is called with JSR so we
004E47r 2               ; can pick up the address of the calling variable off the 65c02's
004E47r 2               ; stack. The final RTS takes us to the original caller of the
004E47r 2               ; routine that itself called DOVAR. This is the default
004E47r 2               ; routine installed with CREATE.
004E47r 2               ; """
004E47r 2                   ; Pull the return address off the machine's stack, adding
004E47r 2                   ; one because of the way the 65c02 handles subroutines
004E47r 2  7A               ply             ; LSB
004E48r 2  68               pla             ; MSB
004E49r 2  C8               iny
004E4Ar 2  D0 01            bne @1
004E4Cr 2  1A               inc
004E4Dr 2               @1:
004E4Dr 2  CA               dex
004E4Er 2  CA               dex
004E4Fr 2               
004E4Fr 2  95 01            sta 1,x
004E51r 2  98               tya
004E52r 2  95 00            sta 0,x
004E54r 2               
004E54r 2  60               rts
004E55r 2               
004E55r 2               ; =====================================================================
004E55r 2               ; LOW LEVEL HELPER FUNCTIONS
004E55r 2               
004E55r 2               byte_to_ascii:
004E55r 2               ; """Convert byte in A to two ASCII hex digits and EMIT them"""
004E55r 2               .scope
004E55r 2  48               pha
004E56r 2  4A               lsr             ; convert high nibble first
004E57r 2  4A               lsr
004E58r 2  4A               lsr
004E59r 2  4A               lsr
004E5Ar 2  20 rr rr         jsr _nibble_to_ascii
004E5Dr 2  68               pla
004E5Er 2               
004E5Er 2                   ; fall through to _nibble_to_ascii
004E5Er 2               
004E5Er 2               _nibble_to_ascii:
004E5Er 2               ; """Private helper function for byte_to_ascii: Print lower nibble
004E5Er 2               ; of A and and EMIT it. This does the actual work.
004E5Er 2               ; """
004E5Er 2  29 0F            and #$0F
004E60r 2  09 30            ora #'0'
004E62r 2  C9 3A            cmp #$3A        ; '9+1
004E64r 2  90 02            bcc @1
004E66r 2  69 06            adc #$06
004E68r 2               
004E68r 2  4C rr rr     @1:               jmp emit_a
004E6Br 2               
004E6Br 2  60               rts
004E6Cr 2               .endscope
004E6Cr 2               
004E6Cr 2               compare_16bit:
004E6Cr 2               ; """Compare TOS/NOS and return results in form of the 65c02 flags
004E6Cr 2               ; Adapted from Leventhal "6502 Assembly Language Subroutines", see
004E6Cr 2               ; also http://www.6502.org/tutorials/compare_beyond.html
004E6Cr 2               ; For signed numbers, Z signals equality and N which number is larger:
004E6Cr 2               ;       if TOS = NOS: Z=1 and N=0
004E6Cr 2               ;       if TOS > NOS: Z=0 and N=0
004E6Cr 2               ;       if TOS < NOS: Z=0 and N=1
004E6Cr 2               ; For unsigned numbers, Z signals equality and C which number is larger:
004E6Cr 2               ;       if TOS = NOS: Z=1 and N=0
004E6Cr 2               ;       if TOS > NOS: Z=0 and C=1
004E6Cr 2               ;       if TOS < NOS: Z=0 and C=0
004E6Cr 2               ; Compared to the book routine, WORD1 (MINUED) is TOS
004E6Cr 2               ;                               WORD2 (SUBTRAHEND) is NOS
004E6Cr 2               ; """
004E6Cr 2               .scope
004E6Cr 2                   ; Compare LSB first to set the carry flag
004E6Cr 2  B5 00            lda 0,x                 ; LSB of TOS
004E6Er 2  D5 02            cmp 2,x                 ; LSB of NOS
004E70r 2  F0 0A            beq _equal
004E72r 2               
004E72r 2                   ; LSBs are not equal, compare MSB
004E72r 2  B5 01            lda 1,x                 ; MSB of TOS
004E74r 2  F5 03            sbc 3,x                 ; MSB of NOS
004E76r 2  09 01            ora #1                  ; Make zero flag 0 because not equal
004E78r 2  70 08            bvs _overflow
004E7Ar 2  80 08            bra _not_equal
004E7Cr 2               _equal:
004E7Cr 2                   ; Low bytes are equal, so we compare high bytes
004E7Cr 2  B5 01            lda 1,x                 ; MSB of TOS
004E7Er 2  F5 03            sbc 3,x                 ; MSB of NOS
004E80r 2  50 04            bvc _done
004E82r 2               _overflow:
004E82r 2                   ; Handle overflow because we use signed numbers
004E82r 2  49 80            eor #$80                ; complement negative flag
004E84r 2               _not_equal:
004E84r 2  09 01            ora #1                  ; if overflow, we can't be eqal
004E86r 2               _done:
004E86r 2  60               rts
004E87r 2               .endscope
004E87r 2               
004E87r 2               current_to_dp:
004E87r 2               ; """Look up the current (compilation) dictionary pointer
004E87r 2               ; in the wordlist set and put it into the dp zero-page
004E87r 2               ; variable. Uses A and Y.
004E87r 2               ; """
004E87r 2                   ; Determine which wordlist is current
004E87r 2  A0 04            ldy #current_offset
004E89r 2  B1 rr            lda (up),y      ; current is a byte variable
004E8Br 2  0A               asl             ; turn it into an offset (in cells)
004E8Cr 2               
004E8Cr 2                   ; Get the dictionary pointer for that wordlist.
004E8Cr 2  18               clc
004E8Dr 2  69 06            adc #wordlists_offset   ; add offset to wordlists base.
004E8Fr 2  A8               tay
004E90r 2  B1 rr            lda (up),y              ; get the dp for that wordlist.
004E92r 2  85 rr            sta dp
004E94r 2  C8               iny
004E95r 2  B1 rr            lda (up),y
004E97r 2  85 rr            sta dp+1
004E99r 2               
004E99r 2  60               rts
004E9Ar 2               
004E9Ar 2               
004E9Ar 2               dp_to_current:
004E9Ar 2               ; """Look up which wordlist is current and update its pointer
004E9Ar 2               ; with the value in dp. Uses A and Y.
004E9Ar 2               ; """
004E9Ar 2                   ; Determine which wordlist is current
004E9Ar 2  A0 04            ldy #current_offset
004E9Cr 2  B1 rr            lda (up),y      ; current is a byte variable
004E9Er 2  0A               asl             ; turn it into an offset (in cells)
004E9Fr 2               
004E9Fr 2                   ; Get the dictionary pointer for that wordlist.
004E9Fr 2  18               clc
004EA0r 2  69 06            adc #wordlists_offset   ; add offset to wordlists base.
004EA2r 2  A8               tay
004EA3r 2  A5 rr            lda dp
004EA5r 2  91 rr            sta (up),y              ; get the dp for that wordlist.
004EA7r 2  C8               iny
004EA8r 2  A5 rr            lda dp+1
004EAAr 2  91 rr            sta (up),y
004EACr 2               
004EACr 2  60               rts
004EADr 2               
004EADr 2               interpret:
004EADr 2               .scope
004EADr 2               ; """Core routine for the interpreter called by EVALUATE and QUIT.
004EADr 2               ; Process one line only. Assumes that the address of name is in
004EADr 2               ; cib and the length of the whole input line string is in ciblen
004EADr 2               ; """
004EADr 2                   ; Normally we would use PARSE here with the SPACE character as
004EADr 2                   ; a parameter (PARSE replaces WORD in modern Forths). However,
004EADr 2                   ; Gforth's PARSE-NAME makes more sense as it uses spaces as
004EADr 2                   ; delimiters per default and skips any leading spaces, which
004EADr 2                   ; PARSE doesn't
004EADr 2               _loop:
004EADr 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_parse_name       ; ( "string" -- addr u )
004EB0r 2               
004EB0r 2                   ; If PARSE-NAME returns 0 (empty line), no characters were left
004EB0r 2                   ; in the line and we need to go get a new line
004EB0r 2  B5 00            lda 0,x
004EB2r 2  15 01            ora 1,x
004EB4r 2  F0 70            beq _line_done
004EB6r 2               
004EB6r 2                   ; Go to FIND-NAME to see if this is a word we know. We have to
004EB6r 2                   ; make a copy of the address in case it isn't a word we know and
004EB6r 2                   ; we have to go see if it is a number
004EB6r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_two_dup          ; ( addr u -- addr u addr u )
004EB9r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_find_name        ; ( addr u addr u -- addr u nt|0 )
004EBCr 2               
004EBCr 2                   ; A zero signals that we didn't find a word in the Dictionary
004EBCr 2  B5 00            lda 0,x
004EBEr 2  15 01            ora 1,x
004EC0r 2  D0 28            bne _got_name_token
004EC2r 2               
004EC2r 2                   ; We didn't get any nt we know of, so let's see if this is
004EC2r 2                   ; a number.
004EC2r 2  E8               inx                     ; ( addr u 0 -- addr u )
004EC3r 2  E8               inx
004EC4r 2               
004EC4r 2                   ; If the number conversion doesn't work, NUMBER will do the
004EC4r 2                   ; complaining for us
004EC4r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_number           ; ( addr u -- u|d )
004EC7r 2               
004EC7r 2                   ; Otherweise, if we're interpreting, we're done
004EC7r 2  A5 rr            lda state
004EC9r 2  F0 E2            beq _loop
004ECBr 2               
004ECBr 2                   ; We're compiling, so there is a bit more work.  Check
004ECBr 2                   ; status bit 5 to see if it's a single or double-cell
004ECBr 2                   ; number.
004ECBr 2  A9 20            lda #$20
004ECDr 2  24 rr            bit status
004ECFr 2  F0 0D            beq _single_number
004ED1r 2               
004ED1r 2                   ; It's a double cell number.  If we swap the
004ED1r 2                   ; upper and lower half, we can use the literal_runtime twice
004ED1r 2                   ; to compile it into the dictionary.
004ED1r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_swap
004ED4r 2  A0 rr            ldy #>literal_runtime
004ED6r 2  A9 rr            lda #<literal_runtime
004ED8r 2  20 rr rr         jsr cmpl_subroutine
004EDBr 2               
004EDBr 2                   ; compile our number
004EDBr 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_comma
004EDEr 2               
004EDEr 2                   ; Fall into _single_number to process the other half.
004EDEr 2               _single_number:
004EDEr 2  A0 rr            ldy #>literal_runtime
004EE0r 2  A9 rr            lda #<literal_runtime
004EE2r 2  20 rr rr         jsr cmpl_subroutine
004EE5r 2               
004EE5r 2                   ; compile our number
004EE5r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_comma
004EE8r 2               
004EE8r 2                   ; That was so much fun, let's do it again!
004EE8r 2  80 C3            bra _loop
004EEAr 2               
004EEAr 2               _got_name_token:
004EEAr 2                   ; We have a known word's nt TOS. We're going to need its xt
004EEAr 2                   ; though, which is four bytes father down.
004EEAr 2               
004EEAr 2                   ; We arrive here with ( addr u nt ), so we NIP twice
004EEAr 2  B5 00            lda 0,x
004EECr 2  95 04            sta 4,x
004EEEr 2  B5 01            lda 1,x
004EF0r 2  95 05            sta 5,x
004EF2r 2               
004EF2r 2  E8               inx
004EF3r 2  E8               inx
004EF4r 2  E8               inx
004EF5r 2  E8               inx                     ; ( nt )
004EF6r 2               
004EF6r 2                   ; Save a version of nt for error handling and compilation stuff
004EF6r 2  B5 00            lda 0,x
004EF8r 2  85 rr            sta tmpbranch
004EFAr 2  B5 01            lda 1,x
004EFCr 2  85 rr            sta tmpbranch+1
004EFEr 2               
004EFEr 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_name_to_int      ; ( nt - xt )
004F01r 2               
004F01r 2                   ; See if we are in interpret or compile mode, 0 is interpret
004F01r 2  A5 rr            lda state
004F03r 2  D0 13            bne _compile
004F05r 2               
004F05r 2                   ; We are interpreting, so EXECUTE the xt that is TOS. First,
004F05r 2                   ; though, see if this isn't a compile-only word, which would be
004F05r 2                   ; illegal. The status byte is the second one of the header.
004F05r 2  A0 01            ldy #1
004F07r 2  B1 rr            lda (tmpbranch),y
004F09r 2  29 01            and #CO                 ; mask everything but Compile Only bit
004F0Br 2  F0 05            beq _interpret
004F0Dr 2               
004F0Dr 2  A9 02            lda #err_compileonly
004F0Fr 2  4C rr rr         jmp error
004F12r 2               
004F12r 2               _interpret:
004F12r 2                   ; We JSR to EXECUTE instead of calling the xt directly because
004F12r 2                   ; the RTS of the word we're executing will bring us back here,
004F12r 2                   ; skipping EXECUTE completely during RTS. If we were to execute
004F12r 2                   ; xt directly, we have to fool around with the Return Stack
004F12r 2                   ; instead, which is actually slightly slower
004F12r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_execute
004F15r 2               
004F15r 2                   ; That's quite enough for this word, let's get the next one
004F15r 2  4C rr rr         jmp _loop
004F18r 2               
004F18r 2               _compile:
004F18r 2                   ; We're compiling! However, we need to see if this is an
004F18r 2                   ; IMMEDIATE word, which would mean we execute it right now even
004F18r 2                   ; during compilation mode. Fortunately, we saved the nt so life
004F18r 2                   ; is easier. The flags are in the second byte of the header
004F18r 2  A0 01            ldy #1
004F1Ar 2  B1 rr            lda (tmpbranch),y
004F1Cr 2  29 04            and #IM                 ; Mask all but IM bit
004F1Er 2  D0 F2            bne _interpret          ; IMMEDIATE word, execute right now
004F20r 2               
004F20r 2                   ; Compile the xt into the Dictionary with COMPILE,
004F20r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_compile_comma
004F23r 2  4C rr rr         jmp _loop
004F26r 2               
004F26r 2               _line_done:
004F26r 2                   ; drop stuff from PARSE_NAME
004F26r 2  E8               inx
004F27r 2  E8               inx
004F28r 2  E8               inx
004F29r 2  E8               inx
004F2Ar 2               
004F2Ar 2  60               rts
004F2Br 2               .endscope
004F2Br 2               
004F2Br 2               
004F2Br 2               is_printable:
004F2Br 2               .scope
004F2Br 2               ; """Given a character in A, check if it is a printable ASCII
004F2Br 2               ; character in the range from $20 to $7E inclusive. Returns the
004F2Br 2               ; result in the Carry Flag: 0 (clear) is not printable, 1 (set)
004F2Br 2               ; is printable. Keeps A. See
004F2Br 2               ; http://www.obelisk.me.uk/6502/algorithms.html for a
004F2Br 2               ; discussion of various ways to do this
004F2Br 2  C9 20            cmp #AscSP              ; $20
004F2Dr 2  90 08            bcc _done
004F2Fr 2  C9 7F            cmp #'~' + 1             ; $7E
004F31r 2  B0 03            bcs _failed
004F33r 2               
004F33r 2  38               sec
004F34r 2  80 01            bra _done
004F36r 2               _failed:
004F36r 2  18               clc
004F37r 2               _done:
004F37r 2  60               rts
004F38r 2               .endscope
004F38r 2               
004F38r 2               
004F38r 2               is_whitespace:
004F38r 2               .scope
004F38r 2               ; """Given a character in A, check if it is a whitespace
004F38r 2               ; character, that is, an ASCII value from 0 to 32 (where
004F38r 2               ; 32 is SPACE). Returns the result in the Carry Flag:
004F38r 2               ; 0 (clear) is no, it isn't whitespace, while 1 (set) means
004F38r 2               ; that it is whitespace. See PARSE and PARSE-NAME for
004F38r 2               ; a discussion of the uses. Does not change A or Y.
004F38r 2  C9 00            cmp #00         ; explicit comparison to leave Y untouched
004F3Ar 2  90 08            bcc _done
004F3Cr 2               
004F3Cr 2  C9 21            cmp #AscSP+1
004F3Er 2  B0 03            bcs _failed
004F40r 2               
004F40r 2  38               sec
004F41r 2  80 01            bra _done
004F43r 2               _failed:
004F43r 2  18               clc
004F44r 2               _done:
004F44r 2  60               rts
004F45r 2               .endscope
004F45r 2               
004F45r 2               
004F45r 2               ; Underflow tests. We jump to the label with the number of cells (not: bytes)
004F45r 2               ; required for the word. This routine flows into the generic error handling
004F45r 2               ; code
004F45r 2               underflow_1:
004F45r 2               ; """Make sure we have at least one cell on the Data Stack"""
004F45r 2  E0 rr            cpx #dsp0-1
004F47r 2  10 10            bpl underflow_error
004F49r 2  60               rts
004F4Ar 2               underflow_2:
004F4Ar 2               ; """Make sure we have at least two cells on the Data Stack"""
004F4Ar 2  E0 rr            cpx #dsp0-3
004F4Cr 2  10 0B            bpl underflow_error
004F4Er 2  60               rts
004F4Fr 2               underflow_3:
004F4Fr 2               ; """Make sure we have at least three cells on the Data Stack"""
004F4Fr 2  E0 rr            cpx #dsp0-5
004F51r 2  10 06            bpl underflow_error
004F53r 2  60               rts
004F54r 2               underflow_4:
004F54r 2               ; """Make sure we have at least four cells on the Data Stack"""
004F54r 2  E0 rr            cpx #dsp0-7
004F56r 2  10 01            bpl underflow_error
004F58r 2  60               rts
004F59r 2               
004F59r 2               underflow_error:
004F59r 2                   ; Entry for COLD/ABORT/QUIT
004F59r 2  A9 09            lda #err_underflow      ; fall through to error
004F5Br 2               
004F5Br 2               error:
004F5Br 2               ; """Given the error number in a, print the associated error string and
004F5Br 2               ; call abort. Uses tmp3.
004F5Br 2               ; """
004F5Br 2  0A               asl
004F5Cr 2  A8               tay
004F5Dr 2  B9 rr rr         lda error_table,y
004F60r 2  85 rr            sta tmp3                ; LSB
004F62r 2  C8               iny
004F63r 2  B9 rr rr         lda error_table,y
004F66r 2  85 rr            sta tmp3+1              ; MSB
004F68r 2               
004F68r 2  20 rr rr         jsr print_common
004F6Br 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_cr
004F6Er 2  4C rr rr         jmp xt_abort            ; no jsr, as we clobber return stack
004F71r 2               
004F71r 2               
004F71r 2               ; =====================================================================
004F71r 2               ; PRINTING ROUTINES
004F71r 2               
004F71r 2               ; We distinguish two types of print calls, both of which take the string number
004F71r 2               ; (see strings.asm) in A:
004F71r 2               
004F71r 2               ;       print_string       - with a line feed
004F71r 2               ;       print_string_no_lf - without a line feed
004F71r 2               
004F71r 2               ; In addition, print_common provides a lower-level alternative for error
004F71r 2               ; handling and anything else that provides the address of the
004F71r 2               ; zero-terminated string directly in tmp3. All of those routines assume that
004F71r 2               ; printing should be more concerned with size than speed, because anything to
004F71r 2               ; do with humans reading text is going to be slow.
004F71r 2               
004F71r 2               print_string_no_lf:
004F71r 2               ; """Given the number of a zero-terminated string in A, print it to the
004F71r 2               ; current output without adding a LF. Uses Y and tmp3 by falling
004F71r 2               ; through to print_common
004F71r 2               ; """
004F71r 2                   ; Get the entry from the string table
004F71r 2  0A               asl
004F72r 2  A8               tay
004F73r 2  B9 rr rr         lda string_table,y
004F76r 2  85 rr            sta tmp3                ; LSB
004F78r 2  C8               iny
004F79r 2  B9 rr rr         lda string_table,y
004F7Cr 2  85 rr            sta tmp3+1              ; MSB
004F7Er 2               
004F7Er 2                   ; fall through to print_common
004F7Er 2               print_common:
004F7Er 2               ; """Common print routine used by both the print functions and
004F7Er 2               ; the error printing routine. Assumes string address is in tmp3. Uses
004F7Er 2               ; Y.
004F7Er 2               ; """
004F7Er 2               .scope
004F7Er 2  A0 00            ldy #0
004F80r 2               _loop:
004F80r 2  B1 rr            lda (tmp3),y
004F82r 2  F0 06            beq _done               ; strings are zero-terminated
004F84r 2               
004F84r 2  20 rr rr         jsr emit_a              ; allows vectoring via output
004F87r 2  C8               iny
004F88r 2  80 F6            bra _loop
004F8Ar 2               _done:
004F8Ar 2  60               rts
004F8Br 2               .endscope
004F8Br 2               
004F8Br 2               print_string:
004F8Br 2               ; """Print a zero-terminated string to the console/screen, adding a LF.
004F8Br 2               ; We do not check to see if the index is out of range. Uses tmp3.
004F8Br 2               ; """
004F8Br 2  20 rr rr         jsr print_string_no_lf
004F8Er 2  4C rr rr         jmp xt_cr               ; JSR/RTS because never compiled
004F91r 2               
004F91r 2               
004F91r 2               print_u:
004F91r 2               ; """basic printing routine used by higher-level constructs,
004F91r 2               ; the equivalent of the forth word  0 <# #s #> type  which is
004F91r 2               ; basically u. without the space at the end. used for various
004F91r 2               ; outputs
004F91r 2               ; """
004F91r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_zero                     ; 0
004F94r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_less_number_sign         ; <#
004F97r 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_number_sign_s            ; #S
004F9Ar 2  20 rr rr         jsr xt_number_sign_greater      ; #>
004F9Dr 2  4C rr rr         jmp xt_type                     ; JSR/RTS because never compiled
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; END
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 1               
004FA0r 1               .segment "DATA"
004FA0r 1               
004FA0r 1               .ifdef TALI_OPTIONAL_ASSEMBLER
004FA0r 1               .include "../../assembler.s"
004FA0r 2               ; Assembler for Tali Forth 2
004FA0r 2               ; Scot W. Stevenson <scot.stevenson@gmail.com>
004FA0r 2               ; First version: 07. Nov 2014 (as tasm65c02)
004FA0r 2               ; This version: 03. Jan 2019
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; This is the built-in assembler for Tali Forth 2. Once the assembler wordlist
004FA0r 2               ; is included with
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ;       assembler-wordlist >order
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; the opcodes are available as normal Forth words. The format is Simpler
004FA0r 2               ; Assembler Notation (SAN) which separates the opcode completely from the
004FA0r 2               ; operand (see https://github.com/scotws/SAN). In this case, the operand is
004FA0r 2               ; entered before the opcode in the postfix Forth notation (for example, "2000
004FA0r 2               ; lda.#"). See the assembler documenation in the manual for more detail.
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; The code here was originally used in A Typist's Assembler for the 65c02
004FA0r 2               ; (tasm65c02), see https://github.com/scotws/tasm65c02 for the standalone
004FA0r 2               ; version. Tasm65c02 is in the public domain.
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; This code makes use of the opcode tables stored as part of the disassembler.
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; ==========================================================
004FA0r 2               ; MNEMONICS
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; The assembler instructions are realized as individual Forth words with
004FA0r 2               ; entries in the assembler wordlist (see header.asm). We pass the opcode in A.
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; An alterantive method would have been along the lines of
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ;               jsr asm_common
004FA0r 2               ;               .byte $EA
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; where the asm_common then uses the address on the Return Stack to pick up the
004FA0r 2               ; opcode and the length. Though this uses fewer resources, the current version
004FA0r 2               ; makes up for this by simplifying the code of asm_common.
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               ; The routines are organized alphabetically by SAN mnemonic, not by opcode. The
004FA0r 2               ; SAN and traditional mnemonics are listed after the opcode load instruction.
004FA0r 2               ; This list was generated by a Python script in the tools folder, see there for
004FA0r 2               ; more detail.
004FA0r 2               
004FA0r 2               assembler:              ; used to calculate size of assembler code
004FA0r 2               .ifdef TALI_OPTIONAL_ASSEMBLER
004FA0r 2               xt_asm_adc_h:   ; adc.# \ ADC #nn
004FA0r 2  A9 69                        lda #$69
004FA2r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FA5r 2               z_asm_adc_h:
004FA5r 2               
004FA5r 2               xt_asm_adc_x:   ; adc.x \ ADC nnnn,X
004FA5r 2  A9 7D                        lda #$7D
004FA7r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FAAr 2               z_asm_adc_x:
004FAAr 2               
004FAAr 2               xt_asm_adc_y:   ; adc.y \ ADC nnnn,Y
004FAAr 2  A9 79                        lda #$79
004FACr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FAFr 2               z_asm_adc_y:
004FAFr 2               
004FAFr 2               xt_asm_adc_z:   ; adc.z \ ADC nn
004FAFr 2  A9 65                        lda #$65
004FB1r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FB4r 2               z_asm_adc_z:
004FB4r 2               
004FB4r 2               xt_asm_adc_zi:  ; adc.zi \ ADC (nn)
004FB4r 2  A9 72                        lda #$72
004FB6r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FB9r 2               z_asm_adc_zi:
004FB9r 2               
004FB9r 2               xt_asm_adc_ziy: ; adc.ziy \ ADC (nn),Y
004FB9r 2  A9 71                        lda #$71
004FBBr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FBEr 2               z_asm_adc_ziy:
004FBEr 2               
004FBEr 2               xt_asm_adc_zx:  ; adc.zx \ ADC nn,X
004FBEr 2  A9 75                        lda #$75
004FC0r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FC3r 2               z_asm_adc_zx:
004FC3r 2               
004FC3r 2               xt_asm_adc_zxi: ; adc.zxi \ ADC (nn,X)
004FC3r 2  A9 61                        lda #$61
004FC5r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FC8r 2               z_asm_adc_zxi:
004FC8r 2               
004FC8r 2               xt_asm_and:     ; and. \ AND nnnn
004FC8r 2  A9 2D                        lda #$2D
004FCAr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FCDr 2               z_asm_and:
004FCDr 2               
004FCDr 2               xt_asm_and_h:   ; and.# \ AND #nn
004FCDr 2  A9 29                        lda #$29
004FCFr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FD2r 2               z_asm_and_h:
004FD2r 2               
004FD2r 2               xt_asm_and_x:   ; and.x \ AND nnnn,X
004FD2r 2  A9 3D                        lda #$3D
004FD4r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FD7r 2               z_asm_and_x:
004FD7r 2               
004FD7r 2               xt_asm_and_y:   ; and.y \ AND nnnn,Y
004FD7r 2  A9 39                        lda #$39
004FD9r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FDCr 2               z_asm_and_y:
004FDCr 2               
004FDCr 2               xt_asm_and_z:   ; and.z \ AND nn
004FDCr 2  A9 25                        lda #$25
004FDEr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FE1r 2               z_asm_and_z:
004FE1r 2               
004FE1r 2               xt_asm_and_zi:  ; and.zi \ AND (nn)
004FE1r 2  A9 32                        lda #$32
004FE3r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FE6r 2               z_asm_and_zi:
004FE6r 2               
004FE6r 2               xt_asm_and_ziy: ; and.ziy \ AND (nn),Y
004FE6r 2  A9 31                        lda #$31
004FE8r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FEBr 2               z_asm_and_ziy:
004FEBr 2               
004FEBr 2               xt_asm_and_zx:  ; and.zx \ AND nn,X
004FEBr 2  A9 35                        lda #$35
004FEDr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FF0r 2               z_asm_and_zx:
004FF0r 2               
004FF0r 2               xt_asm_and_zxi: ; and.zxi \ AND (nn,X)
004FF0r 2  A9 21                        lda #$21
004FF2r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FF5r 2               z_asm_and_zxi:
004FF5r 2               
004FF5r 2               xt_asm_asl:     ; asl \ ASL nnnn
004FF5r 2  A9 0E                        lda #$0E
004FF7r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FFAr 2               z_asm_asl:
004FFAr 2               
004FFAr 2               xt_asm_asl_a:   ; asl.a \ ASL
004FFAr 2  A9 0A                        lda #$0A
004FFCr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
004FFFr 2               z_asm_asl_a:
004FFFr 2               
004FFFr 2               xt_asm_asl_x:   ; asl.x \ ASL nnnn,X
004FFFr 2  A9 1E                        lda #$1E
005001r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005004r 2               z_asm_asl_x:
005004r 2               
005004r 2               xt_asm_asl_z:   ; asl.z \ ASL nn
005004r 2  A9 06                        lda #$06
005006r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005009r 2               z_asm_asl_z:
005009r 2               
005009r 2               xt_asm_asl_zx:  ; asl.zx \ ASL nn,X
005009r 2  A9 16                        lda #$16
00500Br 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00500Er 2               z_asm_asl_zx:
00500Er 2               
00500Er 2               xt_asm_bcc:     ; bcc \ BCC
00500Er 2  A9 90                        lda #$90
005010r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005013r 2               z_asm_bcc:
005013r 2               
005013r 2               xt_asm_bcs:     ; bcs \ BCS
005013r 2  A9 B0                        lda #$B0
005015r 2  A0 02                        ldy #2
005017r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00501Ar 2               z_asm_bcs:
00501Ar 2               
00501Ar 2               xt_asm_beq:     ; beq \ BEQ
00501Ar 2  A9 F0                        lda #$F0
00501Cr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00501Fr 2               z_asm_beq:
00501Fr 2               
00501Fr 2               xt_asm_bit:     ; bit \ BIT nnnn
00501Fr 2  A9 2C                        lda #$2C
005021r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005024r 2               z_asm_bit:
005024r 2               
005024r 2               xt_asm_bit_h:   ; bit.# \ BIT #nn
005024r 2  A9 89                        lda #$89
005026r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005029r 2               z_asm_bit_h:
005029r 2               
005029r 2               xt_asm_bit_x:   ; bit.x \ BIT nnnn,X
005029r 2  A9 3C                        lda #$3C
00502Br 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00502Er 2               z_asm_bit_x:
00502Er 2               
00502Er 2               xt_asm_bit_z:   ; bit.z \ BIT nn
00502Er 2  A9 24                        lda #$24
005030r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005033r 2               z_asm_bit_z:
005033r 2               
005033r 2               xt_asm_bit_zx:  ; bit.zx \ BIT nn,X
005033r 2  A9 34                        lda #$34
005035r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005038r 2               z_asm_bit_zx:
005038r 2               
005038r 2               xt_asm_bmi:     ; bmi \ BMI
005038r 2  A9 30                        lda #$30
00503Ar 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00503Dr 2               z_asm_bmi:
00503Dr 2               
00503Dr 2               xt_asm_bne:     ; bne \ BNE
00503Dr 2  A9 D0                        lda #$D0
00503Fr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005042r 2               z_asm_bne:
005042r 2               
005042r 2               xt_asm_bpl:     ; bpl \ BPL
005042r 2  A9 10                        lda #$10
005044r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005047r 2               z_asm_bpl:
005047r 2               
005047r 2               xt_asm_bra:     ; bra \ BRA
005047r 2  A9 80                        lda #$80
005049r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00504Cr 2               z_asm_bra:
00504Cr 2               
00504Cr 2               xt_asm_brk:     ; brk \ BRK
00504Cr 2  A9 00                        lda #$00
00504Er 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005051r 2               z_asm_brk:
005051r 2               
005051r 2               xt_asm_bvc:     ; bvc \ BVC
005051r 2  A9 50                        lda #$50
005053r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005056r 2               z_asm_bvc:
005056r 2               
005056r 2               xt_asm_bvs:     ; bvs \ BVS
005056r 2  A9 70                        lda #$70
005058r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00505Br 2               z_asm_bvs:
00505Br 2               
00505Br 2               xt_asm_clc:     ; clc \ CLC
00505Br 2  A9 18                        lda #$18
00505Dr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005060r 2               z_asm_clc:
005060r 2

005060r 2  A9 D8                        lda #$D8
005062r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005065r 2               z_asm_cld:
005065r 2

005065r 2  A9 58                        lda #$58
005067r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00506Ar 2               z_asm_cli:
00506Ar 2

00506Ar 2  A9 B8                        lda #$B8
00506Cr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00506Fr 2               z_asm_clv:
00506Fr 2               
00506Fr 2               xt_asm_cmp:     ; cmp \ CMP nnnn
00506Fr 2  A9 CD                        lda #$CD
005071r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005074r 2               z_asm_cmp:

005079r 2  A9 DD                        lda #$DD
00507Br 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00507Er 2               z_asm_cmp_x:
00507Er 2

00507Er 2  A9 D9                        lda #$D9
005080r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005083r 2               z_asm_cmp_y:

005083r 2  A9 C5                        lda #$C5
005085r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005088r 2               z_asm_cmp_z:

005088r 2  A9 D2                        lda #$D2
00508Ar 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00508Dr 2               z_asm_cmp_zi:

00508Dr 2  A9 D1                        lda #$D1
00508Fr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005092r 2               z_asm_cmp_ziy:

005092r 2  A9 D5                        lda #$D5
005094r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
005097r 2               z_asm_cmp_zx:

005097r 2  A9 C1                        lda #$C1
005099r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
00509Cr 2               z_asm_cmp_zxi:
00509Cr 2               
00509Cr 2               xt_asm_cpx:     ; cpx \ CPX nnnn
00509Cr 2  A9 EC                        lda #$EC
00509Er 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
0050A1r 2               z_asm_cpx:

0050A1r 2  A9 E0                        lda #$E0

0050A8r 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
0050ABr 2               z_asm_cpx_z:
0050ABr 2

0050ABr 2  A9 CC                        lda #$CC
0050ADr 2  A0 03                        ldy #3
0050AFr 2  4C rr rr                     jmp asm_common
0050B2r 2               z_asm_cpy:

005152r 2  A9 B9                        lda #$B9

005157r 2               z_asm_lda_y:
005157r 2

0051A2r 2               z_asm_ldy_zx:

0052D3r 2  A9 AA                        lda #$AA
0052D5r 2  80 24                        bra asm_common
0052D7r 2               z_asm_tax:
0052D7r 2

0052D7r 2  A9 A8                        lda #$A8
0052D9r 2  80 20                        bra asm_common
0052DBr 2               z_asm_tay:
0052DBr 2

0052DBr 2  A9 1C                        lda #$1C
0052DDr 2  80 1C                        bra asm_common
0052DFr 2               z_asm_trb:
0052DFr 2
